So taking a look at workbooks and

439
00:24:00.870 --> 00:24:03.800
worksheets, can it be
complicated at times?

440
00:24:03.800 --> 00:24:06.550
Yes, but is it something that we
definitely need to know how to do?

441
00:24:06.550 --> 00:24:08.230
You better believe it, right?

442
00:24:08.230 --> 00:24:11.900
And this actually makes for us being able
to work more effectively, especially with

443
00:24:11.900 --> 00:24:15.530
multiple workbooks, and especially with
multiple worksheets at the same time.

444
00:24:15.530 --> 00:24:18.403
So thank you, Mike, for actually showing
us all those different ways that we can

445
00:24:18.403 --> 00:24:20.120
work with workbooks and worksheets.

446
00:24:20.120 --> 00:24:22.120
Thank you also for watching.

447
00:24:22.120 --> 00:24:25.360
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

448
00:24:25.360 --> 00:24:26.250
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

449
00:24:26.250 --> 00:24:27.275
>> And we'll see you next time.

450
00:24:27.275 --> 00:24:33.260
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike help us to see the navigation feature that are built into Excel 2016.  Even though we can manually navigate around using the mouse or arrow keys, Mike shows how to use the Find tool as well as the Name Box to quickly navigate through large datasets within an Excel 2016 workbook.
episodes.title: Creating Workbooks Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.401 --> 00:00:10.401
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.564 --> 00:00:15.360
Welcome to another exciting
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.360 --> 00:00:17.310
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

4
00:00:17.310 --> 00:00:22.060
today we're gonna be taking a look
at Microsoft Office Excel 2016.

5
00:00:22.060 --> 00:00:25.280
And we're specifically gonna be
dealing with well navigation more than

6
00:00:25.280 --> 00:00:26.200
anything else.

7
00:00:26.200 --> 00:00:28.000
And you might find that a strange topic,
but

8
00:00:28.000 --> 00:00:30.580
here to help us out is
gonna be Mr Mike Rodrick.

9
00:00:30.580 --> 00:00:31.930
Mike how are you doing today?

10
00:00:31.930 --> 00:00:33.440
>> Doing great, Ronnie, glad to be here.

11
00:00:33.440 --> 00:00:35.440
And you're right we're gonna
continue on with Excel.

12
00:00:36.860 --> 00:00:40.940
First thing we really wanna take a look
at is as we start working with larger

13
00:00:40.940 --> 00:00:45.110
datasets, those navigation
techniques really become important.

14
00:00:45.110 --> 00:00:48.160
Being able to work my way
around that document,

15
00:00:48.160 --> 00:00:53.000
find what it is that I'm looking for, for
example, jump to particular spots within

16
00:00:53.000 --> 00:00:57.520
that document, all of that becomes key
to really making us more productive and

17
00:00:57.520 --> 00:01:00.300
more efficient working with
those larger documents.

18
00:01:00.300 --> 00:01:05.020
So I've got a document here on my
screen that has quite a few rows.

19
00:01:05.020 --> 00:01:11.650
If we jump down somewhere around
3,000 rows or something like that.

20
00:01:11.650 --> 00:01:14.000
So as you can see, I can scroll, right?

21
00:01:14.000 --> 00:01:15.760
And I can work my way through there.

22
00:01:15.760 --> 00:01:19.870
But let's say I'm looking for
a particular value or a particular item.

23
00:01:19.870 --> 00:01:25.570
If I start scrolling through here, I could
probably eventually find it, right, maybe.

24
00:01:25.570 --> 00:01:27.300
I might miss it and
get all the way to the end and

25
00:01:27.300 --> 00:01:31.350
go crud and now have to go back up
through it and try it again, right.

26
00:01:31.350 --> 00:01:33.450
There are tools within Excel.

27
00:01:33.450 --> 00:01:34.810
We don't have to do that, right?

28
00:01:34.810 --> 00:01:37.400
First one I wanna show you is right
over here on the home ribbon.

29
00:01:37.400 --> 00:01:39.732
Is this Find & Select, all right.

30
00:01:39.732 --> 00:01:43.890
So, I'm gonna go and click on that and
it's gonna open up a little dropdown list.

31
00:01:43.890 --> 00:01:45.960
And I'm just gonna choose Find.

32
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:50.145
And let's say I'm looking for, I know that
one of the products that we sell is called

33
00:01:50.145 --> 00:01:54.040
tricor, so I wanna see if anybody
has purchased any of this tricor.

34
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:59.310
So I'm simply gonna type in tricor and
then click Find Next.

35
00:01:59.310 --> 00:02:03.730
And notice it does two things,
it finds it and it also selects that cell.

36
00:02:03.730 --> 00:02:09.630
So my active cell, this green border
indicating the active cell, is now tricor.

37
00:02:09.630 --> 00:02:13.920
If I want to see if there is more of
those, I can click Find Next again, and

38
00:02:13.920 --> 00:02:15.500
now I'm down to row 243.

39
00:02:15.500 --> 00:02:18.880
It found another instance of that word.

40
00:02:18.880 --> 00:02:21.150
Now the Find has a few options.

41
00:02:21.150 --> 00:02:25.190
There's just your basic type it in,
click Find Next, and you're good to go.

42
00:02:25.190 --> 00:02:27.780
You could also do Find All.

43
00:02:27.780 --> 00:02:32.450
And what happens is, it opens up
this little or expands this window.

44
00:02:32.450 --> 00:02:35.990
And now I can see every
instance of Tricor.

45
00:02:35.990 --> 00:02:38.380
Without having to go next,
next, next, next, next,

46
00:02:38.380 --> 00:02:42.520
I could jump right to the last
instance by clicking on that and

47
00:02:42.520 --> 00:02:47.680
it takes me right to that cell
down that row 2799 for Tricor.

48
00:02:47.680 --> 00:02:49.460
So I like the Find All.

49
00:02:49.460 --> 00:02:51.890
You can also do some options in here.

50
00:02:51.890 --> 00:02:56.450
If I click Options with my find you'll see
a few options that might come in handy

51
00:02:56.450 --> 00:02:58.813
when you're searching for something.

52
00:02:58.813 --> 00:03:02.950
All right let's zoom in here and
take a look [COUGH].

53
00:03:02.950 --> 00:03:06.680
I typed in Tricor as what I was
looking for within Sheet, so

54
00:03:06.680 --> 00:03:08.710
it's just looking in this one worksheet.

55
00:03:08.710 --> 00:03:11.210
What if this workbook had
several worksheets and

56
00:03:11.210 --> 00:03:15.050
I wanted to find instances across
all those different worksheets?

57
00:03:15.050 --> 00:03:17.350
I could change that to workbook.

58
00:03:17.350 --> 00:03:18.960
It normally searches by rows,

59
00:03:18.960 --> 00:03:22.690
meaning that it's going taking this row,
searching all the columns.

60
00:03:22.690 --> 00:03:25.700
Then going to the next row,
going through each column, and

61
00:03:25.700 --> 00:03:27.210
then the next row, and so on.

62
00:03:27.210 --> 00:03:30.710
You might find it more efficient like
if you know they're all in one column,

63
00:03:30.710 --> 00:03:34.060
you could change this to by columns, and
it might make it a little more efficient.

64
00:03:34.060 --> 00:03:39.200
Now with 3,000 rows, that might seem like
a lot to us, to Excel, that's nothing.

65
00:03:39.200 --> 00:03:43.690
I mean, it goes up to 16 million
plus rows, almost 17 million rows.

66
00:03:43.690 --> 00:03:46.900
So, 3,000 rows is not a lot.

67
00:03:46.900 --> 00:03:51.010
But it might be more efficient if you've
got a super large data set to change that

68
00:03:51.010 --> 00:03:53.829
to search, By columns.

69
00:03:53.829 --> 00:03:55.920
Look in Formulas.

70
00:03:55.920 --> 00:03:58.540
What if the word I was looking for
was like sum.

71
00:03:58.540 --> 00:04:01.800
And I wanted to see if there were
any formulas in the spreadsheet

72
00:04:01.800 --> 00:04:03.250
that had the word sum in it, right?

73
00:04:03.250 --> 00:04:05.960
I could search Formulas,
or I could search Values.

74
00:04:05.960 --> 00:04:09.025
So, if the word sum was in the formula,
it wouldn't find that.

75
00:04:09.025 --> 00:04:11.040
Cuz now it's only looking at
the output of the format,

76
00:04:11.040 --> 00:04:14.140
the actual value that's in the cell,
or comments.

77
00:04:14.140 --> 00:04:17.010
If people have created comments,
if you're collaborating.

78
00:04:17.010 --> 00:04:19.840
You can search for a particular comment or
I can search for Ronnie's name,

79
00:04:19.840 --> 00:04:22.910
maybe every time we make a comment
it puts our name in there.

80
00:04:22.910 --> 00:04:25.660
I can search for comments done by Ronnie.

81
00:04:25.660 --> 00:04:28.770
So a few different options
to tweak your search there.

82
00:04:28.770 --> 00:04:32.880
As well as Match case and
Match entire contents.

83
00:04:32.880 --> 00:04:35.510
Now I typed in tricor with a lower case t.

84
00:04:35.510 --> 00:04:39.720
It doesn't have Match case, so
it found the ones even with a capital T.

85
00:04:39.720 --> 00:04:41.850
If I choose Match case and

86
00:04:41.850 --> 00:04:47.130
then Find All, it says we couldn't
find what you were looking for, right?

87
00:04:47.130 --> 00:04:49.780
Well I know tricor's out there,
we just saw it.

88
00:04:49.780 --> 00:04:52.260
But it's not spelled with a lowercase t.

89
00:04:52.260 --> 00:04:54.290
So maybe you're looking for
all the miss-types.

90
00:04:54.290 --> 00:04:57.600
Where somebody put in mister but
used a lower case m or

91
00:04:57.600 --> 00:04:59.800
the word Florida with a lowercase f.

92
00:04:59.800 --> 00:05:03.910
I can do a search for
Florida with a lowercase f, match case and

93
00:05:03.910 --> 00:05:07.810
it would ignore all the ones that have the
proper capital F for the word Florida, but

94
00:05:07.810 --> 00:05:09.810
it would find all the ones that didn't.

95
00:05:09.810 --> 00:05:12.200
So use these to your advantage.

96
00:05:12.200 --> 00:05:17.430
Entire contents,
if I search for tricor, what if

97
00:05:17.430 --> 00:05:23.280
there's one that says trichlorophoroploro
something, right, some big crazy name.

98
00:05:23.280 --> 00:05:27.254
Well, match entire contents, it wouldn't
take, it wouldn't find that one.

99
00:05:27.254 --> 00:05:30.260
Right, because Tricor is only
part of the cell contents.

100
00:05:30.260 --> 00:05:34.370
So you just have to decide is it looking
for just part, as long as it's in

101
00:05:34.370 --> 00:05:38.230
the cell, somewhere in there, or does it
have to match everything in that cell?

102
00:05:38.230 --> 00:05:41.280
So a few different option you can
use with the Find and Replace.

103
00:05:41.280 --> 00:05:43.100
Again just trying to make it easier for

104
00:05:43.100 --> 00:05:48.070
us to jump around within this document
when we've got large datasets.

105
00:05:48.070 --> 00:05:49.170
Another cool thing,

106
00:05:49.170 --> 00:05:52.090
another way we can jump around, and
let me scroll back up to the top here.

107
00:05:53.900 --> 00:05:56.620
Let me just grab this guy and
drag it up that'll be a little quicker.

108
00:05:57.980 --> 00:06:01.980
Is this box right over here,
is known as the Name Box.

109
00:06:01.980 --> 00:06:06.194
If I scroll into this and take a closer
look see when I hover over it,

110
00:06:06.194 --> 00:06:07.488
this says Name Box.

111
00:06:07.488 --> 00:06:10.321
And you can see in there it says C2799.

112
00:06:10.321 --> 00:06:14.260
Well, that's actually the cell
that I currently have selected.

113
00:06:14.260 --> 00:06:16.530
If I click on one of these other cells,

114
00:06:16.530 --> 00:06:21.900
you'll see it changes to B4
cuz I have cell B4 selected.

115
00:06:21.900 --> 00:06:24.820
So the first thing the Name Box says
is tell you where your active cell

116
00:06:24.820 --> 00:06:26.260
currently resides.

117
00:06:26.260 --> 00:06:29.440
You can also use this to
jump to a particular cell.

118
00:06:29.440 --> 00:06:30.870
What if I wanted to go to C2000,

119
00:06:30.870 --> 00:06:32.970
I want to go all the way down
to the row 2000 column C.

120
00:06:32.970 --> 00:06:36.450
I just type it in there hit Enter and
there you go.

121
00:06:36.450 --> 00:06:41.210
All right, I'm now at, if I can find
it there, there's my active cell,

122
00:06:41.210 --> 00:06:43.270
row 2000 column C.

123
00:06:43.270 --> 00:06:48.340
Now that Name Box does some other
cool things that we're gonna save for

124
00:06:48.340 --> 00:06:52.230
a later episode, if you hang on
the edge of your seat for that one.

125
00:06:52.230 --> 00:06:53.570
But in its basic sense,

126
00:06:53.570 --> 00:06:57.400
the Name Box tells you the name of
the cell that you currently have selected.

127
00:06:57.400 --> 00:07:00.210
And in Excel,
everything is about column, row, right?

128
00:07:00.210 --> 00:07:03.088
Our spreadsheets are organized
in columns of information.

129
00:07:03.088 --> 00:07:09.070
Those are designated with letters,
A, B, C, D, all the way out to Z.

130
00:07:09.070 --> 00:07:16.040
And if we get out to Z, it starts over AA,
AB, AC, it goes all the way out to AZ.

131
00:07:16.040 --> 00:07:19.367
And then the next column is gonna be BA,
BB, BC.

132
00:07:19.367 --> 00:07:22.094
And it just keeps incrementing and

133
00:07:22.094 --> 00:07:26.240
when it gets to ZZ it goes to AAA,
AAB, AAC, right?

134
00:07:26.240 --> 00:07:27.577
It just keeps going.

135
00:07:27.577 --> 00:07:32.390
[COUGH] There are 65,000 columns,
I believe, you can have in Excel 2016.

136
00:07:32.390 --> 00:07:36.975
>> It normally ends at UFD,
however many that is, that's all I know.

137
00:07:36.975 --> 00:07:38.650
[LAUGH]
>> It's way out there, right?

138
00:07:38.650 --> 00:07:40.100
>> Yeah.
>> Hopefully you're not working with data

139
00:07:40.100 --> 00:07:41.910
sets quite that large.

140
00:07:41.910 --> 00:07:43.350
Rows, yes, maybe not columns.

141
00:07:43.350 --> 00:07:46.140
And a lot of times if I see
a spreadsheet like that I'm like,

142
00:07:46.140 --> 00:07:47.960
this should probably be broken up
into more than one spreadsheet.

143
00:07:47.960 --> 00:07:49.640
But that's another story.

144
00:07:49.640 --> 00:07:52.120
All right, so
we've got our searching for data.

145
00:07:52.120 --> 00:07:54.800
We can use that find option.

146
00:07:54.800 --> 00:07:56.905
Let's see if my keyboard
shortcut is going to work.

147
00:07:56.905 --> 00:07:59.650
Ctrl+F is the keyboard shortcut for that.

148
00:07:59.650 --> 00:08:03.150
You can see it brings up that
Find dialog box as well.

149
00:08:03.150 --> 00:08:06.130
We also saw the Name Box,
what else we got?

150
00:08:06.130 --> 00:08:10.790
Ooh, hyperlinks, another great
way to navigate around documents.

151
00:08:10.790 --> 00:08:13.280
Let's look at some of the cool
things I can do with hyperlinks.

152
00:08:13.280 --> 00:08:16.990
I'm gonna go ahead and
close that particular workbook and

153
00:08:16.990 --> 00:08:18.350
I'm gonna open up one.

154
00:08:18.350 --> 00:08:24.033
Let's see which one I wanna use,
I wanna use this customers.

155
00:08:24.033 --> 00:08:26.700
Yeah that'd be a good way to do that,
yeah let's use customers.

156
00:08:26.700 --> 00:08:30.550
All right, so
let me go open up another spreadsheet.

157
00:08:33.470 --> 00:08:38.090
We'll find customers, all right.

158
00:08:38.090 --> 00:08:40.640
And here I've got a list of just
my customers that we deal with.

159
00:08:40.640 --> 00:08:46.060
So we distribute pharmaceuticals to
these different hospitals in the area.

160
00:08:46.060 --> 00:08:48.840
One thing I could do is
I can insert hyperlinks.

161
00:08:48.840 --> 00:08:49.990
Now think well why?

162
00:08:49.990 --> 00:08:52.970
What's the point of putting
a hyperlink in a spreadsheet?

163
00:08:52.970 --> 00:08:54.600
There's actually some pretty
cool things you can do.

164
00:08:54.600 --> 00:08:56.780
I'm gonna go to my Insert ribbon.

165
00:08:57.820 --> 00:09:00.410
And then, over here I've got Hyperlink.

166
00:09:00.410 --> 00:09:01.940
I'm gonna go ahead and click on that.

167
00:09:01.940 --> 00:09:05.900
In fact, let's do this,
if I have a blank cell selected and

168
00:09:05.900 --> 00:09:09.900
I do Hyperlink, It starts me
out with this blank dialog box.

169
00:09:09.900 --> 00:09:12.360
With the Insert Hyperlink there's
a few things that you need to do.

170
00:09:12.360 --> 00:09:16.230
You need to put Text to Display,
what's it actually gonna put in the cell.

171
00:09:16.230 --> 00:09:19.600
In other words,
what's gonna be displayed in that cell.

172
00:09:19.600 --> 00:09:23.740
Down at the bottom, the actual address.

173
00:09:23.740 --> 00:09:25.350
Where if I click on this hyperlink,

174
00:09:25.350 --> 00:09:28.650
we know a hyperlink js a link
to another place, right?

175
00:09:28.650 --> 00:09:31.250
Typically we see this in webpages.

176
00:09:31.250 --> 00:09:32.455
So where is it going to take me?

177
00:09:32.455 --> 00:09:34.780
What is the address that
it's going to take me?

178
00:09:34.780 --> 00:09:39.050
And then over in the side, in my Places
bar, I have Link to: Existing File or

179
00:09:39.050 --> 00:09:45.280
Webpage, Place in this Document,
Create New Document or Email Address.

180
00:09:45.280 --> 00:09:49.540
We'll just start at the beginning here,
Existing File or Web Page.

181
00:09:49.540 --> 00:09:52.870
And what I'm gonna do Is I'm
actually going to browse.

182
00:09:52.870 --> 00:09:57.720
You can see I've got Current Folder,
Browse Pages, Recent Files.

183
00:09:57.720 --> 00:10:00.460
Well what Im gonna do is I'm
gonna zoom back out for a second.

184
00:10:00.460 --> 00:10:03.240
Open up my browser and

185
00:10:03.240 --> 00:10:09.040
let's go to Florida hospital Tampa.

186
00:10:11.860 --> 00:10:14.880
Not the shooting that occurred there,
evidently.

187
00:10:14.880 --> 00:10:19.530
And let's see if I can find their
actual website, here we go.

188
00:10:19.530 --> 00:10:21.270
So here's their webpage.

189
00:10:21.270 --> 00:10:25.830
So I want to select that URL,
and I'm gonna just copy it.

190
00:10:25.830 --> 00:10:27.720
Then I'm gonna jump back over to Excel.

191
00:10:27.720 --> 00:10:30.610
And you'll see something interesting
happen over here in Excel.

192
00:10:30.610 --> 00:10:33.980
You saw me browsing with
this hyperlink thing open.

193
00:10:33.980 --> 00:10:34.790
And you see what it did.

194
00:10:34.790 --> 00:10:36.890
It filled in some text.

195
00:10:36.890 --> 00:10:39.500
That's pulled from their webpage.

196
00:10:39.500 --> 00:10:43.070
The title of the page and
the actual address.

197
00:10:43.070 --> 00:10:44.710
Now, if it hadn't filled that in for me,

198
00:10:44.710 --> 00:10:46.870
I could obviously type
whatever I wanted there.

199
00:10:46.870 --> 00:10:48.920
I could paste in that URL.

200
00:10:48.920 --> 00:10:52.710
If I had browsed to that page in the past,
I could do browse pages and

201
00:10:52.710 --> 00:10:55.600
it actually shows me my
history from my browser.

202
00:10:56.720 --> 00:10:58.270
I'll go ahead and click OK.

203
00:10:58.270 --> 00:11:00.856
Let's change this actually,
let's make that a little bit shorter.

204
00:11:03.653 --> 00:11:04.770
Now we'll click OK.

205
00:11:06.110 --> 00:11:09.184
We'll zoom back out and
there's my hyperlink.

206
00:11:09.184 --> 00:11:14.629
And let's close the browser, just so
I can prove that it's actually working.

207
00:11:14.629 --> 00:11:16.081
All right, I'll go ahead and click.

208
00:11:16.081 --> 00:11:18.940
You notice when I hover over it,
all right?

209
00:11:18.940 --> 00:11:22.060
I get that little hand icon which is,
we're use to that.

210
00:11:22.060 --> 00:11:26.700
I click on it,
then sure enough there's that web page.

211
00:11:26.700 --> 00:11:30.540
So may be you've gotta workbook or you've
got a list of all your customers and

212
00:11:30.540 --> 00:11:35.370
you wanna be able to quickly jump out
to a webpage that the customer has

213
00:11:35.370 --> 00:11:38.510
to get more information about
the customer or something like that.

214
00:11:38.510 --> 00:11:40.600
Any number of reasons you
might want to jump out.

00:11:40.600 --> 00:11:44.630
Like I've had a spreadsheet
that had products listed in it.

And then we had a web server that hosted

00:12:08.170 --> 00:12:10.380

00:12:10.380 --> 00:12:13.490

00:12:13.490 --> 00:12:15.850
So, different reasons you

00:12:15.850 --> 00:12:20.180
Another cool thing is, if I select this

230
00:12:22.180 --> 00:12:25.950
It takes the text that's in the cell and

231
00:12:25.950 --> 00:12:30.800
So now I could just paste that link in

00:12:34.120 --> 00:12:37.480

00:12:37.480 --> 00:12:41.640
One use of hyperlinks is to jump
to a webpage, which is what we

is going to somewhere out on the Internet.

236
00:12:45.080 --> 00:12:48.640
But that's not the only

237
00:12:48.640 --> 00:12:52.480
Let me open up another workbook, and

00:12:52.480 --> 00:12:56.930
let's do, we'll take a look at orders,

00:12:56.930 --> 00:13:01.580
Now, maybe here I wanna be able
to look at this order sheet,

240
00:13:02.590 --> 00:13:07.016
and I see that Memorial Hospital

241
00:13:07.016 --> 00:13:09.591
And I wanna be,
my sales rep needs to be able to say, ooh,

00:13:09.591 --> 00:13:12.079
I need to contact them and
see if they need more of that.

maybe there's a warning that came

245
00:13:17.820 --> 00:13:21.280
Well I've got their contact

00:13:21.280 --> 00:13:22.868
So now they have to go and

00:13:22.868 --> 00:13:25.030
No they don't, right?

248
00:13:25.030 --> 00:13:28.820
Let's take a look,
what we can do is insert hyperlink, so

00:13:28.820 --> 00:13:32.410
I'll go back to my insert and hyperlink.

00:13:32.410 --> 00:13:37.300
And this time I'm gonna say, it's
the same option existing file or webpage.

251
00:13:37.300 --> 00:13:42.880
And I'm gonna grab, instead of a URL for a
webpage, Customers.xlsx, that spreadsheet.

252
00:13:42.880 --> 00:13:46.690
I'll click OK, and
let me close that workbook so

00:13:46.690 --> 00:13:48.530
I can prove to you that it works.

254
00:13:49.860 --> 00:13:51.950
And yeah, let's save it, it is pretty.

255
00:13:51.950 --> 00:13:54.620
So now they can be looking at the orders,
they can say,

00:13:54.620 --> 00:13:57.650
I need to contact these guys,
I can click on Memorial Hospital.

00:13:57.650 --> 00:14:00.190
And actually opens up my

And then I can click on

I didn't do Memorial Hospital.

But I can maybe jump to their webpage, or

at least I can get their

00:14:08.430 --> 00:14:10.190
And I can give them a call, all right.

So really cool I think, being able to

265
00:14:18.690 --> 00:14:22.530
Another one we can do is

00:14:22.530 --> 00:14:25.040
And you might think, what the heck?

Well, let's open up that big

Actually, I already got it opened don't I?

Oops, so let's go over here to orders.

00:14:33.648 --> 00:14:37.840
Remember, this is that one that has,

00:14:37.840 --> 00:14:41.820
Let's say I've taken my time and

Now I gotta scroll back up.

273
00:14:43.970 --> 00:14:45.060
Yeah, not really.

I can come over here and

00:14:50.510 --> 00:14:53.740

So, let's do a hyperlink and

00:14:58.321 --> 00:15:02.348
I know cell A1 is the top,

I've already got my text to display

I click okay and now it looks like

This is extremely handy, you might

00:15:20.440 --> 00:15:22.850
Let's do that Ronnie,
let's go back down here.

And say down here there was a, we'll

And when I open this up a lot of

I don't care how many rows there are,

the details,

Well, all I have to do is

00:15:43.497 --> 00:15:48.660
So I can go, oops, you know what,

00:15:48.660 --> 00:15:51.019
[LAUGH] let's jump back to the top.

00:15:52.020 --> 00:15:55.330
All right, and go over here, and

00:15:56.770 --> 00:16:01.015
And then I'll turn that into a hyperlink,
and uh-oh, 3002.

293
00:16:01.015 --> 00:16:03.050
>> I think that's what you said.

294
00:16:03.050 --> 00:16:08.320
>> Something like that, we'll click OK,

00:16:08.320 --> 00:16:11.240
boom, it takes me right

297

I can jump anywhere within this worksheet

this workbook to another separate
workbook to a URL to a webpage.

299
00:16:21.980 --> 00:16:24.930
I can even create a blank workbook.

300
00:16:24.930 --> 00:16:27.930
Maybe you've got that template for

301
00:16:27.930 --> 00:16:30.930
And when they're sitting there

00:16:30.930 --> 00:16:33.760
in the spreadsheet that
says create new workbook.

303
00:16:33.760 --> 00:16:37.100
Why, I don't know you could
File > New just as easy right?

304
00:16:37.100 --> 00:16:38.910
But you get the idea.

305
00:16:38.910 --> 00:16:43.730
Email is another one, I don't have email

but there was also an email option

Email address, so I can basically create I
can put a cell down there that said, hey,

if you need more information contact me.

Turn it into a link.

When they click on it it opens up their

Or for customer support.

00:17:04.030 --> 00:17:06.220
So you can see the kind of things

314
00:17:06.220 --> 00:17:08.250

315

Love, love, love,

316
00:17:11.300 --> 00:17:16.330
Ronnie, a few different ways that we can

with using this, the key here is more

You may not use all of them,

You can spend 20,

But it doesn't make you more

So knowing how to actually get this stuff

especially when you're working

324

Remember, what ends up

>> [LAUGH]
>> So

00:17:46.581 --> 00:17:50.830
using these tools to your advantage

00:17:50.830 --> 00:17:53.570
It will also give you more

330
00:17:53.570 --> 00:17:57.710
And so Mike, we emphasize the idea of

00:17:57.710 --> 00:18:00.280
that's about as important as we

You want the technology to help you,

00:18:09.480 --> 00:18:12.990
>> All right, so that's the way that we

tools that we can use to help us navigate

Make sure you do take the time to practice

it is really gonna help you out as

00:18:24.670 --> 00:18:27.080
more in your skills in Excel as well.

00:18:27.080 --> 00:18:30.080
>> I was gonna say we'll make sure we put

All right, so signing off for ITProTV,

346
00:18:39.660 --> 00:18:41.739

347
00:18:41.739 --> 00:18:44.629

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike help us with making our worksheets presentable.  They remind us that seeing the data is not enough.  Data must be presented in a manner that will help to make the point with our data the way we need, according to the guys.  Mike demonstrates how to make the worksheets look better through adjusting the page setup, adjusting the column or row height to make it more effective and adding in additional rows when data is already present.  These techniques are key to formatting data for presentation as well productivity.
episodes.title: Format Worksheets
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

And here to help us to learn how to

00:00:44.150 --> 00:00:45.460
Mike, how's it going?

Excited to be here,

16

>> [LAUGH] So he's exactly right.

That's really what we're
going to highlight here and

>> Yeah.
>> Right.

32

>> Why do we care?

I'm not gonna leave you out,

So you might find and

To the point where as you can see on this

has about six I think down there seven so

00:02:23.160 --> 00:02:28.680

Let me just add a few sheets in here.

I'm just clicking that plus sign over and

So if you're working with workbooks like

56

That's all we're talking about here.

00:03:48.480 --> 00:03:52.030

73
00:03:52.030 --> 00:03:55.770
You know, maybe you wanna make it

74
00:03:55.770 --> 00:04:00.000
maybe you like colorful things,
or you like to do rainbows.

75
00:04:00.000 --> 00:04:03.420
Or you want to make sure that summary

76
00:04:03.420 --> 00:04:05.640
Maybe that's the only one you color.

77
00:04:05.640 --> 00:04:06.770
Whatever your need is,

81

83
00:04:23.610 --> 00:04:27.330
>> And Mike I can see where this would be
really useful especially if I'm tracking

00:04:27.330 --> 00:04:31.730

00:06:10.610 --> 00:06:15.090

309
00:16:19.230 --> 00:16:24.090
I might have an entry down here further
that's even wider than that, and

310
00:16:24.090 --> 00:16:26.460
it's still chopped off,
I just don't see it.

311
00:16:26.460 --> 00:16:28.760
Excel gives me another way to do this.

312
00:16:28.760 --> 00:16:32.660
You can actually just double click, so
what I'm doing is I'm on that border

313
00:16:32.660 --> 00:16:35.980
again, but I'm not going to hold my mouse
down, I'm just going to double click.

314
00:16:37.590 --> 00:16:38.360
And I say I'm going to.

315
00:16:38.360 --> 00:16:39.210
There we go.
>> [LAUGH]

316
00:16:39.210 --> 00:16:40.520
>> And it's going to stretch that column

317
00:16:40.520 --> 00:16:45.290
out to the widest item of that column,
so what we call auto fit the column.

318
00:16:45.290 --> 00:16:48.260
There's an option for
that on your menu as well, but it's so

319
00:16:48.260 --> 00:16:51.950
easy to just go there and
double click and let it move things out.

320
00:16:51.950 --> 00:16:55.630
Look out big that one got and you're
thinking why the heck did it get that big?

321
00:16:55.630 --> 00:16:57.380
What's all that white space for?

322
00:16:57.380 --> 00:17:02.020
Well that's because somewhere in
this sheet there is a longer name.

323
00:17:02.020 --> 00:17:04.080
And it needed that room, right?

324
00:17:04.080 --> 00:17:06.770
So when you double click, it doesn't
look at just what you're viewing,

325
00:17:06.770 --> 00:17:08.290
it looks at that entire column.

326
00:17:08.290 --> 00:17:12.330
It says I'm gonna make this column
wide enough to fit any item

327
00:17:12.330 --> 00:17:14.430
in this particular column, all right?

328
00:17:14.430 --> 00:17:18.360
Now it's not gonna resize,
like if I made this one, oops.

329
00:17:18.360 --> 00:17:21.150
Like if I went and
started adding data to this,

330
00:17:21.150 --> 00:17:24.750
it's not going to automatically
expand the column.

331
00:17:24.750 --> 00:17:26.370
Now that one's chopped off, right.

332
00:17:26.370 --> 00:17:28.520
But I could just double-click again and

333
00:17:28.520 --> 00:17:31.100
it'll move out to however
wide it needs to be.

334
00:17:31.100 --> 00:17:32.790
So that's that auto fit option.

335
00:17:32.790 --> 00:17:35.930
You just double-click on the border,
all right?

336
00:17:35.930 --> 00:17:38.420
Let's fix a couple of other places here.

337
00:17:38.420 --> 00:17:41.310
I'm gonna go ahead and
just double-click, move that over, so

338
00:17:41.310 --> 00:17:42.480
now I can see everything there.

339
00:17:42.480 --> 00:17:43.749
We'll get rid of that.

340
00:17:44.930 --> 00:17:45.790
All right.

341
00:17:45.790 --> 00:17:47.140
Now that's not too bad.

342
00:17:47.140 --> 00:17:47.770
Pretty easy to do.

343
00:17:47.770 --> 00:17:49.890
And it's the same thing with rows.

344
00:17:49.890 --> 00:17:53.570
If I want to change a row height
I can right-click on that row,

345
00:17:53.570 --> 00:17:58.040
choose row height, and
I can set the numeric value 15 by default.

346
00:17:58.040 --> 00:18:02.860
I can go to the border and
I can drag and make those guys bigger or

347
00:18:02.860 --> 00:18:06.180
I can double-click,
it'll do the same thing.

348
00:18:06.180 --> 00:18:08.770
>> That really does tend
to help when you end up

349
00:18:08.770 --> 00:18:11.660
changing font sizes and
all of a sudden you realize that it's not

350
00:18:11.660 --> 00:18:13.510
actually showing you
everything that you need to.

351
00:18:13.510 --> 00:18:17.145
Being able to adjust the row height as
well as the column height is really gonna

352
00:18:17.145 --> 00:18:21.480
be able to allow you to put that worksheet
and format it the best way that you can.

353
00:18:21.480 --> 00:18:23.690
That way, whenever you're actually
presenting your data to someone,

354
00:18:23.690 --> 00:18:27.490
they don't look at it and go, wow,
why is all this stuff jammed up together?

355
00:18:27.490 --> 00:18:31.410
Why can't I see what the full name
that's supposed to be listing here is?

356
00:18:31.410 --> 00:18:32.570
Just doing a simple little thing,

357
00:18:32.570 --> 00:18:35.770
like double clicking in between
the column headers or the row headers,

358
00:18:35.770 --> 00:18:39.810
being able to adjust them that quickly
is a tremendous amount of help.

359
00:18:39.810 --> 00:18:42.200
When you do need to do
something like printing or

360
00:18:42.200 --> 00:18:45.090
doing anything like that in
terms of presentation, too.

361
00:18:45.090 --> 00:18:46.610
>> Yeah, absolutely.

362
00:18:46.610 --> 00:18:48.040
And in fact,
I can show you what Ronnie means.

363
00:18:48.040 --> 00:18:52.940
I'm gonna go over here and just make
this header row a little bit bigger.

364
00:18:52.940 --> 00:18:56.520
And you see actually Excel's doing
a pretty good job of resizing the row.

365
00:18:56.520 --> 00:19:01.130
Notice it resized the row height, but
it didn't fix my column width there.

366
00:19:01.130 --> 00:19:04.090
And sometimes you'll find if you
just type big text in there,

367
00:19:04.090 --> 00:19:05.910
that it doesn't adjust that either.

368
00:19:05.910 --> 00:19:10.260
So as I said, just double-click between
those columns, and you're good to go.

369
00:19:10.260 --> 00:19:13.430
All right, so I undid that boldness
there on our column row, but

370
00:19:13.430 --> 00:19:16.710
I wanna show you I've got other
tabs that need to be fixed, right?

371
00:19:16.710 --> 00:19:18.640
So I could do what we did with January.

372
00:19:18.640 --> 00:19:22.680
I could go to February,
I could double-click on the borders, and

373
00:19:22.680 --> 00:19:24.040
go to each one.

374
00:19:24.040 --> 00:19:26.180
And eventually I'd get it done, right?

375
00:19:26.180 --> 00:19:27.490
That's a lot of work.

376
00:19:27.490 --> 00:19:28.670
Here's another trick.

377
00:19:28.670 --> 00:19:32.230
What if I grab all the columns right?

378
00:19:32.230 --> 00:19:35.060
Now I just go to, it doesn't matter
which column between I double click,

379
00:19:35.060 --> 00:19:37.530
I'm just gonna click on
one of the borders and

380
00:19:37.530 --> 00:19:40.350
notice how it resized all
the columns at the same time.

381
00:19:40.350 --> 00:19:41.750
And not all to the same size.

382
00:19:41.750 --> 00:19:45.670
It looked at each column and said,
how wide do I need to make this?

383
00:19:45.670 --> 00:19:47.610
And I'll take it a step further right.

384
00:19:47.610 --> 00:19:49.760
I still have four sheets to do.

385
00:19:49.760 --> 00:19:52.760
Well Mike, you just showed us how we just
go to the sheet, select the columns,

386
00:19:52.760 --> 00:19:54.830
double click, move on to the next sheet.

387
00:19:54.830 --> 00:19:56.060
What if I do this?

388
00:19:56.060 --> 00:19:58.240
What if I select all the sheets?

389
00:19:58.240 --> 00:20:01.540
I'm just clicking on the first one,
holding down shift and

390
00:20:01.540 --> 00:20:02.570
clicking on the last one.

391
00:20:02.570 --> 00:20:05.000
Now I have four sheets selected.

392
00:20:05.000 --> 00:20:08.170
I'm gonna select all the columns.

393
00:20:08.170 --> 00:20:11.510
I'm gonna double-click, and
now I'll click away to deselect.

394
00:20:11.510 --> 00:20:16.210
And you'll see that March is fixed,
April's fixed, May, and June.

395
00:20:16.210 --> 00:20:20.450
And it doesn't matter if the data
is not the same width, right?

396
00:20:20.450 --> 00:20:21.930
The same columns was important.

397
00:20:21.930 --> 00:20:23.829
It's only gonna do the first five columns.

398
00:20:23.829 --> 00:20:26.012
If one of those sheets would
have had seven columns,

399
00:20:26.012 --> 00:20:28.156
it would resize the first five and
not the last two.

400
00:20:28.156 --> 00:20:28.690
Right?

401
00:20:28.690 --> 00:20:29.880
Because I only selected five columns.

402
00:20:31.350 --> 00:20:34.840
You know what another trick I should show
you guys, we talked about inserting and

403
00:20:34.840 --> 00:20:36.580
deleting rows and columns.

404
00:20:36.580 --> 00:20:39.150
And I did a single row and
a single column.

405
00:20:39.150 --> 00:20:42.740
There are times when you know
I need more rows than that,

406
00:20:42.740 --> 00:20:46.460
you don't have to insert
one row at a time.

407
00:20:46.460 --> 00:20:50.190
When I selected one column and
then insert it.

408
00:20:50.190 --> 00:20:53.240
If I select four columns, and

409
00:20:53.240 --> 00:20:57.570
then right click Insert,
notice it inserts four columns.

410
00:20:57.570 --> 00:20:58.720
Same thing with rows.

411
00:20:58.720 --> 00:21:02.188
If I select multiple rows, and
then I right click at Insert,

412
00:21:02.188 --> 00:21:06.210
however many rows I have selected,
that's how many it's gonna Insert.

413
00:21:06.210 --> 00:21:10.380
So it's just some little time-saving
tricks for you there as you go through and

414
00:21:10.380 --> 00:21:11.720
do some of this formatting.

415
00:21:13.130 --> 00:21:15.750
All right, so we looked at change
in the work sheet tab, crawler,

416
00:21:15.750 --> 00:21:16.730
inserting and deleting rows.

417
00:21:16.730 --> 00:21:19.500
You know what, I almost skipped over
good old Page Setup, didn't I, Ronnie?

418
00:21:19.500 --> 00:21:21.470
>> Yeah.
>> They gotta take a look at that.

419
00:21:21.470 --> 00:21:25.680
Let's look at Page Setup,
this is on my Page Layout ribbon,

420
00:21:25.680 --> 00:21:29.340
and it really has to do with
printing more than anything.

421
00:21:29.340 --> 00:21:31.580
When you get ready to
print your worksheet,

422
00:21:31.580 --> 00:21:36.250
you're gonna need to adjust some of these,
depending on what you have.

423
00:21:36.250 --> 00:21:37.970
It's pretty straightforward.

424
00:21:37.970 --> 00:21:40.590
Orientation, I'll start with that
one just because it's the easiest.

425
00:21:40.590 --> 00:21:42.050
Landscape or portrait.

426
00:21:42.050 --> 00:21:42.550
Right?

427
00:21:42.550 --> 00:21:45.990
Portrait is where it's
taller than it is wide.

428
00:21:45.990 --> 00:21:48.330
Landscape it's going to
be wider than it is tall.

429
00:21:48.330 --> 00:21:52.260
If we're dealing with USNR
standard documents with 8.5x11.

430
00:21:52.260 --> 00:21:55.060
So eight and
a half wide by 11 high for portrait.

431
00:21:55.060 --> 00:22:00.390
Landscape 11 wide by eight and a half
high and I find that especially useful

432
00:22:00.390 --> 00:22:06.280
when I'm working in Excel, because a lot
of times my data is wider than it is tall.

433
00:22:06.280 --> 00:22:07.990
Or it might be tall.

434
00:22:07.990 --> 00:22:11.360
There might be 3,000 rows,
but because it has so

435
00:22:11.360 --> 00:22:15.970
many columns, when I try to print it,
it gets a little wonky, right?

436
00:22:15.970 --> 00:22:18.510
Because it can print
the first four columns, but

437
00:22:18.510 --> 00:22:21.760
the next two columns have
to go on a separate page.

438
00:22:21.760 --> 00:22:25.080
I know I'm going to get page
breaks because I have 3000 rows.

439
00:22:25.080 --> 00:22:30.550
But if I rotate that to a landscape, now I
can fit all my columns on the same page.

440
00:22:30.550 --> 00:22:32.480
I'm still gonna have page breaks every so

441
00:22:32.480 --> 00:22:36.880
many rows, but
at least all my columns fit on one page.

442
00:22:36.880 --> 00:22:38.920
So play around with your portrait and
landscape options.

443
00:22:38.920 --> 00:22:41.770
You also have sizing, depending on
what you're printing to, right?

444
00:22:41.770 --> 00:22:46.060
Letter, legal, you can see they
have a few pre-builts in here, and

445
00:22:46.060 --> 00:22:48.710
I say a few as you see if
you scroll through there.

446
00:22:48.710 --> 00:22:51.980
Quite a few, some cards,
some index card sizes.

447
00:22:51.980 --> 00:22:53.700
There's also margins.

448
00:22:53.700 --> 00:22:57.110
This could effect how much
data you can fit on that page.

449
00:22:57.110 --> 00:23:02.560
If I'm just one column short trying
to get it to fit on one page and

450
00:23:02.560 --> 00:23:04.382
I'm using normal margins.

451
00:23:04.382 --> 00:23:07.600
0.75 on either side, left and

452
00:23:07.600 --> 00:23:12.520
right, if I reduce those,
I could gain another half inch or an inch.

453
00:23:12.520 --> 00:23:16.730
I can now fit that column on that one
page and not have to go to a second page.

454
00:23:16.730 --> 00:23:21.450
So you've got some pre-built ones,
normal, wide, and narrow.

455
00:23:21.450 --> 00:23:25.500
And then of course you can always go
in and do your custom margins as well,

456
00:23:25.500 --> 00:23:29.070
where you manually specify the margins,
the top to bottom,

457
00:23:29.070 --> 00:23:33.530
left, right, as well as the header and
the footer margins there.

458
00:23:33.530 --> 00:23:36.920
>> Mike, I see this as being very
informed because like you, and

459
00:23:36.920 --> 00:23:40.480
probably like everybody else if we've ever
tried to print out an Excel worksheet.

460
00:23:40.480 --> 00:23:42.570
You always look at it and
go, hey that looks fine, and

461
00:23:42.570 --> 00:23:45.330
then you hit the Print, and all of
a sudden the first page comes out and

462
00:23:45.330 --> 00:23:50.070
then the second page comes out, and its
got that one, column there that's left.

463
00:23:50.070 --> 00:23:53.802
And so margins is probably one of the ways
that we can use to help us to adjust that.

464
00:23:53.802 --> 00:23:58.056
So it does actually pay for us to take
the time to learn how to manipulate those.

465
00:23:58.056 --> 00:23:58.567
>> Absolutely.

466
00:23:58.567 --> 00:23:59.839
Let's see if we can
make a difference here.

467
00:23:59.839 --> 00:24:03.590
I'll take a look at I'm gonna go File, and

468
00:24:03.590 --> 00:24:08.294
then my Print, and
we'll see a little preview here.

469
00:24:08.294 --> 00:24:10.850
You'll see I have seven pages, all right.

470
00:24:10.850 --> 00:24:11.875
It should let me.

471
00:24:11.875 --> 00:24:13.790
[LAUGH] I'll zoom in in a second.

472
00:24:13.790 --> 00:24:16.044
I'll go through some of
these different pages here.

473
00:24:16.044 --> 00:24:21.543
You'll see how the summary,
in this case, I think on the last page.

474
00:24:21.543 --> 00:24:23.990
I got this summary information.

475
00:24:23.990 --> 00:24:27.910
Well, that is actually right out here,
right?

476
00:24:27.910 --> 00:24:30.030
But you see this dotted,
I don't know if you can see that.

477
00:24:30.030 --> 00:24:31.080
Let me zoom in.

478
00:24:31.080 --> 00:24:32.790
See, I made this dotted line?

479
00:24:32.790 --> 00:24:33.860
That's my page break, or

480
00:24:33.860 --> 00:24:39.470
that's where the print is going to break
and put everything on another page.

481
00:24:39.470 --> 00:24:43.150
So if we zoom back out, and I'll try to,
let's just make up a few more columns.

482
00:24:43.150 --> 00:24:48.180
We'll say Test 1, Test 2,

483
00:24:48.180 --> 00:24:54.626
we'll insert a couple columns here.

484
00:24:54.626 --> 00:25:00.252
So now the problem is that
we'll make Test 3, all right?

485
00:25:00.252 --> 00:25:02.960
So now I've got columns
all the way out to Test 3.

486
00:25:02.960 --> 00:25:04.330
When I go File, Print.

487
00:25:06.140 --> 00:25:12.919
Well, in my Print preview,
if it will let me scroll into this.

488
00:25:12.919 --> 00:25:15.128
It's not letting me zoom in,
I'll just zoom in manual here.

489
00:25:15.128 --> 00:25:20.510
You can see my columns only
go over to Test 1, right?

490
00:25:20.510 --> 00:25:22.890
So where the heck is test two and
test three?

491
00:25:22.890 --> 00:25:25.370
So as we go through here and
look at my pages,

492
00:25:26.380 --> 00:25:31.210
we're gonna see that there's Test 2 and
Test 3 on that page there.

493
00:25:31.210 --> 00:25:33.870
So if we switch this over,

494
00:25:33.870 --> 00:25:39.150
if I go back out to my I can do it from
here as well as from my ribbon, right?

495
00:25:39.150 --> 00:25:41.150
Switch this to landscape,

496
00:25:41.150 --> 00:25:46.410
now all the sudden,
you should see that all my columns fit.

497
00:25:46.410 --> 00:25:48.170
That little summary area doesn't fit.

498
00:25:48.170 --> 00:25:49.510
It's way out there, right?

499
00:25:49.510 --> 00:25:52.420
But I just wanted to show you how
sometimes you are gonna break it there at

500
00:25:52.420 --> 00:25:54.640
that column, and
that's not gonna work for you.

501
00:25:54.640 --> 00:25:55.380
Flip it, right?

502
00:25:55.380 --> 00:25:58.240
Do a little landscape and
that might help you out just fine.

503
00:25:58.240 --> 00:26:02.215
Or I can start playing with those margins,
reducing the amount of white space on

504
00:26:02.215 --> 00:26:06.008
either side, to give you a little more
room to squeeze that column in there,

505
00:26:06.008 --> 00:26:09.419
cuz I think right now, what did I
leave the Margins set at, Narrow?

506
00:26:09.419 --> 00:26:10.790
>> I think about 0.75.

507
00:26:10.790 --> 00:26:13.420
>> So what if I go to Wide margins?

508
00:26:13.420 --> 00:26:18.548
Now if I go back to Print,
all of a sudden, Test 3 is gone, right?

509
00:26:18.548 --> 00:26:23.071
But simply adjusting the Margins
to Narrow or Normal,

510
00:26:23.071 --> 00:26:28.295
probably, in this case,
I can fit all the columns on one page.

511
00:26:28.295 --> 00:26:32.250
And not have to worry about taping
pages together, or anything like that.

512
00:26:32.250 --> 00:26:34.550
So, play around with those options there.

513
00:26:34.550 --> 00:26:39.042
Get that page to fit just right to get the
Margin the Orientation, the paper size.

514
00:26:39.042 --> 00:26:44.336
We're gonna talk later about print areas,
which are really cool too.

515
00:26:44.336 --> 00:26:48.178
Give you a heads up, what if I just wanted
to print this area, every time I come in,

516
00:26:48.178 --> 00:26:51.780
I don't wanna print all the details,
I just want the summary info.

517
00:26:51.780 --> 00:26:52.980
Print areas will let me do that.

518
00:26:52.980 --> 00:26:54.300
It's a pretty cool little trick.

519
00:26:54.300 --> 00:26:56.294
>> All right, so
remember in this episode, right?

520
00:26:56.294 --> 00:26:59.910
We took a look at basic formatting and
there's still a lot more to go, but

521
00:26:59.910 --> 00:27:02.639
we did see some different
features that we can actually

522
00:27:02.639 --> 00:27:06.044
take advantage of that will help us
to present the data that we want.

523
00:27:06.044 --> 00:27:08.560
But this is a great place for
us to end the episode.

524
00:27:08.560 --> 00:27:12.030
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

525
00:27:12.030 --> 00:27:12.900
>> And, I'm Mike Rodrick.

526
00:27:12.900 --> 00:27:13.961
>> And we'll see you next time.

527
00:27:13.961 --> 00:27:19.126
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike continue to show us more tools to make the data we use in Excel 2016 is presentable.  They demonstrate how to change theme within a worksheet and insert a watermark.  They discuss the effective use of headers and footers and how to set them for a workbook.  Lastly, they show the importance of setting data validation for inputting data.
episodes.title: Formatting Worksheets Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.148 --> 00:00:10.148
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.656 --> 00:00:15.432
Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.432 --> 00:00:17.360
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:17.360 --> 00:00:21.220
And today we're going to be taking,
we've got Microsoft Excel 2016.

5
00:00:21.220 --> 00:00:23.590
Now what we are doing
here is we're picking up

6
00:00:23.590 --> 00:00:27.440
from what we actually had last time
in terms of formatting worksheets.

7

all I'm doing is selecting the cells.

Wow.

We will copy this, paste that over here.

00:24:51.540 --> 00:24:55.557
We'll call this an error and
we'll go back over here and

00:24:55.557 --> 00:24:58.386
uncheck that and make sure we click OK.

487
00:25:00.256 --> 00:25:02.575
And it's not saving my changes for

00:25:02.575 --> 00:25:04.630
It's leaving that on there.

489
00:25:04.630 --> 00:25:06.650
That's all right,
well not too worried about it.

00:25:06.650 --> 00:25:09.710
Yeah it wants to throw

00:25:09.710 --> 00:25:13.140
I'll have to check, that's probably a

00:25:13.140 --> 00:25:14.510
but you see the different options.

493
00:25:14.510 --> 00:25:16.140
All right, now what can we do with this?

00:25:16.140 --> 00:25:19.380
Notice I still have numbers

Any data that's already been entered

496
00:25:23.690 --> 00:25:27.230
It's not gonna go back and

00:25:27.230 --> 00:25:32.307
But if I try to insert new information,
And

I do a number like 12, that's allowed, if

00:25:37.326 --> 00:25:42.150
value does not much the data validation

00:25:42.150 --> 00:25:43.420
And I get my custom message.

00:25:43.420 --> 00:25:45.270
And it says retry and I can go back and

00:25:45.270 --> 00:25:47.996

All right, and other things we can

00:26:01.590 --> 00:26:04.690
I didn't realize I needed to do that

I've already got a lot of data in there.

What do we do?

Well, I can go back to data validation and

00:26:13.740 --> 00:26:17.410
And now it'll let me find, and

00:26:23.210 --> 00:26:25.877
So, now I can go back and

And then once I change it so

it doesn't violate it anymore,

00:26:31.660 --> 00:26:32.995
So, it gives me this really quick and

that's extremely handy when

That you've gotta find the errors then,

00:26:43.920 --> 00:26:47.750
Then when I'm done fixing anything I

00:26:47.750 --> 00:26:49.940
If I wanted to leave some of those and

Other things I wanna point

How do I know if there's any

00:27:09.340 --> 00:27:13.850
All right, and it says hey,

All right, so I like that.

00:27:15.830 --> 00:27:18.280
The other think you might wanna

00:27:18.280 --> 00:27:20.360
Maybe if somebody puts

And then at the bottom of that

that will remove all of my

everything's gone back

I click OK.

And now if I do circle validation

because I've removed, well we thought I

00:27:55.108 --> 00:27:57.936
And it's kinda working and grinding there.

547
00:28:02.464 --> 00:28:05.200
Yeah I think my validation

548
00:28:05.200 --> 00:28:07.080

00:28:07.080 --> 00:28:08.260

>> Let's try that again.

550
00:28:08.260 --> 00:28:08.870
>> It's still there.

00:28:08.870 --> 00:28:12.975
>> You know what I think I'm doing

552
00:28:12.975 --> 00:28:14.840
>> [LAUGH]
>> I didn't have the entire column

553
00:28:14.840 --> 00:28:15.810
selected so

554
00:28:15.810 --> 00:28:19.670
whatever cell I selected it was clearing
off that it was still on the other cells.

555
00:28:19.670 --> 00:28:21.420
So let me do the entire column.

556
00:28:21.420 --> 00:28:26.120
Go back in my data validation rule and I'm

557
00:28:26.120 --> 00:28:28.505
cuz now the problem is some

558
00:28:28.505 --> 00:28:30.150
>> [LAUGH]

559
00:28:30.150 --> 00:28:32.300
So it's like hey do you

But the same concept would apply you

00:28:36.845 --> 00:28:40.900
OK and that will remove the data

00:28:40.900 --> 00:28:41.600
All right, so

just, actually a good learning point

So by the way,
we get rid of that data validation.

566

>> All right, Mike.

567
00:28:51.490 --> 00:28:52.940
In terms of formatting,

we've actually covered a lot of different

We took a look at headers and footers.

>> So remember that a lot of times you may

00:29:12.460 --> 00:29:15.200

But it really is.

At least learning the basics here will

00:29:19.720 --> 00:29:23.720
especially when you do need to present it
to colleagues or even to superiors here.

579

Putting it in the right format is really a

to learn how to do this.

581

>> And it's really gonna help you to

582
00:29:33.270 --> 00:29:37.560
Mike, any final words for somebody
just really learning how to do this?

583
00:29:37.560 --> 00:29:40.350
>> Try not to get thrown by those
darn data validation things, right?

584
00:29:40.350 --> 00:29:42.495
>> [LAUGH]
>> Make sure you select the entire column

585
00:29:42.495 --> 00:29:43.970
if that's what you want to do.

586
00:29:43.970 --> 00:29:46.120
No, just get in there and

587

Make it look good,
as I said you eat with your eyes.

588
00:29:48.670 --> 00:29:50.970
Same thing with my data,
you want it to look professional.

589
00:29:50.970 --> 00:29:52.010
You want to impress.

590
00:29:52.010 --> 00:29:55.280
Not that you're trying to impress people

591

And Excel makes it extremely easy to

Heck you can go to galleries and

You can go then boss this took me forever.

And really it was just a click, click and

00:30:10.820 --> 00:30:12.590
Right, so take advantage.

597
00:30:12.590 --> 00:30:14.320
All right, well that's a great place for

00:30:14.320 --> 00:30:16.730
us to go ahead and
wrap up this episode then.

00:30:16.730 --> 00:30:19.350
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

600
00:30:19.350 --> 00:30:20.890
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

601
00:30:20.890 --> 00:30:22.173

602
00:30:22.173 --> 00:30:29.990
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take some time to help us break out of using Excel 2016 default settings.  They talk about show us the benefits of hiding column, roles and even worksheets.  Also reminding us that this is not a security feature but can help when needing to only display or print certain columns of a worksheet without displaying everything.  When working with large worksheets, using split view and freeze panes can help keep track of data easier, according to Mike and Ronnie.  They also show where to effect the workbook properties to make it easier to find the workbook without having to examine the contents
episodes.title: Customizing Views
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.178 --> 00:00:10.178
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.547 --> 00:00:15.660
Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.660 --> 00:00:18.240
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today,

4
00:00:18.240 --> 00:00:22.130
we're going to be taking a look
at Microsoft Excel 2016.

5

Now, we're dealing with it from usually
a standpoint of a default install.

6
00:00:27.080 --> 00:00:29.250
But a lot of times,
what ends up happening of course,

7
00:00:29.250 --> 00:00:32.860
is that you want to see more than
what's actually presented default.

8
00:00:32.860 --> 00:00:34.330
And we're actually talking about now,

9

customizing the way that we can
also deal with Excel as well.

10
00:00:38.130 --> 00:00:40.830
And here to help us is gonna be,
well Mr. Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:40.830 --> 00:00:43.680
Mike why in the world do we want
to customize what we're actually

taking a look at and
not leave it at it's default?

13
00:00:45.230 --> 00:00:47.062

>> Right?

No, there are some times when you want to

22

When we open up a workbook, and
I've got one opened up here on my screen,

23
00:01:07.840 --> 00:01:09.760
I've got several tabs across there.

24
00:01:09.760 --> 00:01:12.100
And if I send Ronnie this workbook, or

every time I open this workbook,

I've got a tab for each one of my months

36

All I'm gonna do is right click on

39
00:01:57.260 --> 00:01:59.650
I know that was crazy complex,

I can take the rest of these sheets,
right click hide, and

44
00:02:10.560 --> 00:02:13.770
So when I go to send this or when
somebody opens this workbook up, in fact,

45
00:02:13.770 --> 00:02:20.910
here let's save it and close it, and
oops we'll close that one as well for now.

46
00:02:20.910 --> 00:02:22.439
And I'm gonna open that one back up.

47
00:02:24.530 --> 00:02:27.170
And ta da, only one tab shows.

48
00:02:27.170 --> 00:02:28.870
Now, they're not gone.

49
00:02:28.870 --> 00:02:29.710
They're just hidden.

50
00:02:29.710 --> 00:02:30.480

51

In fact, these formulas are pulling

So that's where that information is

54

So, obviously they're still there.

55
00:02:43.060 --> 00:02:44.280
They're just not visible.

56

58
00:02:48.440 --> 00:02:50.580
Notice it's got those ellipsis dots.

59
00:02:50.580 --> 00:02:53.380
That means I'm expecting

60
00:02:53.380 --> 00:02:58.500
And sure enough I did, and I can

61
00:02:58.500 --> 00:03:00.350

62
00:03:00.350 --> 00:03:02.070

00:03:02.070 --> 00:03:03.630

00:03:06.750 --> 00:03:09.950

66
00:03:11.360 --> 00:03:14.880
It's just not letting me select

67
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:18.829
So we'll go ahead and I'll quickly go

68
00:03:20.120 --> 00:03:23.470
>> Mike, the ability to hide these
worksheets is really effective,

69
00:03:23.470 --> 00:03:26.220
especially when you don't
want people messing around

70
00:03:26.220 --> 00:03:28.430
with the other data
that might be in there.

71
00:03:28.430 --> 00:03:32.150
It's all right to show them what you wanna
show them, but there are times when you do

72

00:03:36.770 --> 00:03:38.990
Somebody can accidentally

75

76
00:03:41.990 --> 00:03:45.740
By simply hiding it, we're not really

locking it down, but we are making

78
00:03:49.880 --> 00:03:52.810
And that way hopefully they
won't be too curious, and

79

they won't have to
actually figure that out.

80
00:03:54.410 --> 00:03:56.300
But I know I've seen this before too,
Mike.

Where somebody did send me a workbook, and

85
00:04:06.250 --> 00:04:08.280
So, if I didn't know how to get to it,

I've created several workbooks

00:27:50.040 --> 00:27:53.780
just do this Paste Special and
Paste Values.

542
00:27:53.780 --> 00:27:56.460
That way the formulas aren't there,
it's the actual numbers and

543
00:27:56.460 --> 00:27:57.830
that's all they get.

544
00:27:57.830 --> 00:27:59.890
So, being able to hide those
formulas can be helpful for

545
00:27:59.890 --> 00:28:04.110
you so that you can figure out where
the formulas are in your worksheet.

546
00:28:04.110 --> 00:28:06.710
I can also use them when I need
to get rid off the formulas

547
00:28:06.710 --> 00:28:09.020
before I give that
worksheet to somebody else.

548
00:28:09.020 --> 00:28:10.250
>> Excellent, now Mike,

549
00:28:10.250 --> 00:28:14.240
there's one other thing which is really
dealing more with the workbook itself.

550
00:28:14.240 --> 00:28:18.270
And we talk about adding in what we
call workbook properties, right?

551
00:28:18.270 --> 00:28:21.790
And so, Mike, let's go ahead, and
I'm gonna ask you this question.

552
00:28:21.790 --> 00:28:24.850
One, why would I ever do it, okay?

553
00:28:24.850 --> 00:28:27.730
And then two, what do we actually
need to do to accomplish it?

554
00:28:27.730 --> 00:28:30.020
>> Very good questions, and
I don't know the answer to either.

555
00:28:30.020 --> 00:28:33.230
No, [LAUGH] let's talk about that.

556
00:28:33.230 --> 00:28:36.925
We know that files have properties right,
all in Windows or

557
00:28:36.925 --> 00:28:42.140
any operating system a file has properties
like name and size and [COUGH] excuse me.

558
00:28:42.140 --> 00:28:45.030
Created by and last modified,
things like that.

559
00:28:45.030 --> 00:28:48.770
And those can be very useful to us
depending on what we're trying to do.

560
00:28:48.770 --> 00:28:52.310
We can add some additional properties and
really what I'm thinking about here

561
00:28:52.310 --> 00:28:56.110
are things like tags,
where we can add tags to our worksheets.

562
00:28:56.110 --> 00:28:58.320
And why would I want to?

563
00:28:58.320 --> 00:28:59.610
Because it can help me find them.

564
00:28:59.610 --> 00:29:01.100
It can help other people find them.

565
00:29:01.100 --> 00:29:04.520
It's pretty neat,
let me show you what I mean.

566
00:29:04.520 --> 00:29:08.850
This spreadsheet, I'm gonna go to
the backstage area, so I'm gonna go File.

567
00:29:08.850 --> 00:29:15.395
And on the Info tab of this backstage area
I can see properties for my documents.

568
00:29:15.395 --> 00:29:20.226
And you'll notice there's couple here,
we're gonna cancel out of that for

569
00:29:20.226 --> 00:29:23.670
right now, I've got Add tag and
Add category.

570
00:29:23.670 --> 00:29:25.750
So, you can see they're
kinda hover over them and

571
00:29:25.750 --> 00:29:30.010
they look like where I can fill
something in and I actually can.

572
00:29:30.010 --> 00:29:33.881
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna add
a tag, I'm gonna call this one sal,

573
00:29:33.881 --> 00:29:35.140
I'm gonna add salary.

574
00:29:35.140 --> 00:29:39.261
All right, I'm gonna go ahead and
tab out of that, and

575
00:29:39.261 --> 00:29:42.048
then I'm gonna save that document.

576
00:29:42.048 --> 00:29:45.618
And you might think well great
Mike now it has a tag of salary,

577
00:29:45.618 --> 00:29:47.890
what good does that do me?

578
00:29:47.890 --> 00:29:48.600
Well, check this out.

579
00:29:48.600 --> 00:29:51.850
When I go over to Windows Explorer,
I go over to my search,

580
00:29:51.850 --> 00:29:56.050
I type the word salary, if I can spell it.

581
00:29:56.050 --> 00:29:58.520
And there's my worksheet right there.

582
00:29:58.520 --> 00:30:03.077
So imagine going up to a shared location
where there's hundreds of spreadsheets.

583
00:30:03.077 --> 00:30:07.460
And you know one of those spreadsheets
has to deal with purchase orders.

584
00:30:07.460 --> 00:30:11.050
Well, if the person that generated that
spreadsheet took the time to add a tag

585
00:30:11.050 --> 00:30:13.010
purchase order, you could search for it.

586
00:30:13.010 --> 00:30:16.130
You wouldn't have to remember the name
of the workbook or anything like that.

587
00:30:16.130 --> 00:30:18.310
You can just search by tag.

588
00:30:18.310 --> 00:30:20.320
And you can add as many tags as you want.

589
00:30:20.320 --> 00:30:24.220
Even though this is called Employees,
I could add salary.

590
00:30:24.220 --> 00:30:26.230
We could add again any tag that I want.

591
00:30:26.230 --> 00:30:29.685
So really, the benefit of being able
to work with those properties is

592
00:30:29.685 --> 00:30:31.961
to make it easier to
locate those documents.

593
00:30:31.961 --> 00:30:35.598
Especially when you have dozens or
hundreds or hundreds and

594
00:30:35.598 --> 00:30:40.763
hundreds of spreadsheets or when you're
dealing with shared storage locations and

595
00:30:40.763 --> 00:30:45.127
you need to find a worksheet that you
know that somebody's tagged out of

596
00:30:45.127 --> 00:30:48.440
the hundreds of worksheets in there
>> There's no doubt Mike,

597
00:30:48.440 --> 00:30:51.980
this is one of the problems, right,
with the way Excel work books are.

598
00:30:51.980 --> 00:30:54.370
We tend to be fairly
generic with our naming.

599
00:30:54.370 --> 00:30:59.230
So Mike might name his salary_mr for
Mike Rodrick.

600
00:30:59.230 --> 00:31:03.790
And I might name mine salary_rw for
for Ronnie Wong, but

601
00:31:03.790 --> 00:31:06.690
then of course 100 other people
might do the same thing.

602
00:31:06.690 --> 00:31:08.330
Or we might all name our salary.

603
00:31:08.330 --> 00:31:11.733
And they're actually individual and
different, and 1 2 3 4 or

604
00:31:11.733 --> 00:31:13.874
whatever it might be, and now here it is.

605
00:31:13.874 --> 00:31:16.960
You're looking at names like,
I know I named it, crud.

606
00:31:16.960 --> 00:31:19.870
And so
being able to actually add in that tag, so

607
00:31:19.870 --> 00:31:23.300
that you can find yours among
a very common shared storage

608
00:31:23.300 --> 00:31:28.200
is really incredibly helpful because if
not you're gonna do like I do, right?

609
00:31:28.200 --> 00:31:31.050
You just open up everything real quick,
and go, no that's not mine,

610
00:31:31.050 --> 00:31:32.920
no that's not mine, this is mine.

611
00:31:32.920 --> 00:31:36.720
And then you start working and
your realize, that really isn't mine.

612
00:31:36.720 --> 00:31:39.662
And you're just hoping you didn't
actually hit save and save the changes.

613
00:31:39.662 --> 00:31:43.198
>> Yep, and even if you remember
the name of the document,

614
00:31:43.198 --> 00:31:45.620
what if that list is a mile long.

615
00:31:45.620 --> 00:31:47.890
Just by searching up there
in that tag field or

616
00:31:47.890 --> 00:31:52.110
that search field, makes it really easy
to jump right to that document as well.

617
00:31:52.110 --> 00:31:54.690
So it really is a handy feature.

618
00:31:54.690 --> 00:31:56.940
It's one that probably
most people don't use, and

619
00:31:56.940 --> 00:32:00.390
it's something that I think more of
us should use, including myself.

620
00:32:00.390 --> 00:32:05.630
>> Excellent Mike, well we do thank you
for showing us how we can take the default

621
00:32:05.630 --> 00:32:10.550
install of Excel 2016 And be able to
customize it to make it more effective

622
00:32:10.550 --> 00:32:14.100
to the way that we want to
be able to use Excel 2016.

623
00:32:14.100 --> 00:32:15.930
It allows us to be more productive.

624
00:32:15.930 --> 00:32:20.340
It allows us to make sure that we
can actually use it more effectively

625
00:32:20.340 --> 00:32:22.380
to whatever we're actually doing.

626
00:32:22.380 --> 00:32:24.010
And there's actually even more,
isn't there?

627
00:32:24.010 --> 00:32:25.886
>> There is, there's some really
cool stuff coming up, but

628
00:32:25.886 --> 00:32:27.889
I know you're getting ready to
tell me I've talked too long.

629
00:32:27.889 --> 00:32:28.539
>> Yes, you have.

630
00:32:28.539 --> 00:32:30.217
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] We'll save that for

631
00:32:30.217 --> 00:32:30.910
the next episode.

632
00:32:30.910 --> 00:32:31.750
That's our cliffhanger,

633
00:32:31.750 --> 00:32:35.360
keep you on the edge of the couch, hoping
that you come back and watch the next one.

634
00:32:35.360 --> 00:32:39.020
>> All right, well that's a great place
for us to go ahead and sign off for today.

635
00:32:39.020 --> 00:32:40.500
Signing off for ITPro.TV.

636
00:32:40.500 --> 00:32:41.083
I'm Ryan Wong.

637
00:32:41.083 --> 00:32:42.070
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

638
00:32:42.070 --> 00:32:43.411
>> And we'll see you next time.

639
00:32:43.411 --> 00:32:49.998
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike introduce us to more ways to become more efficient when working with Excel 2016.  Productivity and Efficiency and keys to working better with Excel.  They show us how to customize the ribbon and the quick access toolbar (QAT).  They emphasize how customizing these tools makes working in Excel more intuitive for the user.  The guys emphasize the use of Macros within the workbook and the need to secure them too since macros can be changed easily and run not only within that excel workbook but the commands can affect the entire computer system.
episodes.title: Customizing Views Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.178 --> 00:00:10.178
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.663 --> 00:00:15.684
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.684 --> 00:00:17.763
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:17.763 --> 00:00:22.030
today we're gonna be taking
a look at Microsoft Excel 2016.

5
00:00:22.030 --> 00:00:24.010
Now, we're actually going into a part two.

6

We're talking about customizing views,
the earlier version of this, right?

7
00:00:28.350 --> 00:00:32.030
We took a look at some of the tools that
we need to make sure that we understand

8
00:00:32.030 --> 00:00:34.920
and figure out how to work
with our documents better.

But, now, we're actually gonna find

00:00:38.670 --> 00:00:43.075
efficiency and who better to help us than,

11
00:00:43.075 --> 00:00:43.930
Mike Roderick?

00:00:43.930 --> 00:00:44.618
How's it going, Mike?

13

>> Uh-oh, I thought you were

>> [LAUGH] Okay, just kidding,

16

Thanks Ronnie for having me and

00:00:54.860 --> 00:00:57.470
We are progressing our

more advanced capabilities and

And as Ronnie said, and so far we've

that status bar and

The next thing we really want to take

call the Quick Access Toolbar, or

I don't like calling it that,

Anyway, we actually saw a little bit of

Now we're gonna take a closer look at
some of the things we can do with that

Quick Access Toolbar.

33
00:01:45.850 --> 00:01:47.120
So let's take a look at my screen here.

34
00:01:47.120 --> 00:01:50.150
I've just got a, it doesn't really
matter what workbook we have open.

00:01:50.150 --> 00:01:52.180
But, up in that top right-hand, I'm sorry,

00:01:52.180 --> 00:01:55.910
top left-hand corner,
remember these icons right up here,

00:01:55.910 --> 00:02:01.310
above my ribbons and my tabs, that was

00:02:01.310 --> 00:02:03.978
And I've reset my
customizations from that one

So by default you get Save, Undo and Redo.

Those are the only guys that are on there,

There's a little dropdown list right here

And when you hover over it, you can see

00:02:30.120 --> 00:02:34.010
So I'm gonna hit that dropdown list,

47

These are all the most common things that
Microsoft thinks you might wanna add

00:02:38.150 --> 00:02:40.210

So when I wanna create a new file,

And if I click it now,

So if you're a person that's

This is what you wanna think about,

00:03:21.361 --> 00:03:23.550

And you can see there's

New is one of them, I'll take that off,

New, Open, so if you open a lot of,

Email, Quick Print, Print Preview,

there's really not a lot of Print Preview

00:03:52.980 --> 00:03:56.500
the backstage area, and then print and

00:03:56.500 --> 00:03:59.970
Well now I got it right out here and

00:03:59.970 --> 00:04:03.650
I can take a look at my document and

74
00:04:03.650 --> 00:04:06.380
Oops, let's not do that.

75
00:04:06.380 --> 00:04:10.115
You zoomed in, I can't tell which close,

And so anyway,

There is one we'll point out,

If you use a touchscreen,

or if you work on a tablet or

And when you do the optimize for touch,

00:04:38.250 --> 00:04:42.830
bigger, because when I'm using my finger,
it's easy to, with that smaller mode,

you can end up clicking on

But if we do this switch to touch mode,

move that Quick Access Toolbar to say,

>> You can, there's an option

00:05:11.450 --> 00:05:13.240

Cuz what you'll find is if I start

So definitely something new,

00:05:57.390 --> 00:05:59.210
And I'm gonna bring that ribbon back out.

You can go to, you can look for
