00:30:02.450 --> 00:30:04.660
Something that is not in
use by anything else.

564
00:30:04.660 --> 00:30:09.660
I will do a control L, I think that is
safe there, and then where do I want

565
00:30:09.660 --> 00:30:13.490
to store the Madcrew, this is another
option we have to pay attention to.

566
00:30:13.490 --> 00:30:14.910
This work book.

567
00:30:14.910 --> 00:30:19.270
Personal Macro Workbook or New Workbook.

568
00:30:19.270 --> 00:30:22.330
If I store it in this workbook
which is the default,

569
00:30:22.330 --> 00:30:25.820
every time I open this workbook
up that macro will be available.

570
00:30:25.820 --> 00:30:29.850
If I open up a different workbook
that macro will not be available.

571
00:30:29.850 --> 00:30:33.170
So is this a macro that I'm only going
to use in this particular workbook, or

572
00:30:33.170 --> 00:30:35.480
is it one that I want to be
available no matter what workbook,

573
00:30:35.480 --> 00:30:39.780
even new workbooks that I open If I want
it to be available in other workbooks,

574
00:30:39.780 --> 00:30:42.240
I choose the personal macro workbook.

575
00:30:42.240 --> 00:30:46.540
It's a special workbook that is hidden
from us that access has, and it will put

576
00:30:46.540 --> 00:30:50.340
all the macros in there and that way, any
spread sheets you open, any work book you

577
00:30:50.340 --> 00:30:54.310
open, you'll have access to those macros
so, I'll go ahead and store it there.

578
00:30:54.310 --> 00:30:58.005
That's fine, and,

579
00:30:58.005 --> 00:31:03.910
I'll say add sum Column to data.

580
00:31:03.910 --> 00:31:04.680
Something like that.

581
00:31:04.680 --> 00:31:05.180
We'll click ok.

582
00:31:05.180 --> 00:31:07.620
Alright, so
now it's in the process of recording.

583
00:31:07.620 --> 00:31:10.090
We're gonna scroll back out,
we look down here.

584
00:31:10.090 --> 00:31:12.110
Notice the button has changed to a box.

585
00:31:12.110 --> 00:31:15.280
Which kind of indicates that's our
usually our stop button right on most

586
00:31:15.280 --> 00:31:17.710
tape recorders, or recording devices.

587
00:31:17.710 --> 00:31:20.250
So that's what I'm gonna
click when I'm done.

588
00:31:20.250 --> 00:31:23.190
So I'm gonna add the word Sum,
or let's do Total.

589
00:31:23.190 --> 00:31:24.450
Now, see right there?

590
00:31:24.450 --> 00:31:28.220
It will remember the fact that I made
those typos, and if you watch closely,

591
00:31:28.220 --> 00:31:29.620
it'll actually do that.

592
00:31:29.620 --> 00:31:31.880
Kinda silly.

593
00:31:31.880 --> 00:31:37.110
Then here, I'm gonna add a formula,
equals, quantity

594
00:31:38.510 --> 00:31:42.910
times unit price, and I'll show you how to
do these formulas in an episode coming up,

595
00:31:42.910 --> 00:31:45.460
and I'll go ahead and
hit enter, all right.

596
00:31:45.460 --> 00:31:46.290
So there's my total, and

597
00:31:46.290 --> 00:31:49.880
then I'm gonna go ahead and series fill
all the way down to the end of that,

598
00:31:49.880 --> 00:31:53.660
which I'll show you how to do in just
a little bit as well, and I'll stop there,

599
00:31:53.660 --> 00:31:56.570
cuz we haven't heard a lot about
the formatting and things like that.

600
00:31:56.570 --> 00:31:59.409
So I'll click away to deselect, and

601
00:31:59.409 --> 00:32:03.446
now I'm going to go over here and
stop my recording.

602
00:32:03.446 --> 00:32:05.489
So now I have a macro.

603
00:32:05.489 --> 00:32:10.414
And the idea is that I can go to another
spreadsheet, and I can just play that.

604
00:32:10.414 --> 00:32:11.120
So let's try it.

605
00:32:11.120 --> 00:32:16.078
I'm gonna do my Ctrl+L, and

606
00:32:16.078 --> 00:32:19.330
look at there.

607
00:32:19.330 --> 00:32:23.760
Now, somehow I put total way over there,
which is interesting.

608
00:32:23.760 --> 00:32:28.250
I'll have to double check and
see why, I wonder if my active cell.

609
00:32:28.250 --> 00:32:29.170
We'll move that up here.

610
00:32:31.000 --> 00:32:33.710
But you noticed that it put the word
total in the wrong spot and

611
00:32:33.710 --> 00:32:37.170
we will figure out why it did that here
in just a second, and then it created my

612
00:32:37.170 --> 00:32:41.660
formula and it filled that formula in
all the way down to the bottom, right?

613
00:32:41.660 --> 00:32:44.830
And, that was just a very simple macro.

614
00:32:44.830 --> 00:32:48.470
I could've spent, and what we're going to
do later on is I'm going to show you how

615
00:32:48.470 --> 00:32:53.530
to do all this with a macro, and
really it's just starting the recording,

616
00:32:53.530 --> 00:32:56.120
doing the steps and
then stopping the recording.

617
00:32:56.120 --> 00:32:57.200
That's all there is to it.

618
00:32:57.200 --> 00:32:59.520
>> Now Mike,
when we end up saving this workbook,

619
00:32:59.520 --> 00:33:02.400
is there anything that changes
about the workbook itself?

620
00:33:02.400 --> 00:33:04.790
>> No.
Well yes, actually very good point there.

621
00:33:05.980 --> 00:33:09.760
This particular one I didn't save
the macro in the workbook, so

622
00:33:09.760 --> 00:33:11.040
it shouldn't bother me.

623
00:33:11.040 --> 00:33:12.430
Let's see what happens here.

624
00:33:12.430 --> 00:33:14.590
Click save and everything's fine.

625
00:33:14.590 --> 00:33:17.230
Because I stored that macro
in that personal workbook,

626
00:33:17.230 --> 00:33:18.850
which is separate from this one.

627
00:33:18.850 --> 00:33:21.580
But if you store a macro in a workbook.

628
00:33:21.580 --> 00:33:23.780
Let's say I wanna send
this workbook to Ronny,

629
00:33:23.780 --> 00:33:25.930
and I need that macro functionality.

630
00:33:25.930 --> 00:33:30.680
When Ronny gets it, he needs to be able
to use that macro for whatever reason.

631
00:33:30.680 --> 00:33:33.990
Well, in that case I can't put it in my
personal workbook I got to store it in

632
00:33:33.990 --> 00:33:35.470
this workbook.

633
00:33:35.470 --> 00:33:40.990
The default file format for
Excel is a .xlsx,

634
00:33:40.990 --> 00:33:44.530
which does not contain macros,
and it's a security feature.

635
00:33:44.530 --> 00:33:47.160
That way you can't have macros in there.

636
00:33:47.160 --> 00:33:51.700
If you want to save a workbook with
a macro in it, you have to change the file

637
00:33:51.700 --> 00:33:58.640
extension to a .xls M if I can
say that m being for macro.

638
00:33:58.640 --> 00:34:00.680
Right?
And let's record another macro real quick.

639
00:34:00.680 --> 00:34:03.520
All I'm going to do is I'm
going to just hit record and

640
00:34:03.520 --> 00:34:07.780
I'll call it Macro2 that's fine or
I'll call it HeaderRow.

641
00:34:07.780 --> 00:34:11.680
And I put a space in there,
so let's get rid of that.

642
00:34:11.680 --> 00:34:13.650
And I'm going to store
this in this workbook.

643
00:34:14.830 --> 00:34:15.330
And I'll click okay.

644
00:34:15.330 --> 00:34:20.040
And then I'm gonna select row one and
I'm gonna make it bold and

645
00:34:20.040 --> 00:34:21.910
bump that font up one point.

646
00:34:23.230 --> 00:34:25.460
And I'll leave it at that.

647
00:34:25.460 --> 00:34:26.740
I'll click away from everything.

648
00:34:27.810 --> 00:34:30.020
And I'll stop recording my macro.

649
00:34:30.020 --> 00:34:32.130
Now watch what happens when I go to save.

650
00:34:32.130 --> 00:34:36.670
It's gonna say, the following features
cannot be saved in a macro free workbook.

651
00:34:36.670 --> 00:34:39.920
So I'm gonna say, to continue
saving as a macro free workbook,

652
00:34:39.920 --> 00:34:42.880
yes, I'm gonna say no.

653
00:34:42.880 --> 00:34:48.560
And notice, I'm gonna change
this to a .xlsm right there.

654
00:34:48.560 --> 00:34:50.730
Macro enabled workbook.

655
00:34:51.800 --> 00:34:53.222
See, it changes that extension.

656
00:34:53.222 --> 00:34:54.962
To a .xlsm.

657
00:34:54.962 --> 00:34:56.508
All right.

658
00:34:56.508 --> 00:35:03.230
Then I can click save and that's okay.

659
00:35:03.230 --> 00:35:05.060
We'll click okay and there we go.

660
00:35:05.060 --> 00:35:09.440
So as Ronny asked,
the answer to his question is yes.

661
00:35:09.440 --> 00:35:12.070
If you wanna store macros in the workbook,

662
00:35:12.070 --> 00:35:15.880
you have to change the file format or
the extension on that file.

663
00:35:15.880 --> 00:35:19.600
Otherwise, it'll save it and
it'll leave the macros out.

664
00:35:19.600 --> 00:35:20.460
>> All right, Mike.

665
00:35:20.460 --> 00:35:23.720
Well, that's a lot to really help us to
become more efficient as we think about

666
00:35:23.720 --> 00:35:24.690
a few things here.

667
00:35:24.690 --> 00:35:27.890
Is there any other thing that we need
to think about as far as getting

668
00:35:27.890 --> 00:35:28.510
more efficient?

669
00:35:28.510 --> 00:35:31.960
>> There is one more thing I wanna throw
in there was assigning shortcut keys.

670
00:35:31.960 --> 00:35:34.880
You saw that when I wrote that macro
that I could assign a shortcut

671
00:35:34.880 --> 00:35:36.139
key to the macro itself.

672
00:35:37.710 --> 00:35:40.350
The other shortcut keys we have to worry
about are for the commands up here.

673
00:35:40.350 --> 00:35:44.750
And it's really not so much that we add
them, it's that Microsoft does it for me.

674
00:35:44.750 --> 00:35:47.420
But watch me, if I hit alt on my keyboard,

675
00:35:47.420 --> 00:35:52.250
notice up here at the top, all these
little letters and numbers come out.

676
00:35:52.250 --> 00:35:56.580
So basically what's going on is when
I hit the alt key on my keyboard,

677
00:35:56.580 --> 00:36:01.600
it's saying if you wanna jump to
the formulas ribbon hit the letter M.

678
00:36:01.600 --> 00:36:05.740
So I hit M and now here's all
the commands on the formulas written and

679
00:36:05.740 --> 00:36:08.120
each one has a letter associated with it.

680
00:36:08.120 --> 00:36:12.020
So if I want to show formulas,
it's the letter H.

681
00:36:12.020 --> 00:36:13.770
I hit H H.

682
00:36:13.770 --> 00:36:16.780
And there we go, I'm now showing formulas.

683
00:36:16.780 --> 00:36:19.250
So the keyboard shortcuts already exist.

684
00:36:19.250 --> 00:36:21.400
You hit the alt key to pull them up.

685
00:36:21.400 --> 00:36:23.680
When it talks about
assigning shortcut keys,

686
00:36:23.680 --> 00:36:27.110
you're really looking at macros,
and your custom ribbons.

687
00:36:27.110 --> 00:36:29.350
Let's go take a look at my tab over here.

688
00:36:29.350 --> 00:36:34.847
I'm gonna hit alt, And
I'll hit Y2 for my custom tab.

689
00:36:34.847 --> 00:36:37.000
>> [LAUGH]
>> Y2, all right.

690
00:36:37.000 --> 00:36:39.190
So one, I didn't assign that, right?

691
00:36:39.190 --> 00:36:40.650
When we created that custom ribbon,

692
00:36:40.650 --> 00:36:43.930
I didn't say, Y2's gonna need
a keyboard shortcut for it.

693
00:36:43.930 --> 00:36:45.500
But it assigned one for me.

694
00:36:45.500 --> 00:36:50.840
And then the commands that I added to my
ribbon, It also added keyboard circuits.

695
00:36:50.840 --> 00:36:55.700
So pate special, I don't have anything so
they're grayed out I don't have a table so

696
00:36:55.700 --> 00:36:56.770
those are grayed out.

697
00:36:56.770 --> 00:37:02.870
But you can see it added keyboard
shortcuts to those commands for me, right?

698
00:37:02.870 --> 00:37:07.050
So even my custom ribbons that I create
get assigned keyboard shortcuts.

699
00:37:07.050 --> 00:37:10.950
And just again, some people are really
good, I love keyboard shortcuts.

700
00:37:10.950 --> 00:37:14.750
Yes the more time, you know, here's what
the, I remember when I first got into

701
00:37:14.750 --> 00:37:18.370
computers they tried to tell me that,
you know, the mouse is inefficient.

702
00:37:18.370 --> 00:37:21.060
Like I love my mouse,
I can work really well with it.

703
00:37:21.060 --> 00:37:23.880
But what you'll find is that somebody that
can do keyboard shortcuts by the time that

704
00:37:23.880 --> 00:37:27.450
it takes for you take your hand off
the mouse, put it on the keyboard,

705
00:37:27.450 --> 00:37:32.230
type whatever, and go back to your mouse,
click on the next thing,

706
00:37:32.230 --> 00:37:33.040
get back to your keyboard.

707
00:37:33.040 --> 00:37:35.690
Somebody that knows a keyboard
shortcut would've been done by now.

708
00:37:35.690 --> 00:37:37.760
So they are pretty efficient.

709
00:37:37.760 --> 00:37:38.710
>> All right.

710
00:37:38.710 --> 00:37:42.060
Well Mike, that's a great place for
us to go in this episode,

711
00:37:42.060 --> 00:37:45.500
since we did learn more about
how we can actually use Excel.

712
00:37:45.500 --> 00:37:48.200
And make it a bit more efficient
in the way that we work.

713
00:37:48.200 --> 00:37:50.080
So we're gonna go and sign off.

714
00:37:50.080 --> 00:37:52.490
Signing off for ITPro TV, I'm Ronny Wong.

715
00:37:52.490 --> 00:37:53.690
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

716
00:37:53.690 --> 00:37:59.001
>> And we'll see you next time.

717
00:37:59.001 --> 00:38:02.850
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike talk about the importance of saving and printing with Excel 2016.  They guide us through some of the different options we have for saving an Excel file in a different format to make the data more accessible to people who may not use excel.  While printing is not difficult, setting up to print what we want to print has many more options that can make it a little more complex so Mike shows us some of the printing options available including setting a print area and setting print scaling as well as adding in information into the headers and footers.  They close out of the show by talking about the benefits of saving to remote locations.
episodes.title: Printing and Saving
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.546 --> 00:00:16.005
Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on ITproTV.

3
00:00:16.005 --> 00:00:18.370
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today,

4
00:00:18.370 --> 00:00:21.910
we're gonna be taking a look
at Microsoft Excel 2016.

5
00:00:21.910 --> 00:00:24.070
And we're heading into
the area of printing and

6
00:00:24.070 --> 00:00:28.030
saving, two of the big areas that
we really do need to understand.

7
00:00:28.030 --> 00:00:31.080
Because it is essential that we can
take the data that we're working,

8
00:00:31.080 --> 00:00:34.820
with make sure that we can save it so
that we don't lose the data, but

9
00:00:34.820 --> 00:00:36.170
as well as being able to print it out.

10
00:00:36.170 --> 00:00:38.940
And we are gonna see there are some
challenges especially when we're printing

11
00:00:38.940 --> 00:00:40.500
out large work books, too.

12
00:00:40.500 --> 00:00:44.860
And who better to help us than well Mr.
Excel himself, Mike Rodrick.

13
00:00:44.860 --> 00:00:48.950
Mike, welcome back and
where are we getting started here?

14
00:00:48.950 --> 00:00:51.790
>> Well, let's start with printing, right?

15
00:00:51.790 --> 00:00:53.500
And printing is something,
we're going paperless, so

16
00:00:53.500 --> 00:00:54.970
we really don't need to print for
much longer.

17
00:00:54.970 --> 00:00:55.710
>> Never.

18
00:00:55.710 --> 00:00:56.360
>> I'm kidding, right?

19
00:00:56.360 --> 00:00:59.160
We've been saying that since,
I don't know, a decade now.

20
00:00:59.160 --> 00:01:03.980
But, yes, there's many times that we do
need a hard copy, what I call a hard copy.

21
00:01:03.980 --> 00:01:05.930
We gotta get it off our screen and

22
00:01:05.930 --> 00:01:11.330
onto a good old piece of paper that we can
share with somebody, send to somebody,

23
00:01:11.330 --> 00:01:15.790
put on a clipboard somewhere, whatever
the case may be, you need that hard copy.

24
00:01:15.790 --> 00:01:18.830
Or maybe the numbers change and
you need a snap shot.

25
00:01:18.830 --> 00:01:19.770
You need to print it or

26
00:01:19.770 --> 00:01:22.735
what have you, several different
reasons you might want to print it out.

27
00:01:22.735 --> 00:01:26.370
Sometimes I like to print them out just so
I can scribble and make notes and

28
00:01:26.370 --> 00:01:30.846
think about it and then go back and
then do things inside or on Excel.

29
00:01:30.846 --> 00:01:33.856
So whatever the reason,
we need to be able to print.

30
00:01:33.856 --> 00:01:34.480
And as Ronnie said,

31
00:01:34.480 --> 00:01:40.190
printing in Excel is not a straight
forward as a text editor like Word.

32
00:01:40.190 --> 00:01:43.250
Because in Word we've got our page layout,
right?

33
00:01:43.250 --> 00:01:46.450
And we've got our margins, and
we type within those margins.

34
00:01:46.450 --> 00:01:49.460
And it just puts a new page and
our text roles down.

35
00:01:49.460 --> 00:01:51.325
And we're typically good to go.

36
00:01:51.325 --> 00:01:54.410
Now, of course, there are some fancy
things we can do with that, but

37
00:01:54.410 --> 00:01:57.950
by default it's pretty easy
just to print out a document.

38
00:01:57.950 --> 00:02:00.720
With Excel we don't really have that,
right?

39
00:02:00.720 --> 00:02:04.690
Because we can many columns,
many, many, many columns, and

40
00:02:04.690 --> 00:02:07.688
they're not gonna fit on one page,
at least legibly.

41
00:02:07.688 --> 00:02:10.720
We can have hundreds of thousands of rows,
and

42
00:02:10.720 --> 00:02:14.720
again, not gonna be able to fit
that on one or two pages legibly.

43
00:02:14.720 --> 00:02:17.140
And we might not want all of that.

44
00:02:17.140 --> 00:02:20.580
So we've got to figure out how to
decide what it is we want to print,

45
00:02:20.580 --> 00:02:24.690
how we're going to go about printing it,
how we want to make it fit on the page and

46
00:02:24.690 --> 00:02:26.190
still be legible.

47
00:02:26.190 --> 00:02:29.210
So there's a few things, and
we've seen a couple of them already.

48
00:02:29.210 --> 00:02:30.840
We've looked at orientation or

49
00:02:30.840 --> 00:02:34.870
we talked a little bit about it kind of
when we were exploring the interface.

50
00:02:34.870 --> 00:02:38.140
We've looked at headers and footers a
little bit, but we're gonna go back in and

51
00:02:38.140 --> 00:02:39.040
take another look at those.

52
00:02:39.040 --> 00:02:42.980
So the first thing I want to talk about
specifically is setting what they call

53
00:02:42.980 --> 00:02:43.610
a print area.

54
00:02:43.610 --> 00:02:47.500
And this is a very common
thing to do with Excel.

55
00:02:47.500 --> 00:02:50.220
If we take a look at this
workbook that I have open here,

56
00:02:50.220 --> 00:02:52.928
I've got the January sales figures here.

57
00:02:52.928 --> 00:02:56.010
And as I scroll down,
you can see I've got, I don't know,

58
00:02:56.010 --> 00:03:01.110
a few hundred rows here, 250,
something like that, a pretty long list.

59
00:03:01.110 --> 00:03:02.770
And then off to the side,

60
00:03:02.770 --> 00:03:06.740
I've got like a summary information
where I've got some totals going on.

61
00:03:06.740 --> 00:03:10.820
And my boss, when they want these numbers,
she doesn't want the details.

62
00:03:10.820 --> 00:03:13.880
All she needs is the summary information,
right?

63
00:03:13.880 --> 00:03:18.350
Well, when I go to print this, then all
I wanna do is print this over here.

64
00:03:18.350 --> 00:03:21.490
I can do like Print Selections,
which I'll show you how to do.

65
00:03:21.490 --> 00:03:26.800
But what we're gonna do is,
set up what we call the Print Area.

66
00:03:26.800 --> 00:03:29.600
There's this option on
the Page Layout ribbon.

67
00:03:29.600 --> 00:03:34.790
There's a Print Area dropdown,
and I can do Set Print Area.

68
00:03:34.790 --> 00:03:38.400
When I do that, oops, and
yes, let's cancel that.

69
00:03:38.400 --> 00:03:43.750
You want to before you do that, you want
to select the print area, all right?

70
00:03:43.750 --> 00:03:44.570
I forgot to do that.

71
00:03:44.570 --> 00:03:48.280
So I'm gonna just click and
drag across this area right here.

72
00:03:48.280 --> 00:03:52.770
Now that I got that area highlighted,
I'm gonna choose Set Print Area.

73
00:03:52.770 --> 00:03:56.450
So it's a little backwards from a lot of
the other things we're doing in Excel

74
00:03:56.450 --> 00:03:59.910
where you first pick the command, and
then it gives you the picker dialogue box,

75
00:03:59.910 --> 00:04:01.500
where you go Select Your Cells.

76
00:04:01.500 --> 00:04:06.550
In this one you want to select them
first and then click the Set Print Area.

77
00:04:06.550 --> 00:04:08.930
So now notice it's called the Print Area.

78
00:04:08.930 --> 00:04:11.745
You can see over here in
the name box it says Print Area.

79
00:04:11.745 --> 00:04:12.575
I click away from it.

80
00:04:12.575 --> 00:04:14.725
It really doesn't look any different.

81
00:04:14.725 --> 00:04:19.175
You might be able to see that faint
line that's going around that area.

82
00:04:19.175 --> 00:04:23.085
But other than that the sheet
still works exactly the same.

83
00:04:23.085 --> 00:04:25.445
The difference is going
to be when I go to print.

84
00:04:25.445 --> 00:04:27.665
I go File, then Print.

85
00:04:27.665 --> 00:04:34.150
And if you look at my print preview
it's just those totals area, right?

86
00:04:34.150 --> 00:04:36.840
There's no columns,
there's no details or anything.

87
00:04:36.840 --> 00:04:41.140
And I didn't have to select anything when
I got in here like Print My Selection or

88
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:43.020
Define the Range or anything like that.

89
00:04:43.020 --> 00:04:47.030
By setting that ahead of time,
you could actually add Print or

90
00:04:47.030 --> 00:04:50.540
Quick Print up here in your quick
access toolbar and just click Print.

91
00:04:50.540 --> 00:04:52.450
And it would just print that area.

92
00:04:52.450 --> 00:04:56.080
No matter what other data's on that sheet,
it's just gonna print that area.

93
00:04:56.080 --> 00:04:59.220
So I find that really handy if I
have a sheet like this that has

94
00:04:59.220 --> 00:05:01.230
that summary type information.

95
00:05:03.180 --> 00:05:04.470
To get rid of that print area,

96
00:05:04.470 --> 00:05:07.680
because now every time we go to Print
it only wants to print that area.

97
00:05:07.680 --> 00:05:13.190
If I need to get rid of that, you go right
back to Print Area and Clear Print Area.

98
00:05:13.190 --> 00:05:19.180
Now that I've got a print area added or
created, notice it has Add to Print Area.

99
00:05:19.180 --> 00:05:24.060
So maybe I had a totals row
down at the bottom down here.

100
00:05:24.060 --> 00:05:29.358
I'm just gonna real quick pretend that
this is some kind of totals area.

101
00:05:29.358 --> 00:05:31.280
So we're just gonna do
a real quick auto sum.

102
00:05:31.280 --> 00:05:34.520
Don't worry I'll show you some of
these information in the future.

103
00:05:36.670 --> 00:05:37.770
Then, we'll drag that over there.

104
00:05:37.770 --> 00:05:41.342
Let's say I wanted to add
that to my print area.

105
00:05:41.342 --> 00:05:47.170
I could highlight these guys and

106
00:05:47.170 --> 00:05:53.550
then go to back to my Page Layout and
then Print Area, Add to Print Area.

107
00:05:55.230 --> 00:05:58.340
So now you see there's a faint little
box going around that as well.

108
00:05:58.340 --> 00:06:03.380
When I go File and Print, I get two pages.

109
00:06:03.380 --> 00:06:08.320
The second page is going to be
that totals row that I just added.

110
00:06:08.320 --> 00:06:12.030
So you do your print page, what I was
trying to show you there is that the print

111
00:06:12.030 --> 00:06:13.830
areas don't have to be contiguous.

112
00:06:13.830 --> 00:06:15.100
They don't have to be touching.

113
00:06:15.100 --> 00:06:18.720
You can have a section from over here,
a little section from over there.

114
00:06:18.720 --> 00:06:20.490
You define all those as your print area,

115
00:06:20.490 --> 00:06:24.390
and then when you print it skips the other
stuff and then just prints those.

116
00:06:24.390 --> 00:06:27.680
And then of course to get rid of it,
Clear Print Area.

117
00:06:27.680 --> 00:06:28.300
They're all gone.

118
00:06:28.300 --> 00:06:33.050
And that doesn't do, it clears all of
them, not just the last one you did.

119
00:06:33.050 --> 00:06:35.020
This is no longer a print area either.

120
00:06:35.020 --> 00:06:41.470
When I go to File and Print, it's now back
to printing the entire worksheet there.

121
00:06:41.470 --> 00:06:42.420
So pretty easy to do.

122
00:06:42.420 --> 00:06:44.740
If you've got a section that
you always need to print,

123
00:06:44.740 --> 00:06:46.620
just define it as a print area.

124
00:06:48.020 --> 00:06:50.700
Other things that we're gonna
kind of jump around here, Ronnie.

125
00:06:50.700 --> 00:06:55.460
They got saving workbooks in alternate
file format, another thing that we really

126
00:06:55.460 --> 00:07:00.840
need to be able to do, especially in
environments where we use a big fancy,

127
00:07:00.840 --> 00:07:04.950
heterogeneous type of
environment where people use

128
00:07:04.950 --> 00:07:07.810
different types of applications
to work with this data.

129
00:07:07.810 --> 00:07:11.700
If not everybody is using Excel, I might
need to save this in a format that is

130
00:07:11.700 --> 00:07:15.110
compatible with somebody
else's applications,

131
00:07:15.110 --> 00:07:16.505
whatever they want to do it in.

132
00:07:16.505 --> 00:07:19.400
And Excel gives us several
different options.

133
00:07:19.400 --> 00:07:21.090
If we go File and

134
00:07:21.090 --> 00:07:25.290
I'm gonna do a Save As, because this
document has already been saved once.

135
00:07:25.290 --> 00:07:29.600
If I just click Save,
it's gonna use the already existing name,

136
00:07:29.600 --> 00:07:33.300
the already existing location, and
the already existing extension.

137
00:07:33.300 --> 00:07:35.140
So I won't be able to change any of that.

138
00:07:35.140 --> 00:07:38.940
If I want to save this as an alternate
file format to give to Ronnie to work with

139
00:07:38.940 --> 00:07:42.400
his program, I have to do a Save As.

140
00:07:42.400 --> 00:07:46.530
All right, and in here, I can go and find
the location that I want to save it to.

141
00:07:47.930 --> 00:07:51.850
And then for the Save as type,
I get a drop down list.

142
00:07:51.850 --> 00:07:53.960
And you'll see it's not a short list.

143
00:07:53.960 --> 00:07:56.609
I've got my default Excel
workbook there at the top.

144
00:07:56.609 --> 00:08:00.879
And let me zoom in a wee bit so
we can get a better look at these guys.

145
00:08:00.879 --> 00:08:01.750
Right?

146
00:08:01.750 --> 00:08:07.340
So I've got my Excel Workbook, I've got my
Macro-Enabled Workbook, Binary Workbooks.

147
00:08:07.340 --> 00:08:12.700
Here I can go back to a 97-2003 format,
so if not everyone's been upgraded,

148
00:08:12.700 --> 00:08:17.750
they wouldn't understand that .xlsx
possibly, I can save it as an .xls.

149
00:08:17.750 --> 00:08:20.740
Or I might have some other
application that's not Office, but

150
00:08:20.740 --> 00:08:25.610
it does, it was at the time compatible
with the old office formats.

151
00:08:25.610 --> 00:08:29.030
So I can go back to that older format,
xml for

152
00:08:29.030 --> 00:08:33.900
example a very neutral language that
almost all applications understand.

153
00:08:33.900 --> 00:08:36.080
Web formats you can do templates.

154
00:08:36.080 --> 00:08:37.670
We haven't talk about those guys yet.

155
00:08:39.090 --> 00:08:43.983
We've got Tab delimited,
comma separated values.

156
00:08:43.983 --> 00:08:46.482
Remember I showed you that one,
in a previous episode?

157
00:08:46.482 --> 00:08:48.241
Very common format to use,

158
00:08:48.241 --> 00:08:53.060
when I need to move this data
from one application to another.

159
00:08:53.060 --> 00:08:57.715
I've got some old Macintosh text
files csv files down there,

00:08:57.715 --> 00:09:01.305
PDFs, xps, everybody's favorite, right?

161
00:09:01.305 --> 00:09:02.191
>> Mm-hm.

00:09:02.191 --> 00:09:03.066
>> I'm just kidding.
>> [LAUGH]

163
00:09:03.066 --> 00:09:04.482
>> I'm kidding, Microsoft.

164
00:09:04.482 --> 00:09:05.380
We all love XPS.

165
00:09:07.040 --> 00:09:08.210
OpenDocument Spreadsheet.

166
00:09:08.210 --> 00:09:10.150
Notice that's actually a choice.

167
00:09:10.150 --> 00:09:13.969
So we were talking at the break with
David out there in the chat room,

00:09:13.969 --> 00:09:16.192
talking about Google Docs and Sheets.

00:09:16.192 --> 00:09:21.107
I can save this as a dot ods

00:09:21.107 --> 00:09:25.482
Now I'm pretty sure, Google Docs can

00:09:25.482 --> 00:09:29.659
what if you wanted to put it in that
format because you had an application that

00:09:29.659 --> 00:09:33.440
understood dot ods, but
didn't understand dot xlxs, right?

173
00:09:33.440 --> 00:09:33.970
Well, you can do that,

174
00:09:33.970 --> 00:09:38.790
it's as simple as just doing a file save
and then choosing the format you want.

175
00:09:38.790 --> 00:09:42.300
So if somebody comes to you and says, hey,
I need that data that you've got in that

176
00:09:42.300 --> 00:09:47.390
Excel Spreadsheet, but my application only
does PDFs, or only does comma separated

177
00:09:47.390 --> 00:09:51.890
values, or doesn't understand that
Excel format, could you give it to me?

178
00:09:51.890 --> 00:09:54.940
You don't have to try to copy and

00:09:54.940 --> 00:10:01.390
you can just do a File > Save As, and

180
00:10:01.390 --> 00:10:02.800
So Excel makes it pretty darn easy.

00:10:04.650 --> 00:10:08.560
All right, so

00:10:08.560 --> 00:10:11.670
Again, that's really for

00:10:11.670 --> 00:10:16.850

00:10:16.850 --> 00:10:20.016
>> Yeah, I think that usually the times
that I really need it is because

00:10:20.016 --> 00:10:22.530
somebody is not running
the latest version of Excel.

186
00:10:22.530 --> 00:10:26.393
So even if I were to transfer

00:10:26.393 --> 00:10:31.260
if they're running let's say
Excel 2007 and not up to 2016.

00:10:31.260 --> 00:10:34.405
Well, you may find out that they
can't actually open that format,

00:10:34.405 --> 00:10:38.280
even though you can perfectly open their
format, they may not be able to open that.

190
00:10:38.280 --> 00:10:42.200
So giving you the ability to save it

00:10:42.200 --> 00:10:44.864
The other thing that also helps

00:10:44.864 --> 00:10:48.010
the very fact is not everybody's

00:10:48.010 --> 00:10:52.737
So you may actually again want to save it
in some format that they believe that they

00:10:52.737 --> 00:10:54.180

00:10:54.180 --> 00:10:58.319
You will end up finding out sometimes

00:10:58.319 --> 00:11:01.899

00:11:01.899 --> 00:11:04.368
And there's a couple of reasons for

00:11:04.368 --> 00:11:07.482
just kinda realize that they
may not see exactly that way.

00:11:07.482 --> 00:11:10.660
So you may see some format changing
going on, but overall though,

00:11:10.660 --> 00:11:13.190
they'll at least get all

00:11:13.190 --> 00:11:14.030
>> Yeah, absolutely.

00:11:14.030 --> 00:11:15.490
That's a great point, Ronnie.

00:11:15.490 --> 00:11:18.450
The other thing you might

If you've got formulas in here and

00:11:24.120 --> 00:11:26.980
It's not gonna understand those formulas,

00:11:26.980 --> 00:11:28.154

00:11:28.154 --> 00:11:31.816

00:11:31.816 --> 00:11:33.149
Do you wanna continue?

00:11:33.149 --> 00:11:34.090
You say, yes.

00:11:34.090 --> 00:11:36.530
And it just strips out anything

00:11:36.530 --> 00:11:40.954
Charts and graphs, Excel has some

00:11:40.954 --> 00:11:45.738
those charts might not work in a Google
Doc or a TXT file or something like that,

00:11:45.738 --> 00:11:48.441
so again, youre gonna lose some of that.

00:11:48.441 --> 00:11:52.441
Sometimes the way to go to

00:11:52.441 --> 00:11:54.290
All right, what else we got Ronnie?

Printing back to printing.

Printing individual worksheets

00:12:00.620 --> 00:12:06.734
When we go to File and Print,

This is all one particular spreadsheet.

Print active sheet, so in other words,

I can hit this drop down list, and

00:12:32.580 --> 00:12:36.950
So I can print all five or six of those

00:12:36.950 --> 00:12:41.460
I don't have to go to one tab,

Remember, I said you

00:12:47.066 --> 00:12:49.150

00:12:49.150 --> 00:12:53.016
And let me zoom back out here,
what if I want to,

00:12:53.016 --> 00:12:56.230
normally I wanna print Just this area.

00:12:56.230 --> 00:12:57.774
I might print it.

I might do it as a set print area.

00:13:00.480 --> 00:13:04.270
But today,
I just wanna print this right here.

00:13:04.270 --> 00:13:05.610
I don't normally do that.

00:13:05.610 --> 00:13:08.295
Well, I'm not gonna set the print area,
cuz that makes it the default,

00:13:08.295 --> 00:13:10.500

What I can do, is I can select it and

So if it's not something you do all

So easy to flip back and

And if you look at this one that I have

00:15:57.244 --> 00:16:00.578

00:28:48.250 --> 00:28:52.920
stuff like that, but notice down here,
Connected service, one drive personal.

514
00:28:52.920 --> 00:28:56.810
So I have tied this in
to my OneDrive account.

515
00:28:56.810 --> 00:29:01.704
You can always go to add service and
you can add storage, Office 365,

516
00:29:01.704 --> 00:29:06.510
OnePoint, you can do sharing with
LinkedIn and Twitter, Flickr,

517
00:29:06.510 --> 00:29:11.810
YouTube, bunch of neat options we
could do now in this day and age.

518
00:29:11.810 --> 00:29:13.860
I'm gonna go back over
to the save as here.

519
00:29:13.860 --> 00:29:16.850
Now that I know that I'm logged in, and
I can see my account right up here.

520
00:29:16.850 --> 00:29:18.840
I can verify that I'm signed in.

521
00:29:18.840 --> 00:29:24.410
Right, I can change accounts if I needed
too, and then I can choose OneDrive and

522
00:29:24.410 --> 00:29:30.013
I can come up here and I'll put it on
Mike Roderick's good old OneDrive folder,

523
00:29:30.013 --> 00:29:33.404
and I'll click save.

524
00:29:33.404 --> 00:29:36.190
It takes a little bit longer
than saving it locally, right?

525
00:29:36.190 --> 00:29:39.890
It's reaching out there to those
servers that Microsoft hosts and

526
00:29:39.890 --> 00:29:41.250
it's now out there in the cloud.

527
00:29:41.250 --> 00:29:45.490
So I can go home to my machine, or I can
take my laptop that I travel with while

528
00:29:45.490 --> 00:29:48.680
I'm working on the road or
staying at that hotel, and

529
00:29:48.680 --> 00:29:52.140
I can work with that document, and when I
save it, I put it back up in the cloud.

530
00:29:52.140 --> 00:29:53.160
I get back to work.

531
00:29:53.160 --> 00:29:58.700
I log-in into my desktop back at work and
I can access that same document with

532
00:29:58.700 --> 00:30:03.210
all those changes, so it's a lot different
than working with that local copy.

533
00:30:03.210 --> 00:30:06.062
You're working with one copy that
you can access from anywhere.

534
00:30:06.062 --> 00:30:09.580
So Microsoft makes it very easy for
us to access that cloud storage and

535
00:30:09.580 --> 00:30:11.370
save those files up there.

536
00:30:11.370 --> 00:30:15.222
>> Now Mike, when you talk about
mentioning saving it to the cloud here,

537
00:30:15.222 --> 00:30:18.813
there may be people out there that
say look, I don't trust that,

538
00:30:18.813 --> 00:30:23.013
I'd rather save it to my laptop or my
desktop and I know it will be safe there.

539
00:30:23.013 --> 00:30:24.229
Mike, why should I even consider this.

540
00:30:24.229 --> 00:30:26.630
>> Because of the convenience, right?

541
00:30:26.630 --> 00:30:29.890
Because of the face that
if I save it locally,

542
00:30:29.890 --> 00:30:33.070
I now have to, what if I want to
work with it while I'm on the road?

543
00:30:33.070 --> 00:30:34.420
Let's say this is my desktop.

544
00:30:34.420 --> 00:30:35.940
I can't take it with me.

545
00:30:35.940 --> 00:30:37.810
Well, I've got to copy that
file to a thumb drive.

546
00:30:37.810 --> 00:30:40.730
Got to take that thumb drive with me,
plug it into my laptop,

547
00:30:40.730 --> 00:30:42.910
and I can work with that document there.

548
00:30:42.910 --> 00:30:47.040
When I get back to work, I've got to
remember to plug that thumb drive back in,

549
00:30:47.040 --> 00:30:48.910
copy it back over to my local machine,

550
00:30:48.910 --> 00:30:51.470
replace the old file
with that new version.

551
00:30:51.470 --> 00:30:55.000
You end up with multiple versions and
it gets really confusing.

552
00:30:55.000 --> 00:30:58.690
When you're dealing with the Cloud, you're
always working with the same document,

553
00:30:58.690 --> 00:31:01.140
you're just accessing it
from different locations.

554
00:31:01.140 --> 00:31:03.080
It's actually stored
out there on the Cloud.

555
00:31:03.080 --> 00:31:05.620
If your hard drive fails,
you didn't lose your document.

556
00:31:05.620 --> 00:31:07.420
It's out there on the cloud, right?

557
00:31:07.420 --> 00:31:11.710
Microsoft's OneDrive, they've got
unbelievable redundancy built in, right?

558
00:31:11.710 --> 00:31:13.400
They've taken care of all of that for me.

559
00:31:13.400 --> 00:31:16.245
I don't have to worry about,
I shouldn't say this out loud.

560
00:31:16.245 --> 00:31:17.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I don't have to worry about

561
00:31:17.750 --> 00:31:21.295
backing my stuff up because
Microsoft's doing it, right?

562
00:31:21.295 --> 00:31:25.650
[LAUGH] That's probably not a good
thing to say as an IT professional, but

563
00:31:25.650 --> 00:31:27.900
when you think about it,
it's kinda true, right?

564
00:31:27.900 --> 00:31:30.250
They've got redundant hardware solutions,

565
00:31:30.250 --> 00:31:33.830
they've got ways to make sure,
they're making money off this.

566
00:31:33.830 --> 00:31:37.060
They've got to make sure that they
don't lose customer's data, or

567
00:31:37.060 --> 00:31:39.100
we're not gonna pay for it anymore.

568
00:31:39.100 --> 00:31:41.530
So they're pretty safe.

569
00:31:41.530 --> 00:31:44.820
So it's the accessibility,
the convenience that you get.

570
00:31:44.820 --> 00:31:46.400
Now if you don't have Cloud Storage,

571
00:31:46.400 --> 00:31:49.270
you don't trust Cloud storage,
I say get with the times.

572
00:31:49.270 --> 00:31:50.294
That's where we're going.

573
00:31:50.294 --> 00:31:51.520
No, I'm kidding.

574
00:31:51.520 --> 00:31:54.037
Maybe you're using local
storage on your machine, but

575
00:31:54.037 --> 00:31:55.758
maybe local storage on your network.

576
00:31:55.758 --> 00:31:58.504
That's still a very common thing to do.

577
00:31:58.504 --> 00:32:02.410
If I want to If I have a document
that many people need access to,

578
00:32:02.410 --> 00:32:05.100
I don't wanna share it out off my machine.

579
00:32:05.100 --> 00:32:08.540
We've got a folder up on our file
server on the network at work,

580
00:32:08.540 --> 00:32:09.910
that I can put things in.

581
00:32:09.910 --> 00:32:13.110
And other people can go to that folder and
access that information.

582
00:32:13.110 --> 00:32:15.920
Ronnie says, hey Mike,
you got a copy of that spreadsheet, sure,

583
00:32:15.920 --> 00:32:20.440
I'll dump it up in that share and
you can access it from there, right?

584
00:32:20.440 --> 00:32:21.440
So we need to be able to do that.

585
00:32:21.440 --> 00:32:22.140
How do you do that?

586
00:32:22.140 --> 00:32:26.790
Well, you just go back to file, save or
save as, depending if it's a new document

587
00:32:26.790 --> 00:32:31.320
or not, and then browse and
find your network location.

588
00:32:31.320 --> 00:32:35.110
You're either gonna have, depending on
your environment, you might have a mapped

589
00:32:35.110 --> 00:32:39.980
network drive or you might have
to type in a UNC path up here.

590
00:32:39.980 --> 00:32:41.653
Right, you can go \\,

591
00:32:41.653 --> 00:32:45.907
I don't know if it'll let me
browse this network, maybe not.

592
00:32:45.907 --> 00:32:49.417
>> [LAUGH]
>> So if you don't have a Map Drive,

593
00:32:49.417 --> 00:32:53.486
like a permanent pointer to that
shared folder on the network,

594
00:32:53.486 --> 00:32:55.739
then you have to know the UNC path.

595
00:32:55.739 --> 00:32:58.900
Right, \\, computer name \ share name.

596
00:32:58.900 --> 00:33:03.300
If you have it mapped, meaning it shows
up as a drive in your local machine,

597
00:33:03.300 --> 00:33:05.790
you just select it from
your list over here.

598
00:33:05.790 --> 00:33:08.400
And I can save it on that share.

599
00:33:08.400 --> 00:33:10.930
I can dump it up in there, right?

600
00:33:10.930 --> 00:33:12.230
And now I can tell Ronnie hey,

601
00:33:12.230 --> 00:33:15.230
go to that share and you'll see
that spreadsheet I'm working on.

602
00:33:15.230 --> 00:33:17.140
Maybe you can give me some pointers on it.

603
00:33:17.140 --> 00:33:22.200
So being able to save it we can save it
locally, we can save it to a UNC path.

604
00:33:22.200 --> 00:33:25.630
Or a shared folder on the network or
on another machine.

605
00:33:25.630 --> 00:33:28.050
Or we can save it out there to the cloud.

606
00:33:28.050 --> 00:33:31.700
>> Yeah, this idea of actually saving it
in another location is pretty much a key

607
00:33:31.700 --> 00:33:36.030
idea that we're going to be going to from
now, probably until the end of history.

608
00:33:36.030 --> 00:33:37.880
Because what we're finding out.

609
00:33:37.880 --> 00:33:41.400
And we found out for a long time, right,
is that even though you might depend on

610
00:33:41.400 --> 00:33:45.830
your hard drive, you shouldn't depend on
your hard drive when it comes down to it.

611
00:33:45.830 --> 00:33:49.040
Your machine is not gonna have all
those backups and those redundancies.

612
00:33:49.040 --> 00:33:53.270
Saving it to another location just ensures
that as long as you can access it,

613
00:33:53.270 --> 00:33:55.830
you have access to it and
what you need to do to it.

614
00:33:55.830 --> 00:33:59.510
And then, if you ever actually need to go
to another machine because your hard drive

615
00:33:59.510 --> 00:34:01.930
actually has died,
you're not now bringing and

616
00:34:01.930 --> 00:34:05.910
going I hope you can help me find
the file and then there it is,

617
00:34:05.910 --> 00:34:10.280
your IT person says no, we can't recover
any data off of it and it's lost.

618
00:34:10.280 --> 00:34:11.220
>> Absolutely.

619
00:34:11.220 --> 00:34:14.400
And I was working on a project for
a company here, and

620
00:34:14.400 --> 00:34:17.740
it was a very complex Excel
spreadsheet that we were working on.

621
00:34:17.740 --> 00:34:20.345
And so I was working with it locally and

622
00:34:20.345 --> 00:34:25.210
I found that I had seven different
versions of this document.

623
00:34:25.210 --> 00:34:28.120
Between working on it here
while I had a few minutes.

624
00:34:28.120 --> 00:34:32.408
Working on it at home, working on it on a
work station over in this business while I

625
00:34:32.408 --> 00:34:34.120
went over to visit them.

626
00:34:34.120 --> 00:34:37.768
It was really getting difficult to
remember what the latest version was,

627
00:34:37.768 --> 00:34:42.230
I'd go to show or my client the
spreadsheet, say check out what I've got,

628
00:34:42.230 --> 00:34:46.090
that's not the right version,
I left that on my other laptop, right.

629
00:34:46.090 --> 00:34:48.990
Put that out in the cloud and
it's all solved.

630
00:34:48.990 --> 00:34:52.079
I can just go to any machine,
connect to the cloud, grab that file, and

631
00:34:52.079 --> 00:34:55.050
I know it's the latest version,
so a really good benefit.

632
00:34:55.050 --> 00:34:56.020
It really is.

633
00:34:56.020 --> 00:34:58.560
>> Well, Mike, you've shown us
a lot here on printing and saving.

634
00:34:58.560 --> 00:35:01.052
Any last words on printing and saving?

635
00:35:01.052 --> 00:35:03.800
>> Not really,
play with some of those options in there.

636
00:35:03.800 --> 00:35:08.010
As far as the scaling goes because
there's no one size fits all,

637
00:35:08.010 --> 00:35:12.470
it depends on how many columns,
font sizes, landscape versus portrait.

638
00:35:12.470 --> 00:35:14.910
So just play with the options and
see what's going to work best for you.

639
00:35:14.910 --> 00:35:16.960
Use that print preview before you print.

640
00:35:16.960 --> 00:35:20.380
You don't want to go to the printer,
grab 20 pages and go that didn't work,

641
00:35:20.380 --> 00:35:22.090
throw it out and print it again.

642
00:35:22.090 --> 00:35:23.530
So use that print preview there.

643
00:35:24.990 --> 00:35:25.960
Trust the cloud.

644
00:35:25.960 --> 00:35:28.160
>> That's all that we have for
this episode.

645
00:35:28.160 --> 00:35:30.770
Signing off for ITProTv, I'm Ronnie Wong.

646
00:35:30.770 --> 00:35:31.610
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

647
00:35:31.610 --> 00:35:36.713
>> We'll see you next time.

648
00:35:36.713 --> 00:35:41.140
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show us how to work with inserting data into our workbooks.  Even though we can manually enter data, the data may already exist in a different workbook, or be entered incorrectly or located elsewhere in the same workbook, the guys show us how use the powerful tools in excel to help us to insert the data where it needs to be.  Mike demonstrates multiple tools such as Find and Replace, Copy and Paste, autofill and couple of others to demonstrate the power of excel when dealing with data.
episodes.title: Inserting Data
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.046 --> 00:00:15.400
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.400 --> 00:00:16.885
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.885 --> 00:00:20.296
in today's episode, we're going
to be moving along in Excel 2016.

5
00:00:20.296 --> 00:00:24.790
And today, we're going to be looking
at how to order and group your data.

6
00:00:24.790 --> 00:00:27.345
And who do we have here to help
us out with this topic today?

7
00:00:27.345 --> 00:00:28.200
Mr. Mike Roderick.

8
00:00:28.200 --> 00:00:28.890
How you doing, Mike?

9
00:00:28.890 --> 00:00:29.970
>> Doing great, Wes.

10
00:00:29.970 --> 00:00:32.510
We are all going to have
some fun with our data.

11
00:00:32.510 --> 00:00:33.390
And exactly right.

12
00:00:33.390 --> 00:00:35.620
We're gonna try to put some order and
some grouping to it.

13
00:00:35.620 --> 00:00:36.940
We're actually gonna do a lot.

14
00:00:36.940 --> 00:00:40.410
We're gonna do some pretty cool
formatting tricks as well.

15
00:00:40.410 --> 00:00:45.060
So, we're gonna start with something
called conditional formatting.

16
00:00:45.060 --> 00:00:49.536
Now in a previous episode, we've done
some formatting, we've made things bold,

17
00:00:49.536 --> 00:00:51.616
we've worked with the alignment, and

18
00:00:51.616 --> 00:00:55.671
we even changed the background color
to give it like a highlighting effect.

19
00:00:55.671 --> 00:01:00.525
But now what I want to do is I want
to apply these styles to these cells

20
00:01:00.525 --> 00:01:01.921
based on the data.

21
00:01:01.921 --> 00:01:02.670
Right?

22
00:01:02.670 --> 00:01:04.224
Conditional formatting,

23
00:01:04.224 --> 00:01:08.754
that means we're gonna format it
conditionally based on certain conditions.

24
00:01:08.754 --> 00:01:13.087
So let me show you the really
neat things that Excel can do.

25
00:01:13.087 --> 00:01:14.630
We've always been able to
do conditional formatting.

26
00:01:14.630 --> 00:01:19.387
We've been able to go in and write
rules and say, if a number was greater

27
00:01:19.387 --> 00:01:24.420
than such and such, maybe color it
a certain color, or make it bold.

28
00:01:24.420 --> 00:01:28.080
But now, with the Excel 2016,
it's not brand new to 2016,

29
00:01:28.080 --> 00:01:32.290
it was actually in 2013 as well,
we can do some pretty neat things.

30
00:01:32.290 --> 00:01:33.510
Let's take a look.

31
00:01:33.510 --> 00:01:36.010
On my screen here, I've got that
chart we've been working with.

32
00:01:36.010 --> 00:01:40.440
I say chart, this data set that we've
been working with, my monthly sales.

33
00:01:40.440 --> 00:01:42.780
And I've got months going across the top,

34
00:01:42.780 --> 00:01:46.090
I've got my categories that
we sell down across the side.

35
00:01:46.090 --> 00:01:46.837
And then some values out here.

36
00:01:46.837 --> 00:01:49.663
And as I said,
previously we did this manually.

37
00:01:49.663 --> 00:01:52.718
Right?
I colored the background of these cells

38
00:01:52.718 --> 00:01:55.820
using the cell styles and just did that.

39
00:01:55.820 --> 00:01:58.260
But it's regardless of
the data that's in there.

40
00:01:58.260 --> 00:02:02.788
I could take the number 22 there and
go ahead and make it look bad.

41
00:02:02.788 --> 00:02:05.310
Right?
So, we're just kinda doing that manually.

42
00:02:05.310 --> 00:02:08.090
>> Yeah, so one other things I was
thinking too on this one is, okay,

43
00:02:08.090 --> 00:02:09.710
you got good and bad, right?

44
00:02:09.710 --> 00:02:11.510
Red and green here.

45
00:02:11.510 --> 00:02:15.220
One of the things I'm thinking is if,
we had good sales numbers, right?

46
00:02:15.220 --> 00:02:18.653
We might wanna know that the numbers are
good just by looking at the spreadsheet or

47
00:02:18.653 --> 00:02:19.671
if the numbers are bad.

48
00:02:19.671 --> 00:02:23.636
And not have to go manually through that
process on every single cell saying yep,

49
00:02:23.636 --> 00:02:26.040
this is good, this is bad,
this is what we want.

50
00:02:26.040 --> 00:02:27.290
So is there a way that we can do that?

51
00:02:27.290 --> 00:02:28.110
>> Absolutely.

52
00:02:28.110 --> 00:02:32.340
As our data sets get larger and
larger, or if it's changing data.

53
00:02:32.340 --> 00:02:34.290
Right?
I want that formatting to change.

54
00:02:34.290 --> 00:02:36.760
What if that number changes from 0 to 15?

55
00:02:36.760 --> 00:02:38.520
I guess it wouldn't change in the past.

56
00:02:38.520 --> 00:02:44.240
But depending on what your data contains,
you might have numbers that change.

57
00:02:44.240 --> 00:02:47.780
And as those numbers change you
would want that formatting a change.

58
00:02:47.780 --> 00:02:50.730
If they brought those numbers up, then
we want to highlight them with something

59
00:02:50.730 --> 00:02:52.740
that indicates that those
numbers are now good,

60
00:02:52.740 --> 00:02:56.380
or they're above a certain bar,
whatever level we set.

61
00:02:56.380 --> 00:02:57.950
And so, let's take a look.

62
00:02:57.950 --> 00:03:00.500
The first thing I'm going to
do is I'm going to get rid of

63
00:03:00.500 --> 00:03:02.220
the formatting that we've already done.

64
00:03:02.220 --> 00:03:04.260
So, I'm going to clear my formatting.

65
00:03:05.372 --> 00:03:07.420
And I'll go ahead and
center align those guys again,

66
00:03:07.420 --> 00:03:10.760
just because I think it makes
it a little bit easier to read.

67
00:03:10.760 --> 00:03:15.430
Now I'm gonna select my data,
that's the first thing I've gotta do.

68
00:03:15.430 --> 00:03:19.290
And on my home ribbon I've got
my conditional formatting.

69
00:03:19.290 --> 00:03:23.340
And we'll click that, and it's drop down,
it's going to give me a few options.

70
00:03:23.340 --> 00:03:25.640
I've got my highlight cells rules.

71
00:03:25.640 --> 00:03:29.000
And we'll just start here, and kind of,
work our way down through a few of these.

72
00:03:29.000 --> 00:03:30.540
I won't be able to do every one of them.

73
00:03:30.540 --> 00:03:32.720
You're gonna have to
explore some of these.

74
00:03:32.720 --> 00:03:36.660
But the highlight cells, it's kind of
what I was doing manually, a minute ago.

75
00:03:36.660 --> 00:03:39.350
But let's say now,
I've got a number in mind.

76
00:03:39.350 --> 00:03:42.950
If it's over ten,
I want it to be highlighted.

77
00:03:42.950 --> 00:03:47.950
Well I can say highlight cells greater
than, and I can fill in a value and

78
00:03:47.950 --> 00:03:51.345
let's make it something where a few
more shall, we'll say over five.

79
00:03:51.345 --> 00:03:52.675
All right?
And I wanna fill it in,

80
00:03:52.675 --> 00:03:54.530
if it's over five, it's good.

81
00:03:54.530 --> 00:03:57.910
So I'm gonna change that to
green with dark green text.

82
00:03:58.970 --> 00:04:00.190
Click OK.

83
00:04:00.190 --> 00:04:00.754
And there you go.
Right?

84
00:04:00.754 --> 00:04:04.030
Now if one of these
numbers happen to change.

85
00:04:04.030 --> 00:04:06.230
This was a four so it's not highlighted.

86
00:04:06.230 --> 00:04:06.780
Now it's 11.

87
00:04:06.780 --> 00:04:08.600
And look at that.

88
00:04:08.600 --> 00:04:11.040
It automatically turns green.

89

And I've got the months as my Y axis or
going over there vertically.

323
00:15:45.310 --> 00:15:46.080
So easy to do.

324
00:15:46.080 --> 00:15:50.980
If you've got a dataset like that, it's
what they call transposing the rows and

325
00:15:50.980 --> 00:15:51.638
columns.

326
00:15:51.638 --> 00:15:56.136
And if you need to do that, simply copy
it, grab all that data, copy it and

327
00:15:56.136 --> 00:15:57.088
then paste it.

328
00:15:57.088 --> 00:16:00.018
But do a paste special and
choose the Transpose.

329
00:16:00.018 --> 00:16:01.538
And Excel will do it for you.

330
00:16:01.538 --> 00:16:03.288
And then you can delete
the one that you copied.

331
00:16:03.288 --> 00:16:06.850
Like I could go back,
if we decided this way was better.

332
00:16:06.850 --> 00:16:11.180
Well, I can go back and now delete this
once I've copied it and transposed it.

333
00:16:11.180 --> 00:16:13.940
So, very easy to do there within Excel.

334
00:16:15.350 --> 00:16:18.570
All right, so a lot of cool things
you can do with the formatting.

335
00:16:18.570 --> 00:16:21.240
The next one's gonna be
a little more complex, but

336
00:16:21.240 --> 00:16:25.430
I wanna show you how to do what we
call an outline in Excel, all right?

337
00:16:25.430 --> 00:16:30.115
And it's not quite what you think of
an outline like with a Word document or

338
00:16:30.115 --> 00:16:31.920
something like that.

339
00:16:31.920 --> 00:16:38.350
An outline in Excel gives us the ability
to group data and then collapse data up.

340
00:16:38.350 --> 00:16:42.950
And it's especially handy when you're
working with large amounts of data and

341
00:16:42.950 --> 00:16:47.350
you need to be able to look at
a summary view of the information,

342
00:16:47.350 --> 00:16:49.830
as well as see all the raw data,
all right?

343
00:16:49.830 --> 00:16:51.890
So let me flip over to
another workbook here and

344
00:16:51.890 --> 00:16:54.790
I'll show you how to do this and
what I mean.

345
00:16:54.790 --> 00:16:59.540
So on this sheet here,
if we jump down to the bottom,

346
00:16:59.540 --> 00:17:03.115
we got about 2,500 rows of data in here.

347
00:17:03.115 --> 00:17:08.660
Now, what I would like to do is I
wanna see how many dogs did we sell?

348
00:17:08.660 --> 00:17:11.560
How much money did we make
on selling dogs versus cats,

349
00:17:11.560 --> 00:17:14.170
versus fish, versus birds, et cetera?

350
00:17:14.170 --> 00:17:19.490
All the data right now is in this one big,
long list with about 2,500 rows.

351
00:17:19.490 --> 00:17:22.462
So what I'm gonna do is I'm
going to create an outline.

352
00:17:22.462 --> 00:17:26.380
I'm gonna group the data,
put some subtotals in there, and

353
00:17:26.380 --> 00:17:27.760
create an outline out of it.

354
00:17:27.760 --> 00:17:30.390
And Excel makes it
extremely easy nowadays.

355
00:17:30.390 --> 00:17:34.750
A few Office editions ago,
this was not quite as easy.

356
00:17:34.750 --> 00:17:38.020
So if you're gonna do that, the first
thing you would need to do is sort it

357
00:17:38.020 --> 00:17:40.530
by whatever you wanna group it by,
all right?

358
00:17:40.530 --> 00:17:41.880
Now, I'm gonna group it by category.

359
00:17:41.880 --> 00:17:45.210
And as we scroll down through here,
we can see it's not organized.

360
00:17:45.210 --> 00:17:48.000
Right, I've got dogs,
birds, cats, dogs, cats.

361
00:17:48.000 --> 00:17:49.180
So it's not sorted yet.

362
00:17:49.180 --> 00:17:51.880
So let's sort that by category.

363
00:17:51.880 --> 00:17:54.860
So I'm gonna do that by using my Sort and
Filter.

364
00:17:54.860 --> 00:17:56.210
And we'll do it just A to Z.

365
00:17:57.420 --> 00:18:01.540
So now as you look through here,
there's all my bird sales.

366
00:18:01.540 --> 00:18:04.100
Eventually we'll get down to,
what would be next,

367
00:18:04.100 --> 00:18:06.370
cats I guess would come after birds.

368
00:18:06.370 --> 00:18:07.290
That's a lot of scrolling.

369
00:18:07.290 --> 00:18:08.158
There's my cats.

370
00:18:08.158 --> 00:18:13.598
So at this point it is all
sorted by category, all right.

371
00:18:13.598 --> 00:18:18.110
Now, the next thing I wanna do is
I wanna insert some subtotals.

372
00:18:18.110 --> 00:18:22.720
So now I'm gonna go to my,
where are we at here, my Insert.

373
00:18:22.720 --> 00:18:26.890
I'm sorry, not my Insert, my Data ribbon,
and I'm gonna choose Subtotal.

374
00:18:26.890 --> 00:18:30.940
Now, I have to make sure
that my active cell

375
00:18:30.940 --> 00:18:35.030
is in the column that I wanna create
the subtotals based on, right?

376
00:18:35.030 --> 00:18:39.260
If it's over here, it's gonna try to
create a subtotal based on store.

377
00:18:39.260 --> 00:18:44.220
And because it's not sorted properly
Excel is gonna have a problem with that.

378
00:18:44.220 --> 00:18:48.600
So I wanna make sure I sort the column,
and then I have that column selector, or

379
00:18:48.600 --> 00:18:53.980
the active sell is in that column, and
I'm gonna click on Subtotal, all right.

380
00:18:53.980 --> 00:18:59.940
Then it's gonna say, at each change in,
and this is where you've gotta watch it,

381
00:18:59.940 --> 00:19:03.580
I selected that category, but
Excel didn't even recognize it.

382
00:19:03.580 --> 00:19:10.760
So I'm gonna make sure I tell Excel at
each change in category, all right.

383
00:19:10.760 --> 00:19:15.060
So, each time this change,
right now it's birds, once its changes,

384
00:19:15.060 --> 00:19:17.970
it changes to cats next,
that's the break point.

385
00:19:17.970 --> 00:19:19.550
That's what I'm telling Excel.

386
00:19:19.550 --> 00:19:22.840
Every time the category changes,
what do I wanna do?

387
00:19:22.840 --> 00:19:26.420
I could do a count,
maybe I just wanna see how many.

388
00:19:26.420 --> 00:19:27.610
Let's do a sum though.

389
00:19:27.610 --> 00:19:32.370
We'll say a sum, and
I wanna do a sum of the amount, right?

390
00:19:32.370 --> 00:19:34.420
That would make the most sense.

391
00:19:34.420 --> 00:19:40.558
And I'm gonna put the summary below
the data, and I'll go ahead and click OK.

392
00:19:40.558 --> 00:19:45.132
And it whirs and grinds for a second and
it doesn't really look like anything

393
00:19:45.132 --> 00:19:48.578
happened, except I've got
this extra space over here.

394
00:19:48.578 --> 00:19:54.413
And if I scroll down, and
I get back down to where that change is,

395
00:19:54.413 --> 00:20:01.110
eventually, a lot of birds we sell,
there I can see my birds total.

396
00:20:01.110 --> 00:20:04.430
And there's my total,
my subtotal for birds, right?

397
00:20:04.430 --> 00:20:06.030
And then it starts in cats.

398
00:20:06.030 --> 00:20:08.980
And so,
that's pretty cool to know of itself but

399
00:20:08.980 --> 00:20:12.260
it's these over here that
are really pretty neat, as well.

400
00:20:12.260 --> 00:20:14.360
This is the outline part, right?

401
00:20:14.360 --> 00:20:18.280
So you saw me create the groups and
create the subtotals.

402
00:20:18.280 --> 00:20:21.550
Now we wanna work with the outline and
it did it for me.

403
00:20:21.550 --> 00:20:26.170
When I inserted the subtotal, it created
the groups as well as the outline.

404
00:20:26.170 --> 00:20:28.710
What these numbers represent is the level.

405
00:20:28.710 --> 00:20:33.220
So if I click on level one,
everything is gonna collapse up, and

406
00:20:33.220 --> 00:20:35.610
look at that,
all I have is the grand total.

407
00:20:35.610 --> 00:20:38.980
Man, we make a lot of
money selling animals.

408
00:20:38.980 --> 00:20:39.690
[LAUGH] All right.

409
00:20:39.690 --> 00:20:42.650
But if I wanna see a little more detail
than that I can go to level two.

410
00:20:42.650 --> 00:20:49.060
And there's each one of my categories and
their totals.

411
00:20:49.060 --> 00:20:54.370
If I go to level three, I'm back out to
the actual data, everything's expanded.

412
00:20:54.370 --> 00:20:56.170
Or if I just wanna see
a particular category,

413
00:20:56.170 --> 00:21:00.620
I could jump back over to two,
and then expand out cats.

414
00:21:00.620 --> 00:21:02.550
And there's all the cat data.

415
00:21:02.550 --> 00:21:04.640
All the others are still collapsed.

416
00:21:04.640 --> 00:21:08.810
So these little plus and
minus signs allow me to collapse or

417
00:21:08.810 --> 00:21:11.010
expand a particular section.

418
00:21:12.640 --> 00:21:18.320
And that's what that outline allows
me to do is to really focus in on or

419
00:21:18.320 --> 00:21:22.220
create that ability to
collapse the data down,

420
00:21:22.220 --> 00:21:26.170
view those subtotals, but
then expand it out if I need to.

421
00:21:26.170 --> 00:21:30.740
A lot of times the higher ups, my boss
doesn't care about the individual sales,

422
00:21:30.740 --> 00:21:32.920
they just want to know what we're doing.

423
00:21:32.920 --> 00:21:37.590
Should we continue to sell reptiles or
dogs or cats?

424
00:21:37.590 --> 00:21:39.120
Is it worth the cost?

425
00:21:39.120 --> 00:21:41.840
They need to see these overall numbers.

426
00:21:41.840 --> 00:21:45.800
But the person ordering might
need to see what species of bird

427
00:21:45.800 --> 00:21:47.310
we sell more than others.

428
00:21:47.310 --> 00:21:51.890
So they can expand out birds and
they can see that data.

429
00:21:51.890 --> 00:21:54.760
So that's the advantage of
doing those outlines there.

430
00:21:54.760 --> 00:21:55.910
Pretty cool.

431
00:21:55.910 --> 00:21:58.660
Play around with it a little bit,

432
00:21:58.660 --> 00:22:02.610
you can do a couple different
levels of subtotals in there.

433
00:22:02.610 --> 00:22:06.400
For example,
let's see if I can get this to work, Wes.

434
00:22:06.400 --> 00:22:08.790
I try to add another subtotal.

435
00:22:08.790 --> 00:22:11.970
And I'm going to say, we also wanna do a,

436
00:22:11.970 --> 00:22:15.230
yeah it's not gonna let me
do that on this one, is it?

437
00:22:15.230 --> 00:22:19.890
So change that to account of the species,
and

438
00:22:19.890 --> 00:22:23.160
we'll click OK, and see what we get now.

439
00:22:23.160 --> 00:22:24.566
So we get down to the bottom of Birds.

440
00:22:27.708 --> 00:22:29.860
See how nicely Excel played along with me.

441
00:22:29.860 --> 00:22:36.770
And now you can see I've got my bird
count as well, as my bird total.

442
00:22:36.770 --> 00:22:37.960
And oops, I left that checked.

443
00:22:37.960 --> 00:22:43.010
You'll notice I left Count selected
on the amount column as well.

444
00:22:43.010 --> 00:22:44.770
So I need to go back in there and
fix that.

445
00:22:44.770 --> 00:22:49.674
And I can go back into my outline here,
and for the count function,

446
00:22:49.674 --> 00:22:51.786
I'm gonna uncheck amount.

447
00:22:51.786 --> 00:22:57.386
We did a sum on the species.

448
00:22:57.386 --> 00:22:59.230
Or, sorry that should
have been on the amount.

449
00:22:59.230 --> 00:23:06.488
And we did the Count on the species,
right?

450
00:23:06.488 --> 00:23:07.146
Yeah.

451
00:23:07.146 --> 00:23:11.210
And then you can also create a new
page if you wanna separate that out.

452
00:23:11.210 --> 00:23:13.200
I'm not gonna change this again,

453
00:23:13.200 --> 00:23:16.300
I don't wanna goof up my numbers
that I've already generated there.

454
00:23:16.300 --> 00:23:18.810
But you can see how I can
play around with that and

455
00:23:18.810 --> 00:23:22.540
you could add different
subtotals to those sections.

456
00:23:22.540 --> 00:23:27.730
So if I want to get a count, as well
as a sum of the value, we can do that.

457
00:23:27.730 --> 00:23:29.715
So play around those outlines,

458
00:23:29.715 --> 00:23:33.570
it gives you a great way to
collapse that information up.

459
00:23:33.570 --> 00:23:38.990
Now I can see, I go back out to
level three, and I've got the count,

460
00:23:38.990 --> 00:23:42.850
as well as the sum for
each one of those sections.

461
00:23:42.850 --> 00:23:45.810
So if that's all I need,
I can hide all that other data.

462
00:23:45.810 --> 00:23:47.332
I don't need to see all of that.

463
00:23:47.332 --> 00:23:50.420
And if I need to see it,
I can just expand it out,

464
00:23:50.420 --> 00:23:54.144
and I can see all the details
within that section.

465
00:23:54.144 --> 00:23:55.322
>> That's great information.

466
00:23:55.322 --> 00:23:58.650
And, man, I tell you what, it makes
it very handy to see the information,

467
00:23:58.650 --> 00:24:01.860
especially when you've got many,
many lines within that spreadsheet.

468
00:24:01.860 --> 00:24:05.540
So we've looked at some really cool things
today, how to apply conditional forwarding

469
00:24:05.540 --> 00:24:07.800
to your spreadsheets,
we've looked at spark lines.

470
00:24:07.800 --> 00:24:09.970
Nice to have those little graphs
at the end of that row, so

471
00:24:09.970 --> 00:24:13.060
you can really get a visualization
of what the information means,

472
00:24:13.060 --> 00:24:15.100
without having to go column by column.

473
00:24:15.100 --> 00:24:19.230
We've looked at transposing columns and
rows, rearranging those columns and rows,

474
00:24:19.230 --> 00:24:21.970
the information within them,
as well as outlines too.

475
00:24:21.970 --> 00:24:25.070
And collapsing some of the groups
that the outlines bring to us,

476
00:24:25.070 --> 00:24:26.040
make it a little bit easier.

477
00:24:26.040 --> 00:24:27.550
Mike, do you have anything else for us?

478
00:24:27.550 --> 00:24:28.970
>> Nope, I think that does it for
this one.

479
00:24:28.970 --> 00:24:31.510
>> All right then,
it looks like we're coming to the end of

480
00:24:31.510 --> 00:24:35.270
another episode here at ITProTV, so
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

481
00:24:35.270 --> 00:24:37.960
And signing on for ITPROTV,
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

482
00:24:37.960 --> 00:24:39.110
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

483
00:24:39.110 --> 00:24:40.276
>> And we'll see you next time.

484
00:24:40.276 --> 00:24:45.855
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show us how to format the data for presentation.  They show how to change fonts, numbering formats and even apply cell styles.  Using these tools and others, helps to show the data in the context we need it.  They show some of the power of the tools in excel to help provide that emphasis and the context that is needed.
episodes.title: Formatting Data
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.140 --> 00:00:10.140
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.919 --> 00:00:16.180
Welcome back to another exciting episode
here at ITProTV I'm your host Wes Bryan.

3
00:00:16.180 --> 00:00:19.780
In today's episode we're going to
be moving along in Excel 2016.

4
00:00:19.780 --> 00:00:23.750
And specifically we're going to be talking
about inserting and formatting your data.

5
00:00:23.750 --> 00:00:25.775
And who do we have here to
help us out with this topic?

6
00:00:25.775 --> 00:00:26.610
Mr. Mike Rodrick.

7
00:00:26.610 --> 00:00:27.520
How are you doing Mike?

8
00:00:27.520 --> 00:00:28.200
>> Oh doing good.

9
00:00:28.200 --> 00:00:30.790
Yeah we're always looking to
put new data in our worksheets.

10
00:00:30.790 --> 00:00:33.280
And several different
ways we can go about it.

11
00:00:33.280 --> 00:00:35.630
So let's just dive right in and
see what we can do.

12
00:00:35.630 --> 00:00:39.790
One of the most basic ways that you can
put new data into your worksheet is to

13
00:00:39.790 --> 00:00:40.940
simply type it in.

14
00:00:40.940 --> 00:00:42.660
Standard data entry.

15
00:00:42.660 --> 00:00:44.300
For example,
let's take a look at what I've got here.

16
00:00:44.300 --> 00:00:48.030
I'm going to jump down to
the bottom of my spreadsheet and

17
00:00:48.030 --> 00:00:50.290
I'm going to type in a new sale.

18
00:00:50.290 --> 00:00:52.919
I'll put my sales person's ID in there.

19
00:00:54.150 --> 00:00:57.290
And I'll put the category
of animal that they sold.

20
00:00:57.290 --> 00:01:02.860
And you'll notice that as I type,
Excel is gonna try to fill it in for me.

21
00:01:02.860 --> 00:01:06.860
It looks at the column that I'm in, it
looks at the other values in that column.

22
00:01:06.860 --> 00:01:08.040
I type the letter b,

23
00:01:08.040 --> 00:01:12.920
and it says wait, the word bird has
been used before in this column.

24
00:01:12.920 --> 00:01:15.940
Maybe that's what Mike is trying to type,
and it fills it in for me.

25
00:01:15.940 --> 00:01:20.870
And if that's what I want I simply
hit Tab and move on to the next cell.

26
00:01:20.870 --> 00:01:24.280
And I'll start typing in
the type of bird that I sold.

27
00:01:24.280 --> 00:01:27.690
I hit the letter A, and
there goes African Grey.

28
00:01:27.690 --> 00:01:31.660
If I had wanted to type in something else,
like Albatross, it's gonna let me.

29
00:01:31.660 --> 00:01:34.850
I just continue to type
whatever it is I want to type.

30
00:01:34.850 --> 00:01:39.010
But if it figures out what I wanna type,
I simply hit Tab and

31
00:01:39.010 --> 00:01:41.580
let it do the work, and
move on to the next cell.

32
00:01:41.580 --> 00:01:43.790
So we'll put in, that was down in Tampa.

33
00:01:43.790 --> 00:01:45.380
We'll make up a dollar value.

34
00:01:45.380 --> 00:01:47.500
And we'll put a date in there.

35
00:01:47.500 --> 00:01:49.361
And we'll be good to go.

36
00:01:49.361 --> 00:01:51.661
Well that's not going to work for
a date, is it Wes?

37
00:01:51.661 --> 00:01:52.681
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's back up.

38
00:01:52.681 --> 00:01:55.175
I don't think there's a day zero.

39
00:01:55.175 --> 00:01:57.679
Put our date in there and
we're good to go.

40
00:01:58.720 --> 00:02:01.290
Very good, and one of the things
that I was thinking is that's a lot

41
00:02:01.290 --> 00:02:03.310
like another technology that we have.

42
00:02:03.310 --> 00:02:06.040
And for instance if you are in PowerShell,
the integrating,

43
00:02:06.040 --> 00:02:10.830
scripting environment, when you typed
out a portion of your commandlet there,

44
00:02:10.830 --> 00:02:14.230
the IntelliSense feature helps you,
gives you a list of the other option.

45
00:02:14.230 --> 00:02:17.010
So a lot of like that now,
one of the things I did see, Mike,

46
00:02:17.010 --> 00:02:21.000
is that you still had to enter the
information cell by cell, line by line.

47
00:02:21.000 --> 00:02:22.450
Looks like it might get a little tedious.

48
00:02:22.450 --> 00:02:24.470
Now what if you have a lot of information.

49
00:02:24.470 --> 00:02:27.850
Obviously we won't want carpel tunnel or
tendonitis by doing data entry.

50
00:02:27.850 --> 00:02:30.920
Is there a way to get that information
into that spreadsheet a little bit easier?

51
00:02:30.920 --> 00:02:32.780
>> There is.
It really depends on what format you

52
00:02:32.780 --> 00:02:33.280
get it in.

53
00:02:33.280 --> 00:02:37.836
If it's comes to you on a piece of paper,
you're probably stuck typing that data in.

54
00:02:37.836 --> 00:02:42.050
But if it's in some on electronic format,
may be we can just copy it and

55
00:02:42.050 --> 00:02:44.560
paste it in there or
append it to our worksheet.

56
00:02:44.560 --> 00:02:48.318
For example,
let me open up a another spreadsheet here.

57
00:02:48.318 --> 00:02:50.779
And you can see I've got
some similar data right?

58
00:02:50.779 --> 00:02:53.422
This is the month of April, I believe,

59
00:02:53.422 --> 00:02:59.110
their sales I'm simply gonna select the
data that I want, and I'm gonna copy it.

60
00:02:59.110 --> 00:03:02.690
I'll click Copy up there
on my home ribbon.

61
00:03:02.690 --> 00:03:08.085
I'll jump back over to that other
workbook, select where I wanna paste it,

62
00:03:08.085 --> 00:03:12.720
right-click, and paste that
information in there and there we go.

63
00:03:12.720 --> 00:03:15.690
I have just inserted in a few new rows

64
00:03:15.690 --> 00:03:18.940
without having to type
all that information in.

65
00:03:18.940 --> 00:03:20.349
You can also import data.

66
00:03:20.349 --> 00:03:21.778
We're going to save importing for

67
00:03:21.778 --> 00:03:24.150
another episode because
there's a little more detail.

68
00:03:24.150 --> 00:03:27.960
We have to worry about the format that

69
00:03:27.960 --> 00:03:31.520
is going to make a difference on
