70
00:03:31.520 --> 00:03:35.210
A lot of times we have multiple
worksheets, we just need to combine

71
00:03:35.210 --> 00:03:39.980
the information, simply copy it from one
worksheet and paste it to the other.

72
00:03:39.980 --> 00:03:44.360
Now when you go and paste that information
we've got a couple of choices.

73
00:03:44.360 --> 00:03:46.410
For example, let me jump back
over to this other workbook,

74
00:03:46.410 --> 00:03:47.880
I'm gonna copy some more data.

75
00:03:48.970 --> 00:03:51.820
I'm going to select all of this and
right-click and Copy.

76
00:03:52.980 --> 00:03:55.900
Now I'm going to go paste
it into that first workbook

77
00:03:55.900 --> 00:03:57.060
at the end of that worksheet.

78
00:03:59.660 --> 00:04:04.158
When I paste it, if I just simply paste
it, it's going to look awfully funny

79
00:04:04.158 --> 00:04:08.097
because it keeps that source formatting,
which had those blue and

80
00:04:08.097 --> 00:04:11.500
white bars on there to make it
a little bit easier to read.

81
00:04:11.500 --> 00:04:14.230
So instead of simply pasting it in there,

82
00:04:14.230 --> 00:04:18.950
what I need to do is be a little
more specific with my paste options.

83
00:04:18.950 --> 00:04:22.810
That's the standard paste, but
we have several paste options.

84
00:04:22.810 --> 00:04:25.552
And then here you might, if you've
never looked at this you're like,

85
00:04:25.552 --> 00:04:28.080
wait a second there's 15 different
ways I can paste things in.

86
00:04:28.080 --> 00:04:31.510
Well not quite 15, but
about ten ways I can paste data.

87
00:04:31.510 --> 00:04:35.180
One of the ways is to paste values, right?

88
00:04:35.180 --> 00:04:38.840
If I paste values,
it's gonna ignore the source formatting.

89
00:04:38.840 --> 00:04:42.797
It's just gonna paste the data itself,
and that way it will pick up

90
00:04:42.797 --> 00:04:46.980
whatever formatting exists in
the worksheet that I'm pasting it to.

91
00:04:46.980 --> 00:04:49.882
Now it's gonna look more like
the rest of my data, and

92
00:04:49.882 --> 00:04:54.203
I don't have to try to undo or clear all
of that formatting that came when I copied

93
00:04:54.203 --> 00:04:55.900
it from that first worksheet.

94
00:04:55.900 --> 00:04:58.830
So play around with those options,
sometimes you do wanna paste

95
00:04:58.830 --> 00:05:01.250
the formatting, so
you just do your normal paste.

96
00:05:01.250 --> 00:05:03.910
Other times you just
wanna paste that data and

97
00:05:03.910 --> 00:05:06.110
you can choose that in your paste options.

98
00:05:06.110 --> 00:05:08.720
>> Great, so you saved us on
our doctor's bill for sure.

99
00:05:08.720 --> 00:05:09.334
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

100
00:05:09.334 --> 00:05:10.734
>> Our risk will last a little bit longer.

101
00:05:10.734 --> 00:05:15.294
Now, with that, being able to import that
information, it does make it very handy.

102
00:05:15.294 --> 00:05:19.184
Do we have any other features that might
be in Excel that'll help us add data

103
00:05:19.184 --> 00:05:21.630
without going cell by cell, line by line?

104
00:05:21.630 --> 00:05:24.240
>> There are.
There's one that I particularly like is

105
00:05:24.240 --> 00:05:26.160
known as the auto-fill.

106
00:05:26.160 --> 00:05:29.300
And let me find another workbook
that we can play around with here.

107
00:05:29.300 --> 00:05:32.250
I'm gonna jump over to the Summary tab.

108
00:05:32.250 --> 00:05:36.810
And I've started a little data
area where I'm gonna keep track of

109
00:05:36.810 --> 00:05:40.480
the different categories of
animals on a monthly basis.

110
00:05:40.480 --> 00:05:42.960
I wanna look at the total sales.

111
00:05:42.960 --> 00:05:46.270
And so I need to put out the names
of my months across here.

112
00:05:46.270 --> 00:05:47.490
And you can see I started.

113
00:05:47.490 --> 00:05:49.830
I typed in January, February, March.

114
00:05:49.830 --> 00:05:51.920
And I could keep going, but guess what?

115
00:05:51.920 --> 00:05:53.980
Excel can do it for me.

116
00:05:53.980 --> 00:05:57.850
When I select the cell March,
you can see that green bounding box.

117
00:05:57.850 --> 00:06:02.620
In the bottom right hand corner, there's a
little green box, and if I hover over it,

118
00:06:02.620 --> 00:06:05.660
my cursor turns to a black crosshair.

119
00:06:05.660 --> 00:06:10.110
If I click and hold while I have
that cross hair I'm grabbing on,

120
00:06:10.110 --> 00:06:11.940
on that little box there.

121
00:06:11.940 --> 00:06:16.930
Now as I drag if you can see the tool
tip it's telling me that is gonna

122
00:06:16.930 --> 00:06:20.730
fill in the rest of these months,
and once I get to December,

123
00:06:20.730 --> 00:06:24.770
I simply let go my mouse and
fills it all for me.

124
00:06:24.770 --> 00:06:27.179
So I didn't have to go about
typing that information in.

125
00:06:27.179 --> 00:06:32.849
It's fantastic and Excel is pretty smart,
it can pick up certain, there's words

126
00:06:32.849 --> 00:06:37.720
that it can pick up and it can detect
the pattern on it as well as numbers.

127
00:06:37.720 --> 00:06:41.620
And let's grab another worksheet,
I'll show you a couple of examples.

128
00:06:41.620 --> 00:06:45.327
You saw with months,
I could do that, what if I did just,

129
00:06:45.327 --> 00:06:49.038
if I wanna do the abbreviation
instead of the full month,

130
00:06:49.038 --> 00:06:53.120
it'll recognize that as
well by drag that on over.

131
00:06:53.120 --> 00:06:56.880
We can see it does,
just that three letter abbreviation and

132
00:06:56.880 --> 00:07:02.020
it will work vertically as well as
horizontally so, I go either way.

133
00:07:03.060 --> 00:07:07.730
If I do the day of the week,
let's put in here Sunday, right.

134
00:07:07.730 --> 00:07:09.859
Well, if I do a series fill on that.

135
00:07:11.580 --> 00:07:14.370
You see it picks it up,
Sunday through Saturday,

136
00:07:14.370 --> 00:07:18.620
and if I go further than Saturday
it simply starts over and

137
00:07:18.620 --> 00:07:21.530
continues on with Sunday,
Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday.

138
00:07:21.530 --> 00:07:26.200
So do the days of the week, it just has
to be something that Excel recognizes.

139
00:07:26.200 --> 00:07:30.112
Like if I do Snickers,
everybody's favorite candy bar,

140
00:07:30.112 --> 00:07:35.040
all right if I try to do a series
fill I'm gonna get Butterfinger,

141
00:07:35.040 --> 00:07:37.100
and Milky Way and things like that right?

142
00:07:37.100 --> 00:07:42.755
It doesn't recognize that, so it has
to be something that Excel understands.

143
00:07:42.755 --> 00:07:44.225
But it's pretty bright.

144
00:07:44.225 --> 00:07:45.461
What if I put QTR.

145
00:07:45.461 --> 00:07:47.337
Oops if I could type here.

146
00:07:47.337 --> 00:07:50.087
QTR1.

147
00:07:50.087 --> 00:07:52.380
Well if I grab that and drag it.

148
00:07:52.380 --> 00:07:59.330
It's going to see that its talking about
quarters and its goes quarter 1, 2, 3, 4.

149
00:07:59.330 --> 00:08:02.895
It knows there is only four quarters,
so it doesn't go quarter 5.

150
00:08:02.895 --> 00:08:04.900
It starts over with quarter 1.

151
00:08:04.900 --> 00:08:07.420
>> Now what if I'm, I'm thinking,
what if I'm a bookie?

152
00:08:07.420 --> 00:08:09.080
And I'm going to be dealing
with a lot of numbers here.

153
00:08:09.080 --> 00:08:10.170
Could it do the same thing?

154
00:08:10.170 --> 00:08:13.450
Is it intelligent enough to do
the same thing across those cells with

155
00:08:13.450 --> 00:08:14.020
numbers as well?

156
00:08:14.020 --> 00:08:15.670
>> It does work pretty good with numbers.

157
00:08:15.670 --> 00:08:17.790
You have to do it just
a little bit differently,

158
00:08:17.790 --> 00:08:22.730
because if I type in one number, and
I try to do a series fill, well,

159
00:08:22.730 --> 00:08:25.300
it's just gonna end up copying that down,
right?

160
00:08:25.300 --> 00:08:28.840
Because it says all right, the number 10,
you wanna do that several times?

161
00:08:28.840 --> 00:08:30.440
Fine, I can do that.

162
00:08:30.440 --> 00:08:34.520
The trick with numbers is to
select more than one cell

163
00:08:34.520 --> 00:08:36.580
when you're doing a series fill.

164
00:08:36.580 --> 00:08:38.510
And what it'll do is it'll
look at the increment,

165
00:08:38.510 --> 00:08:42.480
the difference between the numbers,
and it will repeat that increment.

166
00:08:42.480 --> 00:08:48.800
So if I do 1 and 2, grab both of those
cells, so highlight both of them.

167
00:08:48.800 --> 00:08:51.010
Now grab that series fill and
drag it down,

168
00:08:51.010 --> 00:08:54.850
you'll see that it will end
up incrementing that number.

169
00:08:54.850 --> 00:09:00.470
And if I do a different increment, if I
do 5 and 10, well it'll figure that out.

170
00:09:00.470 --> 00:09:04.930
It'll go okay, you wanna count by fives,
I can do that for you as well.

171
00:09:04.930 --> 00:09:06.200
It'll also go backwards.

172
00:09:06.200 --> 00:09:08.780
If we do 100 and 95,

173
00:09:08.780 --> 00:09:14.720
then we can grab both of those cells so
they can see the difference

174
00:09:14.720 --> 00:09:18.040
between the two numbers, and
it'll take care of that for me as well.

175
00:09:18.040 --> 00:09:22.470
It'll go negatives, and
these will all work horizontally as well.

176
00:09:22.470 --> 00:09:27.700
If I was gonna put,
let's see, 90 here, I can

177
00:09:27.700 --> 00:09:32.760
simply grab both of those cells, so that
it can see the difference between the two.

178
00:09:32.760 --> 00:09:37.190
And as I go,
it'll keep that same increment.

179
00:09:37.190 --> 00:09:41.040
Now, there might be times when you
do wanna copy those numbers and

180
00:09:41.040 --> 00:09:43.290
you don't want it to do a series fill.

181
00:09:43.290 --> 00:09:45.369
Let me clean this up
just a little bit here.

182
00:09:46.690 --> 00:09:47.340
All right?

183
00:09:47.340 --> 00:09:50.620
Let's say I've got some numbers like 10,
5,

184
00:09:50.620 --> 00:09:53.940
but I just wanted to, and
let's do a couple more here.

185
00:09:53.940 --> 00:09:55.490
We'll do 15, something like that.

186
00:09:55.490 --> 00:10:00.300
I don't want it to do a series fill,
I need to repeat those numbers.

187
00:10:00.300 --> 00:10:03.710
If I drag down it's gonna
see that difference, and

188
00:10:03.710 --> 00:10:05.890
it's gonna increment it as it goes.

189
00:10:05.890 --> 00:10:08.590
I can simply click on
the tooltip that pops up and

190
00:10:08.590 --> 00:10:13.790
choose copy cells instead and
now it will copy those cells.

191
00:10:13.790 --> 00:10:19.019
The same thing with text like
if I was doing January, and

192
00:10:19.019 --> 00:10:22.916
for some reason I needed
the word January several times,

193
00:10:22.916 --> 00:10:27.450
well if I do a series fill it's
gonna try to do each month for me.

194
00:10:27.450 --> 00:10:32.230
I change that over to copy, and now it's
just gonna simply copy those cells, so

195
00:10:32.230 --> 00:10:34.090
it's a pretty smart feature.

196
00:10:34.090 --> 00:10:36.460
Definitely something you
should take advantage of.

197
00:10:36.460 --> 00:10:40.810
It's a big time saver, typically when
you're first setting up that spreadsheet.

198
00:10:40.810 --> 00:10:43.330
Now I've gotta put all
the months across the top.

199
00:10:43.330 --> 00:10:44.700
It works with dates.

200
00:10:44.700 --> 00:10:51.810
For example, if we wanted to do 1/1/2015.

201
00:10:51.810 --> 00:10:58.310
I can go and grab that and drag it down,
and it'll start filling in those dates.

202
00:10:58.310 --> 00:11:03.720
And it's smart enough to know that
there's 31 days in January so

203
00:11:03.720 --> 00:11:06.640
at the end of that,
it starts out with February.

204
00:11:06.640 --> 00:11:12.570
And it knows February only has 28 days
this year, so it goes into March.

205
00:11:12.570 --> 00:11:15.830
And it'll follow whatever
format you choose to use.

206
00:11:15.830 --> 00:11:19.030
If you were doing a shorter
version date like 1/1/15,

207
00:11:19.030 --> 00:11:23.470
in this case it wants to change
it because of my format up here.

208
00:11:23.470 --> 00:11:26.830
But if we did,
let's change that to a long date, right?

209
00:11:26.830 --> 00:11:28.230
I can do the long date as well.

210
00:11:29.880 --> 00:11:32.610
All right, we'll make that
a little wider so we can see that.

211
00:11:32.610 --> 00:11:37.800
So that can be a huge time saver when
you're setting up these worksheets.

212
00:11:37.800 --> 00:11:41.560
Take advantage of that series autofill.

213
00:11:41.560 --> 00:11:44.390
And as I said, it works across columns.

214
00:11:44.390 --> 00:11:49.218
The only thing you want to keep in mind
is, if there's no detectable pattern,

215
00:11:49.218 --> 00:11:53.986
like 22, 16, 22, well, it's not
going to know what to do with that.

216
00:11:53.986 --> 00:11:57.370
So you're gonna get kind
of some strange results.

217
00:11:57.370 --> 00:12:02.460
In this case, it just copied the number
20, not sure how it figured that out.

218
00:12:02.460 --> 00:12:03.864
Let's do with some of this other ones.

219
00:12:03.864 --> 00:12:07.418
We'll end up getting some fractions
of numbers because it sees

220
00:12:07.418 --> 00:12:12.660
that this one didn't have any increment,
and this one incremented down by one.

221
00:12:12.660 --> 00:12:14.170
It just can't figure out what to do.

222
00:12:14.170 --> 00:12:19.190
So if there's no detectable pattern,
Excel tries to do the best that it can.

223
00:12:19.190 --> 00:12:22.200
And again, if you just wanna
copy the data, just go ahead and

224
00:12:22.200 --> 00:12:27.560
do your series fill, and then change
it to copy and you're good to go.

225
00:12:27.560 --> 00:12:30.420
So you can really fill
out some information fast

226
00:12:30.420 --> 00:12:32.470
taking advantage of that series autofill.

227
00:12:32.470 --> 00:12:33.870
>> That's great, good things.

228
00:12:33.870 --> 00:12:36.734
Now, I have to be honest with you Mike
this looks like a worksheet that I

229
00:12:36.734 --> 00:12:39.110
might have done because it
looks kinda bland, right?

230
00:12:39.110 --> 00:12:42.610
You don't want me doing any
spreadsheets for you at all.

231
00:12:42.610 --> 00:12:45.130
So one of the things that I
wanted to do in the past,

232
00:12:45.130 --> 00:12:47.190
maybe I wanna name the worksheet inside.

233
00:12:47.190 --> 00:12:48.820
Or I keep say worksheet, spreadsheet.

234
00:12:48.820 --> 00:12:50.290
I wanna name it inside, right?

235
00:12:50.290 --> 00:12:52.500
Well is there a way that
you can bring that out?

236
00:12:52.500 --> 00:12:56.730
Make that one cell stand out a little
bit better, make it easier, and

237
00:12:56.730 --> 00:12:59.600
maybe so it's not just the defaults.

238
00:12:59.600 --> 00:13:00.130
>> Absolutely.

239
00:13:00.130 --> 00:13:03.790
Let me find another worksheet
here I think that I started up.

240
00:13:03.790 --> 00:13:04.770
Where did it go?

241
00:13:05.870 --> 00:13:08.590
Take a look at sales.

242
00:13:08.590 --> 00:13:10.650
And let's look at sales 2015.

243
00:13:10.650 --> 00:13:11.511
Here we go.

244
00:13:13.160 --> 00:13:15.570
I think this one will work for us.

245
00:13:15.570 --> 00:13:17.690
Well, we'll just go back into
this one that we're using here.

246
00:13:17.690 --> 00:13:21.630
Yeah, for example, you might want to put,
what is this information,

247
00:13:21.630 --> 00:13:22.990
what does it represent.

248
00:13:22.990 --> 00:13:25.600
Let's say it's monthly sales.

249
00:13:25.600 --> 00:13:30.410
So I can come up here and
I can type in Monthly Sales.

250
00:13:32.460 --> 00:13:33.690
And we'll increase that file.

251
00:13:33.690 --> 00:13:36.500
Looks like it already did a good
job of increasing it for me.

252
00:13:36.500 --> 00:13:40.510
We'll bump that up to 20 make
that row a little bit taller.

253
00:13:40.510 --> 00:13:44.230
But what you'll notice, and
a couple of things we need to understand

254
00:13:44.230 --> 00:13:48.740
the way Excel works with numbers and
the way Excel works with text.

255
00:13:48.740 --> 00:13:49.270
All right.

256
00:13:49.270 --> 00:13:52.150
When you type in text as you can see,

257
00:13:52.150 --> 00:13:54.410
well we'll do it down here so
you can see it a little bit better.

258
00:13:54.410 --> 00:13:57.620
I put in Monthly Sales.

259
00:13:59.040 --> 00:14:00.820
Well, or Monthly Sales Figures.

260
00:14:00.820 --> 00:14:01.965
How about that.

261
00:14:01.965 --> 00:14:06.330
You notice that text
doesn't fit in this cell.

262
00:14:06.330 --> 00:14:06.970
Right.

263
00:14:06.970 --> 00:14:10.560
But Excel says well there's
nothing in the cell next to it.

264
00:14:10.560 --> 00:14:12.470
So I'm go ahead and show that information.

265
00:14:12.470 --> 00:14:16.420
I can just let it flow right out of
that cell and on into the next one.

266
00:14:16.420 --> 00:14:18.850
Now, technically it's not
in the next cell, right?

267
00:14:18.850 --> 00:14:21.040
The next cell is still blank.

268
00:14:21.040 --> 00:14:24.640
All that data exist in
this cell right here.

269
00:14:24.640 --> 00:14:29.670
If I go and type in something into
this cell, well now, I can no longer

270
00:14:29.670 --> 00:14:34.360
let this one overlap into the next one,
cuz it'll cover this one up, right?

271
00:14:34.360 --> 00:14:39.350
So, as long as there's nothing next to it,
it will let it overlap the cell.

272
00:14:39.350 --> 00:14:43.670
But as soon as something is
inserted into the next cell,

273
00:14:43.670 --> 00:14:46.760
it can't do that any more and
it will chop it off.

274
00:14:46.760 --> 00:14:52.410
If you need this to show up,
you could make this column wider, but

275
00:14:52.410 --> 00:14:55.950
that might goof up the rest of
the way your spreadsheet works out.

276
00:14:55.950 --> 00:15:00.490
So you don't want to change the width
of that column just to support this.

277
00:15:00.490 --> 00:15:03.290
So what you could do is
wrap the text instead.

278
00:15:04.400 --> 00:15:08.360
It's kinda like a word processor
where if it won't fit,

279
00:15:08.360 --> 00:15:12.020
you get to the end of the line, it just
does an automatic carriage return and

280
00:15:12.020 --> 00:15:13.350
moves down to the next line.

281
00:15:13.350 --> 00:15:16.950
So notice now it does fit
in that column width.

282
00:15:16.950 --> 00:15:19.010
It just takes up a little more height.

283
00:15:19.010 --> 00:15:20.980
It made that row a little taller.

284
00:15:20.980 --> 00:15:23.790
To wrap that information over there,
all right?

285
00:15:23.790 --> 00:15:25.490
So that's the way it deals with text.

286
00:15:25.490 --> 00:15:29.230
It'll let it flow into over the next
cell unless there's something there,

287
00:15:29.230 --> 00:15:32.330
and then it'll just chop it off,
all right?

288
00:15:32.330 --> 00:15:37.250
With numbers, and text, by the way,
is left aligned by default.

289
00:15:37.250 --> 00:15:40.500
I'm gonna go back to this point here,
all right?

290
00:15:40.500 --> 00:15:41.660
As we type in text.

291
00:15:41.660 --> 00:15:48.547
Let's see, Hello World, all right,
notice it's all left aligned.

292
00:15:48.547 --> 00:15:53.171
In other words, it's bumped up over
to the left side of that cell.

293
00:15:53.171 --> 00:15:56.962
Numbers are going to be
right aligned by default.

294
00:15:56.962 --> 00:15:57.629
All right.

295
00:15:57.629 --> 00:16:02.100
So as I type in numbers here notice they
all jump to the right side of the cell.

296
00:16:02.100 --> 00:16:09.510
Now if you have a number that doesn't fit
in a cell, notice it does not overlap it.

297
00:16:11.090 --> 00:16:12.490
It will not let it flow out.

298
00:16:12.490 --> 00:16:16.760
It actually changes it to
this scientific notation.

299
00:16:16.760 --> 00:16:21.520
Excel will not let numbers lay
over onto other cells, and

300
00:16:21.520 --> 00:16:25.630
it won't simply chop it off and
not show you the rest of the number,

301
00:16:25.630 --> 00:16:28.400
because we can get ourselves
in trouble with that.

302
00:16:28.400 --> 00:16:32.570
What if you had a column that was
showing how much the customer owed, and

303
00:16:32.570 --> 00:16:37.580
they owed you a $100,000, but
it didn't fit, so it just chopped off

304
00:16:37.580 --> 00:16:42.550
the last couple of zeroes, and
now they only owed you a $1,000.

305
00:16:42.550 --> 00:16:47.200
It's not gonna take that chance and
hide numbers from you.

306
00:16:47.200 --> 00:16:50.010
So it will change the notation
of that scientific notation.

307
00:16:50.010 --> 00:16:52.250
Notice the scientific
notation wouldn't even fit,

308
00:16:52.250 --> 00:16:54.720
and it forced the column to get wider.

309
00:16:54.720 --> 00:16:56.590
If I start dragging this in and
saying, no,

310
00:16:56.590 --> 00:17:00.250
Excel, I don't want you to make that
column wider, it changes my notation.

311
00:17:00.250 --> 00:17:03.010
It drops down the number of
decimals it's showing me.

312
00:17:03.010 --> 00:17:05.730
But it's still representing
the entire number,

313
00:17:05.730 --> 00:17:08.230
it's using that scientific notation.

314
00:17:08.230 --> 00:17:12.260
So its left a line by default for
text, and

315
00:17:12.260 --> 00:17:15.830
it won't let it overlap into another cell.

316
00:17:15.830 --> 00:17:20.470
Now if we want to, let's go back up and
look at what Wes was

317
00:17:20.470 --> 00:17:25.370
talking about earlier, and we've got the
title for this little area of my chart.

318
00:17:25.370 --> 00:17:26.180
And I was trying to find.

319
00:17:26.180 --> 00:17:29.270
I had another one that
might look even better.

320
00:17:29.270 --> 00:17:30.710
Let's see what I did with that.

321
00:17:30.710 --> 00:17:35.430
That was,well,
this one we'll make this one work here.

322
00:17:36.590 --> 00:17:40.050
We can try type this in, but,

323
00:17:40.050 --> 00:17:42.780
again, it's going to overlap
over these next cells, and

324
00:17:42.780 --> 00:17:47.490
everything gets put into these cells is
all of the sudden gonna get chopped off.

325
00:17:47.490 --> 00:17:52.690
So what I can do instead is I
can merge some cells together.

326
00:17:52.690 --> 00:17:55.040
We can combine cells into one and

327
00:17:55.040 --> 00:17:59.060
then center the data within
that combination of cells.

328
00:17:59.060 --> 00:18:03.380
For example, what if I just take this
whole thing here all the way from

329
00:18:03.380 --> 00:18:07.860
end to end of my data set and
then I can choose merge and center.

330
00:18:09.390 --> 00:18:11.580
Now this is one big cell.

331
00:18:11.580 --> 00:18:17.690
You can see this whole thing is one cell
and the text is centered within there.

332
00:18:17.690 --> 00:18:22.560
And no matter how, if I change
these column widths inside here,

333
00:18:22.560 --> 00:18:28.250
it's not going to affect, and I just
completely hid December or November there.

334
00:18:28.250 --> 00:18:29.030
Let me bring that back.

335
00:18:29.030 --> 00:18:33.540
All right, oh, little missed click.

336
00:18:33.540 --> 00:18:35.560
Sorry, just do an unhide there.

337
00:18:35.560 --> 00:18:40.515
And so as I move these things around,
that monthly sales is going to stay

338
00:18:40.515 --> 00:18:45.420
centered over that area,
that merge section.

339
00:18:45.420 --> 00:18:50.080
If I change my mind, I can click merge and
center again, it'll undo that and

340
00:18:50.080 --> 00:18:52.480
put it back into a single cell.

341
00:18:52.480 --> 00:18:55.940
I love that merge and center, I've seen
a lot of people try to do something like

342
00:18:55.940 --> 00:19:00.670
this, put spaces out in front of their

343
00:19:00.670 --> 00:19:05.220
text to try to get it to be centered over
what they're trying to center it over.

344
00:19:05.220 --> 00:19:06.420
Don't do that.

345
00:19:06.420 --> 00:19:08.440
Don't use these extra spaces here.

346
00:19:08.440 --> 00:19:10.150
That's a little clunky.

347
00:19:10.150 --> 00:19:14.840
What you really want to do is just grab
those cells and then do a merge and

348
00:19:14.840 --> 00:19:19.290
center, that way it is gonna remain
center no matter what else happens.

349
00:19:20.510 --> 00:19:25.170
As far as other things we can do to
make this pretty, we can change fonts.

350
00:19:25.170 --> 00:19:29.840
Like let's say the months don't really
stand out from the rest of my data.

351
00:19:29.840 --> 00:19:32.580
So maybe we wanna make
these a little bit bigger.

352
00:19:32.580 --> 00:19:38.170
We'll change that, we'll give it a 14 and
maybe we'll make it bold.

353
00:19:38.170 --> 00:19:38.680
I like that.

354
00:19:38.680 --> 00:19:39.860
All right.

355
00:19:39.860 --> 00:19:41.550
So, now, it really stands out.

356
00:19:41.550 --> 00:19:43.560
But what about the rest of my months?

357
00:19:43.560 --> 00:19:46.650
Now, I have to go and do those as well.

358
00:19:46.650 --> 00:19:49.780
No, we've got something
known as the Format Painter.

359
00:19:49.780 --> 00:19:53.210
That's this little paintbrush

360
00:19:53.210 --> 00:19:56.620
Select the cell that you
like the formatting of,

361
00:19:56.620 --> 00:19:59.450
click on the format painter, and

362
00:19:59.450 --> 00:20:02.650
then click the cell you want to copy
that formatting to, and there you go.

363
00:20:02.650 --> 00:20:06.430
Now that one is exactly the same,
and I didn't have to do any work.

364
00:20:06.430 --> 00:20:10.070
You could also click and
drag if you wanted to do more than one.

365
00:20:10.070 --> 00:20:15.110
I'm gonna select the cell that I like,
click my format painter brush, and

366
00:20:15.110 --> 00:20:20.170
then click and
drag across the rest of them.

367
00:20:20.170 --> 00:20:24.500
And now, we've got all of our
month's stand out a little bit.

368
00:20:24.500 --> 00:20:25.830
We saw this the other day,

369
00:20:25.830 --> 00:20:31.072
if I wanna make those columns fit
a little better, we can do that autofit.

370
00:20:31.072 --> 00:20:32.196
Oof.

371
00:20:32.196 --> 00:20:34.360
Oh, and
it was because of my text down here.

00:20:34.360 --> 00:20:37.400
Let's get rid of that there and
try that one more time.

373
00:20:37.400 --> 00:20:38.670
We can do our auto fit.

374
00:20:40.510 --> 00:20:44.710
But now you see those little months have
little columns, the bigger the month they

375
00:20:44.710 --> 00:20:49.950
names are a little bit longer, so
it depends on what you're trying to do.

376
00:20:49.950 --> 00:20:51.540
Let's set that a little bit better.

377
00:20:51.540 --> 00:20:56.860
Let's just change all of those guys
at once to something around 12,

378
00:20:56.860 --> 00:21:01.590
and now we should look
a little bit better.

379
00:21:02.800 --> 00:21:04.320
Still just a wee big.

380
00:21:04.320 --> 00:21:07.240
Let's drop that down just a hair.

381
00:21:07.240 --> 00:21:09.220
Sorry, I get a little OCD with this.

382
00:21:09.220 --> 00:21:13.800
We're going to change that column width
one more time to something like ten.

383
00:21:13.800 --> 00:21:16.480
And we'll see how that
fits a little bit better.

384
00:21:18.740 --> 00:21:19.990
All right, now that Format Painter,

385
00:21:19.990 --> 00:21:23.560
you notice when I used it if I
click once on the cell that I like,

386
00:21:23.560 --> 00:21:28.150
I click the Format Painter, I get a little
brush attached to my cursor there.

387
00:21:28.150 --> 00:21:33.350
And now if I apply that
formatting somewhere, if I click,

388
00:21:33.350 --> 00:21:35.080
the brush goes away.

389
00:21:35.080 --> 00:21:38.710
If you need that brush to stay so
that you can do more than one place

390
00:21:38.710 --> 00:21:43.410
you can select the format you like,
double click on the Format Painter.

391
00:21:43.410 --> 00:21:48.230
I still get the brush icon but
now I can click on the cell here.

392
00:21:48.230 --> 00:21:51.304
I can go and drag down these guys,
I can click on this cell here,

393
00:21:51.304 --> 00:21:53.520
notice the brush is not going away.

394
00:21:53.520 --> 00:21:56.940
Until I click the Format Painter again,
that brush will remain.

395
00:21:56.940 --> 00:22:02.620
So if you need to apply formatting, but
the cells aren't right next to each other

396
00:22:02.620 --> 00:22:06.500
so you can't simply just click and drag,
just double-click on that Format Painter.

397
00:22:06.500 --> 00:22:09.000
And it kinda locks it in the on position.

398
00:22:09.000 --> 00:22:12.150
It's like doing a caps lock for
the format painter.

399
00:22:12.150 --> 00:22:16.640
Now everything you click on,
that formatting will be applied.

400
00:22:16.640 --> 00:22:18.580
Now other things we can do,

00:22:18.580 --> 00:22:22.320
we can adjust the alignment

00:22:22.320 --> 00:22:26.160
I said that numbers are left aligned,
and you can see these numbers here

00:22:26.160 --> 00:22:29.690

hand side of the column.

404
00:22:30.800 --> 00:22:32.630
Well I wanna center them.

00:22:32.630 --> 00:22:33.940
Let's make it look a little bit better.

00:22:33.940 --> 00:22:38.600
I'm just gonna select all those

00:22:38.600 --> 00:22:40.200
And now it looks a little bit better.

00:22:40.200 --> 00:22:41.510
Maybe I wanna do the titles,

00:22:41.510 --> 00:22:46.520
that looks like they might benefit

00:22:46.520 --> 00:22:47.590
All right.
There we go.

00:22:47.590 --> 00:22:50.180
Now, we're starting to

00:22:50.180 --> 00:22:53.540
Now, this needs to be bold and

00:22:53.540 --> 00:22:54.170
Let's do that.

00:22:54.170 --> 00:22:57.310
Oh now we're starting to
look a little bit better.

415
00:22:57.310 --> 00:22:58.880
This is something more like

00:22:58.880 --> 00:22:59.820
>> Yeah, a little bit better.

00:22:59.820 --> 00:23:02.950
It doesn't look quite as plain as

00:23:02.950 --> 00:23:08.245
Now, what if there's maybe a cell that I

00:23:08.245 --> 00:23:09.915
a lot of information inside of there.

00:23:09.915 --> 00:23:13.225
Is there a way we can do that rather than

00:23:13.225 --> 00:23:14.465

422
00:23:14.465 --> 00:23:17.655
>> Absolutely,
we can do some cell styles and

423
00:23:17.655 --> 00:23:20.805
they give us the ability
to really add some pizazz.

424
00:23:20.805 --> 00:23:23.915
Like if we find a number like these zeros,
that's no good.

00:23:23.915 --> 00:23:25.605
I don't like those.

00:23:25.605 --> 00:23:28.315
Well let's find out how

00:23:28.315 --> 00:23:31.820
Up here on my home ribbon I've

00:23:31.820 --> 00:23:33.230
there's one right there called Bad.

00:23:33.230 --> 00:23:34.560
I like that.

00:23:34.560 --> 00:23:37.860
Notice it's going to change

00:23:39.070 --> 00:23:42.648
So now I can apply that to wherever

00:23:42.648 --> 00:23:44.088
apply that cell style.

433
00:23:44.088 --> 00:23:48.490
So cell styles are ways that we can

00:23:48.490 --> 00:23:53.253
And unfortunately in Excel,

00:23:53.253 --> 00:23:54.045
Right?

00:23:54.045 --> 00:23:55.805
When you think of Word for example,

00:23:55.805 --> 00:24:00.210
you get a button on your toolbar that will

00:24:00.210 --> 00:24:03.390
Just like we used to use the highlighters

00:24:03.390 --> 00:24:05.750
that's just to bring
attention to something?

00:24:05.750 --> 00:24:07.910
In Excel, I can't really do that.

00:24:07.910 --> 00:24:12.780
The way we do it, is we fake it by

00:24:12.780 --> 00:24:15.758
So 22, that's a really good number.

00:24:15.758 --> 00:24:18.740
Maybe you want to highlight that,

00:24:18.740 --> 00:24:21.800
I just changed the fill color of the cell.

00:24:21.800 --> 00:24:22.330
Right?

446
00:24:22.330 --> 00:24:24.240
To make that stand out a little bit more.

00:24:24.240 --> 00:24:28.670
So, there really isn't a highlighter

448
00:24:28.670 --> 00:24:33.600
I can kind of fake it, by changing

00:24:33.600 --> 00:24:35.400
So the only thing that

00:24:35.400 --> 00:24:37.550

00:24:37.550 --> 00:24:40.360
You might want to change

00:24:40.360 --> 00:24:41.920

00:24:41.920 --> 00:24:46.950
If I go a little bit lighter on the green,

00:24:46.950 --> 00:24:49.550

455
00:24:49.550 --> 00:24:52.860
Other things we have to worry

00:24:52.860 --> 00:24:55.880
there's several number

00:24:57.940 --> 00:24:59.900
Let's see where I can

00:24:59.900 --> 00:25:01.050
Right here's a good example.

00:25:01.050 --> 00:25:06.010
On my March tab, I imported some data, and

00:25:06.010 --> 00:25:07.150
Well, these are dollar values,

00:25:07.150 --> 00:25:11.860
but that's not really obvious from the way
those numbers look right there, all right?

00:25:11.860 --> 00:25:14.100
So, we need to format this.

00:25:14.100 --> 00:25:17.690
The format I would choose

00:25:17.690 --> 00:25:22.580
Currency is gonna throw that dollar sign
out there, and give me two decimal points.

00:25:22.580 --> 00:25:27.320
So if I do this like this number here,

466
00:25:27.320 --> 00:25:30.490
now it looks a little bit
more like dollars, all right.

467
00:25:30.490 --> 00:25:32.450
Now you can do it one cell at a time.

468
00:25:32.450 --> 00:25:37.730
You can use your format painter and try to
format the rest of these guys like that.

469
00:25:37.730 --> 00:25:43.830
An easier way to apply a formatting to the
entire column, select the column right.

470
00:25:43.830 --> 00:25:47.450
And then change that to currency and
we're good to go.

471
00:25:47.450 --> 00:25:51.310
Another number format that we commonly
have to use is the date format.

472
00:25:51.310 --> 00:25:55.430
Again, this data was imported, so
it doesn't look much like a date.

473
00:25:55.430 --> 00:26:00.090
Now I go and change that to a short date,
and there we go.

474
00:26:00.090 --> 00:26:02.680
Now we're a little more in business.

00:26:02.680 --> 00:26:03.510
All right?

00:26:03.510 --> 00:26:06.640
A couple other things

00:26:06.640 --> 00:26:10.030
We did our Format Painter,

00:26:10.030 --> 00:26:13.690
The alignment again, you can do

00:26:13.690 --> 00:26:17.910
You can also align it
vertically within the cell.

480
00:26:17.910 --> 00:26:20.650
All right, let me go back
out to our summary here, and

00:26:20.650 --> 00:26:26.340
I'm gonna make this a little bit taller.

00:26:26.340 --> 00:26:29.880
So, I've got all in this, ridiculously

00:26:29.880 --> 00:26:33.660
And all these extra space,
I could take these guys and

00:26:33.660 --> 00:26:39.170
right above my left center and right
align, is my top, middle, and bottom line.

00:26:39.170 --> 00:26:41.580
You see text by default is bottom align,
so

00:26:41.580 --> 00:26:44.260
is numbers,
maybe I wanna center that in that column.

00:26:44.260 --> 00:26:46.760
You see how they jumped in

00:26:46.760 --> 00:26:48.770
So depending on what you're trying to do,
and I'll go ahead and

00:26:48.770 --> 00:26:51.490
do that whole block of data there,

490
00:26:51.490 --> 00:26:56.020
we'll go ahead and center line those, so

491
00:26:56.020 --> 00:27:00.250
It really just depends on what you're

00:27:00.250 --> 00:27:03.100
Maybe stand out a little bit more from it.

00:27:03.100 --> 00:27:07.790
Another thing that we sometimes want
to do, is put a little space before it.

494
00:27:07.790 --> 00:27:11.470
Like text is always left
aligned by default.

00:27:11.470 --> 00:27:15.580
But what if I have, I don't know,

00:27:15.580 --> 00:27:16.990
Let's put some numbers over there.

00:27:16.990 --> 00:27:22.010
All right, because numbers by default, or

00:27:22.010 --> 00:27:26.060
write aligned, they bump right up

00:27:26.060 --> 00:27:28.610
maybe that makes it too hard to read.

00:27:28.610 --> 00:27:32.230
Well, what I could do,

Put a little bit of a buffer between

00:27:38.380 --> 00:27:42.910
Give it a way to stand out from

00:27:42.910 --> 00:27:44.060

00:27:44.060 --> 00:27:49.750
So a lot of cool things I can do with

00:27:49.750 --> 00:27:54.150
Working with the alignment,

00:27:54.150 --> 00:27:58.090

00:27:58.090 --> 00:28:02.890
There's one more, Wes, that I don't

516
00:28:32.960 --> 00:28:38.470
I have Word Art, and when I click on that
and you have got some pretty cool options,

517
00:28:38.470 --> 00:28:40.890
and I'll give excel this there
is some really neat ones.

518
00:28:40.890 --> 00:28:44.790
One of my favorite ones is
this mirrored look here.

519
00:28:44.790 --> 00:28:47.360
I'm gonna select that one and

520
00:28:47.360 --> 00:28:49.810
it's going to give me the ability
to type my text here.

521
00:28:49.810 --> 00:28:53.770
I'll put Mikes, and I'll move
this in just a second, Pet Store.

522
00:28:56.320 --> 00:28:59.100
Right, and
I'll show you what we can do to that.

523
00:28:59.100 --> 00:29:03.700
Let me insert a few blank
rows up here at the top, and

524
00:29:03.700 --> 00:29:08.342
now move that Word Art up there
were you can really see it.

525
00:29:08.342 --> 00:29:09.335
Right?

526
00:29:09.335 --> 00:29:12.835
And so there you can see it,
it's text but it's not text.

527
00:29:12.835 --> 00:29:13.355
Right?

528
00:29:13.355 --> 00:29:19.215
It's actually turned into an object that
I can move around on my spread sheet.

529
00:29:19.215 --> 00:29:21.325
So I could put this anywhere I wanted.

530
00:29:21.325 --> 00:29:24.315
In fact,
I can even rotate it if I want to, and

531
00:29:24.315 --> 00:29:26.715
you can see it's got that mirrored effect.

532
00:29:26.715 --> 00:29:30.095
So the mirrored effect probably
doesn't look to good rotated but

533
00:29:30.095 --> 00:29:35.010
there's several different
Styles that we can use.

534
00:29:35.010 --> 00:29:36.920
But if I'm printing this out,

535
00:29:36.920 --> 00:29:40.870
maybe I want some kind of really
cool font like that up there.

536
00:29:41.980 --> 00:29:43.920
If we got to a print preview on this guy.

537
00:29:45.900 --> 00:29:48.680
Let's do a view.
Actually let's do file and

538
00:29:48.680 --> 00:29:52.350
print that will be
the easiest way to see it.

539
00:29:53.910 --> 00:29:56.450
All right.

540
00:29:56.450 --> 00:29:58.080
And there you go,
we get something like that.

541
00:30:00.350 --> 00:30:02.710
And it looks pretty good, right?

542
00:30:02.710 --> 00:30:03.960
If I'm gonna Print this up, or

543
00:30:03.960 --> 00:30:09.000
present it at a meeting, that adds
some real character to the report,

544
00:30:09.000 --> 00:30:13.520
it draws attention to it, it lets
people know you spent some time on it.

545
00:30:13.520 --> 00:30:16.910
Or maybe it's drawing away from the fact
that you don't have very good numbers, so

546
00:30:16.910 --> 00:30:18.690
you, you want them to focus on the title.

547
00:30:18.690 --> 00:30:19.242
No, I'm kidding.

548
00:30:19.242 --> 00:30:20.000
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

549
00:30:20.000 --> 00:30:23.090
>> So Word Art is something you can

550
00:30:23.090 --> 00:30:23.700
play with.

551
00:30:23.700 --> 00:30:28.900
Again, it's just taking text and
turning it into a graphical object

552
00:30:28.900 --> 00:30:31.880
that we can manipulate and
put anywhere we want on that worksheet.

553
00:30:31.880 --> 00:30:35.410
So lots of things we can do to
spice up these work sheets.

554
00:30:35.410 --> 00:30:36.350
>> That's great Mike.

555
00:30:36.350 --> 00:30:38.890
So we've looked at a lot
of cool features here.

556
00:30:38.890 --> 00:30:42.400
We've looked at how you can get
that data into your spreadsheet.

557
00:30:42.400 --> 00:30:43.850
Auto fill.

558
00:30:43.850 --> 00:30:46.220
Being able to import the information in so

559
00:30:46.220 --> 00:30:49.180
you don't have to type out
cell by cell line by line but.

560
00:30:49.180 --> 00:30:51.130
What happens when the data
is on your spreadsheet?

561
00:30:51.130 --> 00:30:52.300
What can we do with it after then?

562
00:30:52.300 --> 00:30:56.580
We've showed you how to add some flair
make your spreadsheet a little bit more

563
00:30:56.580 --> 00:31:00.170
presentable, so that if you are presenting
it, it looks a little bit better.

564
00:31:00.170 --> 00:31:03.720
Again give it a little bit more flair
there Mike anything else for us?

565
00:31:03.720 --> 00:31:04.790
Now, there's a lot more of it.

566
00:31:04.790 --> 00:31:06.152
I don't think it's gonna fit in this one.

567
00:31:06.152 --> 00:31:06.720
>> All right,

568
00:31:06.720 --> 00:31:09.500
well it looks like we've come to the end
of another exciting episode here.

569
00:31:09.500 --> 00:31:11.290
So signing off for IT Pro TV.

570
00:31:11.290 --> 00:31:12.820
I've been your host Wes Brian.

571
00:31:12.820 --> 00:31:13.640
And I'm Mike Roderick.

572
00:31:13.640 --> 00:31:15.996
And we'll see you next time.

573
00:31:15.996 --> 00:31:20.840
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take some time to help us to group and sort the data.  They show that understanding the basics of grouping and sorting results in reporting exactly what is asked of us.  They remind us that though formulas and details are foundations of the results we need, grouping and sorting helps to present that data in the way that is expected.  They guys demonstrate the use of conditional formatting, transposing put the data into perspective.  Using the sparklines, outlines and subtotals show that we command of presenting the data as requested.  These are great skills that anyone proficient in Excel should know how to accomplish.
episodes.title: Order and Group Data
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.078 --> 00:00:10.078
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.418 --> 00:00:15.438
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.438 --> 00:00:17.243
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:17.243 --> 00:00:20.915
today, we're gonna be taking
a look into Microsoft Excel 2016,

5
00:00:20.915 --> 00:00:25.490
and we're specifically gonna be talking
about grouping and sorting our data.

6
00:00:25.490 --> 00:00:29.140
Making sure that we understand
that our data on a spreadsheet

7
00:00:29.140 --> 00:00:33.520
doesn't always just have to appear as it
is, but we can actually end up being able

8
00:00:33.520 --> 00:00:37.400
to logically group the data together, so
that we can do the things that we need to.

9
00:00:37.400 --> 00:00:39.710
And who better to help us,
than Mr. Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:39.710 --> 00:00:40.880
Mike, how's it going?

11
00:00:40.880 --> 00:00:42.050
>> It's another day in paradise.

12
00:00:42.050 --> 00:00:44.030
Here I am, working at ITProTV.

13
00:00:44.030 --> 00:00:46.120
Working with Excel,
one of my favorite applications.

14
00:00:46.120 --> 00:00:47.640
It doesn't get much better than this.

15
00:00:47.640 --> 00:00:48.890
They pay me to do this.

16
00:00:48.890 --> 00:00:50.840
All right, so what we're gonna
do today is, as Ronnie said,

17
00:00:50.840 --> 00:00:53.500
we're gonna take a look at ordering and
grouping some data.

18
00:00:53.500 --> 00:00:55.370
We also have a couple formatting things.

19
00:00:55.370 --> 00:00:58.170
I don't know if we'd call them formatting,
I guess I would,

20
00:00:58.170 --> 00:01:01.620
because it's conditional formatting,
so we'll call it formatting, and

21
00:01:01.620 --> 00:01:05.110
some cool little miniature graphs
that we're gonna throw in there.

22
00:01:05.110 --> 00:01:09.188
Not giraffes, graphs,
that we're gonna throw in here, as well.

23
00:01:09.188 --> 00:01:13.200
This is just the way Microsoft
likes to organize their objectives.

24
00:01:13.200 --> 00:01:16.490
They call it ordering grouping data, and
then they throw spark lines in there.

25
00:01:16.490 --> 00:01:18.310
So just bear with us on that.

26
00:01:18.310 --> 00:01:20.820
So we're gonna start with
conditional formatting.

27
00:01:20.820 --> 00:01:24.728
Now, in a previous episode,
we did some formatting and, in particular,

28
00:01:24.728 --> 00:01:28.139
I showed you some cell highlighting,
where I could take a cell and

29
00:01:28.139 --> 00:01:32.123
apply a highlighting like good or bad,
or code block, or things like that.

30
00:01:32.123 --> 00:01:36.110
And I talked about being able to draw
our attention to specific values.

31
00:01:36.110 --> 00:01:38.740
So within this chart or
this group of data,

32
00:01:38.740 --> 00:01:41.210
I had some values that were really high,
like the highest value or

33
00:01:41.210 --> 00:01:45.360
the lowest value, that I could manually
apply some formatting to that.

34
00:01:45.360 --> 00:01:49.790
That's all well and good, but
a lot of times, my data is dynamic.

35
00:01:49.790 --> 00:01:55.290
I want my formatting to be able to
look at the data and get applied based

36
00:01:55.290 --> 00:02:00.920
on the actual values, not me specifically
saying, cell G6 should be red.

37
00:02:00.920 --> 00:02:02.570
I want the biggest numbers to be green.

38
00:02:02.570 --> 00:02:04.880
I want the lowest numbers to be red,
right?

39
00:02:04.880 --> 00:02:07.880
Things like that, and if those
numbers change, change the formatting.

40
00:02:07.880 --> 00:02:09.550
Don't make me go back and change it.

41
00:02:09.550 --> 00:02:12.560
That's what conditional
formatting is all about.

42
00:02:12.560 --> 00:02:16.500
Format based on a condition
that you predefine, right?

43
00:02:16.500 --> 00:02:17.940
And that condition could be anything.

44
00:02:17.940 --> 00:02:21.892
It could be greater than a value,
greater than the average,

45
00:02:21.892 --> 00:02:25.388
less than the top 10%, or
whatever the case my be.

46
00:02:25.388 --> 00:02:29.847
And Excel makes it extremely easy for
us to do conditional formatting, and

47
00:02:29.847 --> 00:02:33.618
there's some really cool ones
that you can do now in 2016.

48
00:02:33.618 --> 00:02:34.620
So let's take a look.

49
00:02:34.620 --> 00:02:36.040
I've got a sheet here.

50
00:02:36.040 --> 00:02:37.740
I just made up some numbers.

51
00:02:37.740 --> 00:02:39.690
I took my employees' last names.

52
00:02:39.690 --> 00:02:41.210
Put them down that first column.

53
00:02:41.210 --> 00:02:43.340
I've got my months across the top, and

54
00:02:43.340 --> 00:02:48.190
then I filled in some values in-between
there, and if you're looking at this data,

55
00:02:48.190 --> 00:02:52.530
imagine being a C level or me turning
this in to one of my higher ups.

56
00:02:52.530 --> 00:02:55.210
Well, how do they know how
the top seller is, right?

57
00:02:55.210 --> 00:02:58.120
Or who's the one that really needs
to be called into the office to

58
00:02:58.120 --> 00:03:00.250
have a little sit down with, right?

59
00:03:00.250 --> 00:03:01.680
Who gets that bonus?

60
00:03:01.680 --> 00:03:05.160
Who gets that pink slip
based on these numbers.

61
00:03:05.160 --> 00:03:05.720
Hard to tell.

62
00:03:05.720 --> 00:03:10.600
They all just kind of blur together, and
I could try to find the biggest one.

63
00:03:10.600 --> 00:03:12.930
I'm not gonna even waste my time doing it.

64
00:03:12.930 --> 00:03:15.620
Conditional formatting can do that for me.

65
00:03:15.620 --> 00:03:20.810
So what I'm going to do,
is I'm gonna select my range of data.

66
00:03:20.810 --> 00:03:22.700
Remember, you always
wanna select to affect.

67
00:03:22.700 --> 00:03:26.720
So let me select the data that I
want to apply this formatting to,

68
00:03:26.720 --> 00:03:28.820
and I'm gonna bring my ribbon back.

69
00:03:28.820 --> 00:03:31.820
I closed it up to give it a little more
room for a second, and conditional

70
00:03:31.820 --> 00:03:36.730
formatting is on my Home ribbon,
right over here in my Styles group.

71
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:41.150
I hit this dropdown list, and
the first one I see is Highlight Cells,

72
00:03:41.150 --> 00:03:45.130
all right, and when I hover over that,
I'll zoom in a little bit,

73
00:03:45.130 --> 00:03:47.280
you see the different options that I have.

74
00:03:47.280 --> 00:03:49.930
Let me move that over so
I can get it away from my head.

75
00:03:49.930 --> 00:03:53.866
Highlight Cells, Greater Than,
Less Than, Between,

76
00:03:53.866 --> 00:03:58.468
Equal To, Text Contains,
A Date Occurring, Duplicate Values.

77
00:03:58.468 --> 00:04:02.870
That's a fantastic one if I'm looking for
duplicates that shouldn't be there.

78
00:04:02.870 --> 00:04:05.820
Let me scroll out now and
show you how it works.

79
00:04:05.820 --> 00:04:09.358
I'm gonna simply do a Greater Than.

80
00:04:09.358 --> 00:04:13.282
All right, and you can see in
the background, it's already starting to

81
00:04:13.282 --> 00:04:17.090
because it has a default value
based on the cell I had selected.

82
00:04:17.090 --> 00:04:21.100
I should say, the first cell in the range
of cells that I have selected, but

83
00:04:21.100 --> 00:04:21.910
I can change that.

84
00:04:21.910 --> 00:04:25.490
I know that we average
somewhere around $3500 a month,

85
00:04:25.490 --> 00:04:29.750
or that's what my goal is for
my employees.

86
00:04:29.750 --> 00:04:31.336
So, I put $3500, and

87
00:04:31.336 --> 00:04:36.240
I'm gonna change that formatting to
green fill with dark green text.

88
00:04:36.240 --> 00:04:41.570
You can see the drop down list of
choices that I have over here,

89
00:04:41.570 --> 00:04:42.630
and you can also do custom.

90
00:04:42.630 --> 00:04:44.240
You're not stuck with one of these.

91
00:04:44.240 --> 00:04:48.894
I'll just use one of their built in ones
and if I scroll out and click OK and

92
00:04:48.894 --> 00:04:50.508
click away from my data.

93
00:04:50.508 --> 00:04:51.600
>> Nice.
>> Look at that.

94
00:04:51.600 --> 00:04:53.980
Those numbers really jump out at me,
right?

95
00:04:53.980 --> 00:04:56.040
And if you're thinking,
hey, that's too many,

96
00:04:56.040 --> 00:04:58.660
I wanna see who is really doing the best,

97
00:04:58.660 --> 00:05:03.530
we can simply modify that value that we're
using on that conditional formatting.

98
00:05:03.530 --> 00:05:07.731
All right, I can say, okay, that's too
many people to try to give bonuses to,

99
00:05:07.731 --> 00:05:09.570
let's see who's over 4000.

100
00:05:09.570 --> 00:05:14.410
All right, and I can still see
that's quite a few numbers.

101
00:05:14.410 --> 00:05:18.658
So maybe I want to jump that up to 4500.

102
00:05:18.658 --> 00:05:23.020
So now I've got a few less people,
although it does seem to have kept some of

103
00:05:23.020 --> 00:05:27.300
my, I probably didn't undo that first one,
there we go.

104
00:05:27.300 --> 00:05:27.920
Let's do that again.

105
00:05:27.920 --> 00:05:34.790
Let's say we wanna go greater
than 4500 and I want those guys.

106
00:05:34.790 --> 00:05:35.590
We'll do a custom one.

107
00:05:35.590 --> 00:05:43.750
We'll say custom format and I want it
to be filled with a nice green color,

108
00:05:43.750 --> 00:05:48.400
and I want the font color to be red.

109
00:05:48.400 --> 00:05:49.098
Really want it to stand out.

110
00:05:49.098 --> 00:05:49.718
We'll click OK.

111
00:05:49.718 --> 00:05:52.640
>> [LAUGH]
>> We'll click OK, and there you go.

112
00:05:52.640 --> 00:05:57.042
So you can see who my sales people are,
what their best performing months are,

113
00:05:57.042 --> 00:06:00.058
right, and
you can do whatever formatting you want.

114
00:06:00.058 --> 00:06:02.338
I'll undo that and we'll try another one.

115
00:06:02.338 --> 00:06:03.618
There's the top and bottom.

116
00:06:03.618 --> 00:06:07.622
We're going to highlight cells,
you got greater than, less than, between,

117
00:06:07.622 --> 00:06:08.172
equal to.

118
00:06:08.172 --> 00:06:09.912
Top and bottom are nice, right?

119
00:06:09.912 --> 00:06:13.012
I just wanna see the top ten items.

120
00:06:13.012 --> 00:06:14.112
How about that?

121
00:06:14.112 --> 00:06:15.672
All right, and
let's do something different.

122
00:06:15.672 --> 00:06:18.753
We'll do that green again, right?

123
00:06:18.753 --> 00:06:21.330
I'll click OK, and there you go.

124
00:06:21.330 --> 00:06:23.130
There's the top ten values.

125
00:06:23.130 --> 00:06:24.400
I didn't have to sit there and look.

126
00:06:24.400 --> 00:06:26.520
I didn't have to do what I
did in the previous demo,

127
00:06:26.520 --> 00:06:30.490
where I had to guess 4000, 4500.

128
00:06:30.490 --> 00:06:33.720
It's gonna give me a small
number of top sales.

129
00:06:33.720 --> 00:06:39.370
We'll just use that top ten, and
the top ten, you're not stuck with ten.

130
00:06:39.370 --> 00:06:44.400
It says top ten items, but let say, we're
only paying bonus to the top 15 items.

131
00:06:44.400 --> 00:06:46.020
Well, I can change that to a 15.

132
00:06:46.020 --> 00:06:48.580
Or I can change that to a five, right.

133
00:06:48.580 --> 00:06:51.495
And now it's just gonna do, and
let me undo those changes so

134
00:06:51.495 --> 00:06:53.316
we can see those a little bit better.

135
00:06:53.316 --> 00:06:56.655
All right, top bottom, top ten items.

136
00:06:56.655 --> 00:06:58.470
Let's say I only wanna do the top three.

137
00:06:58.470 --> 00:07:00.351
We only got first,
second and third trophies.

138
00:07:00.351 --> 00:07:04.030
So we'll do the top three,
and there they are, right?

139
00:07:04.030 --> 00:07:07.300
So you're not stuck just because it says
top ten, doesn't mean you have to do that.

140
00:07:07.300 --> 00:07:09.460
There's also 10%.

141
00:07:09.460 --> 00:07:11.088
Let me undo my changes again.

142
00:07:11.088 --> 00:07:15.088
All right, you can say, you know what,
I want the top 10%, and

143
00:07:15.088 --> 00:07:19.970
as another one of those, you're not
stuck with 10, maybe I want the top 5%.

144
00:07:21.150 --> 00:07:25.140
All right, so lots of cool little rules
within this conditional formatting.

145
00:07:25.140 --> 00:07:28.700
Let me undo my changes and let's take
a look at a couple of the others.

146
00:07:29.790 --> 00:07:35.240
Those two, again, Top 10, Top Percent,
Bottom 10, Bottom %, Above Average.

147
00:07:35.240 --> 00:07:36.520
That's a fantastic one, right?

148
00:07:36.520 --> 00:07:37.800
I don't have to sit here and

149
00:07:37.800 --> 00:07:41.330
try to figure out what the average is,
it's gonna look at all those numbers.

150
00:07:41.330 --> 00:07:42.810
Figure out what the average is and

151
00:07:42.810 --> 00:07:45.480
then highlight the cells
that are above average.

152
00:07:45.480 --> 00:07:48.347
If those numbers change,
well, the average changes,

153
00:07:48.347 --> 00:07:51.338
and it's gonna take care of
changing that for me, right?

154
00:07:51.338 --> 00:07:54.546
So that conditional formatting
like that is fantastic.

155
00:07:54.546 --> 00:07:58.230
>> There's no doubt, Mike, that I see
the incredible benefit and use of this.

156
00:07:58.230 --> 00:08:02.047
When somebody is asking me to make a basic
analysis like you're talking about right

157
00:08:02.047 --> 00:08:06.170
away and they're saying, look, can you
give this to me in the next five minutes?

158
00:08:06.170 --> 00:08:08.750
Well, I could, if I have these tools and

159
00:08:08.750 --> 00:08:11.090
the nice thing about those preset ones,
right?

160
00:08:11.090 --> 00:08:13.920
they're usually the most
highly requested ones

161
00:08:13.920 --> 00:08:18.010
that really do help us out by simply
selecting just a couple of clicks away.

162
00:08:18.010 --> 00:08:20.088
And then if I need to
turn that into 15% or

163
00:08:20.088 --> 00:08:23.880
17%, or whatever it might be,
we can change that.

164
00:08:23.880 --> 00:08:26.560
But I couldn't imagine
manually having to go through

165
00:08:26.560 --> 00:08:30.230
just even that square of data that
we had or that rectangle of data and

166
00:08:30.230 --> 00:08:34.420
saying, yeah, here's the top 15
sales that were made this month, and

167
00:08:34.420 --> 00:08:39.190
just use a regular highlighter and
do that on a regular spreadsheet.

168
00:08:39.190 --> 00:08:40.250
But you can imagine then,

169
00:08:40.250 --> 00:08:43.980
the power that we have right here

00:31:54.671 --> 00:31:58.852
Be able to actually say, here's the totals
that we want to be able to present, and

627
00:31:58.852 --> 00:32:03.320
actually make it presentable in the way
that we're asked to present it as well.

628
00:32:03.320 --> 00:32:05.480
So there's a lot of useful tools for us.

629
00:32:05.480 --> 00:32:07.710
Ok Mike, any last things here?

630
00:32:07.710 --> 00:32:10.000
>> I was going to show you one more thing.

631
00:32:10.000 --> 00:32:11.910
Let's see if we can get this back.

632
00:32:11.910 --> 00:32:14.000
So we've got this outline
here that I've done.

633
00:32:14.000 --> 00:32:15.880
We did grouping on the product and

634
00:32:15.880 --> 00:32:19.930
then we did a count,
we did a sum of the count on that product.

635
00:32:19.930 --> 00:32:23.270
What if I also want to
break it by hospital?

636
00:32:23.270 --> 00:32:26.470
All right, because maybe they want to
know which hospital is buying the most of

637
00:32:26.470 --> 00:32:27.800
this product as well.

638
00:32:27.800 --> 00:32:30.050
I can add another subtotal.

639
00:32:30.050 --> 00:32:31.460
I can come back in here.

640
00:32:31.460 --> 00:32:33.010
And I can say hey, at each change, and

641
00:32:33.010 --> 00:32:38.193
this time we're going to
do change in company, let's

642
00:32:38.193 --> 00:32:44.170
do another sum of the quantity,
or should we do unit price?

643
00:32:44.170 --> 00:32:46.220
Again, it would make more sense for
the total.

644
00:32:46.220 --> 00:32:49.360
I'll do unit price just for giggles,
but the total would make more sense.

645
00:32:49.360 --> 00:32:52.630
but I'm going to uncheck
replace current subtotal

646
00:32:52.630 --> 00:32:56.200
which should leave my existing subtotals
in there and just add this to it.

647
00:32:56.200 --> 00:32:57.240
I'll go ahead and click okay.

648
00:32:57.240 --> 00:33:01.210
And this might take it a minute to go out
and calculate because there's lots of

649
00:33:01.210 --> 00:33:04.070
groups already and
that has to look at each group and

650
00:33:04.070 --> 00:33:07.310
break it down by hospital and
perform the calculation on there.

651
00:33:07.310 --> 00:33:10.460
So let's just give it a second,
you can see it flashing away down here,

652
00:33:10.460 --> 00:33:13.550
working away down here,
working hard on me.

653
00:33:13.550 --> 00:33:16.880
Got my spinning Cheerio, so
keep our fingers crossed.

654
00:33:16.880 --> 00:33:20.260
And there we go,
I now have another level of grouping.

655
00:33:20.260 --> 00:33:26.530
Let me click away, so you can see Florida
Hospital, and this is for just Abilify,

656
00:33:26.530 --> 00:33:32.280
Memorial Hospital total St. Joseph's
total, Tampa General, Tampa Shriners.

657
00:33:32.280 --> 00:33:34.500
And then there's the total for
the all of the hospitals.

658
00:33:34.500 --> 00:33:36.120
There's the count, right.

659
00:33:36.120 --> 00:33:39.440
And you see I got another
level of outlining.

660
00:33:39.440 --> 00:33:42.820
So now if I want to collapse those up,

661
00:33:42.820 --> 00:33:45.740
I can see each one of the hospitals and
Abilify.

662
00:33:45.740 --> 00:33:46.450
All right.

663
00:33:46.450 --> 00:33:48.730
So let's jump to say
level three like that.

664
00:33:48.730 --> 00:33:52.290
So look at that, I mean tell me
a boss wouldn't like this view.

665
00:33:52.290 --> 00:33:56.670
Here's the different hospitals,
that have ordered Abilify, there's their

666
00:33:57.850 --> 00:34:02.080
total, there's the Abilify total itself,
all right?

667
00:34:02.080 --> 00:34:07.020
If I want to see how many times Memorial
Hospital, if I can say that, ordered.

668
00:34:07.020 --> 00:34:08.630
I can get the details right there.

669
00:34:08.630 --> 00:34:10.370
It's not like the data went away.

670
00:34:10.370 --> 00:34:11.560
It's just hidden.

671
00:34:11.560 --> 00:34:16.430
So you can, jump to those different levels
of the outline so, fantastic stuff.

672
00:34:16.430 --> 00:34:17.040
>> Well excellent.

673
00:34:17.040 --> 00:34:20.800
Mike that looks like a great place for
us to go and end this episode.

674
00:34:20.800 --> 00:34:23.960
Signing off for ITPROTV I'm Ronnie Wong.

675
00:34:23.960 --> 00:34:24.640
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

676
00:34:24.640 --> 00:34:26.400
>> And we'll see you next time.

677
00:34:26.400 --> 00:34:32.202
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show how to create tables and use the power of tables when dealing with data.   They demonstrate the ease of creating a table using the built in tools and show how to use those table tools to get the data results we are looking for quickly and dynamically.  These features provide benefits to working with very large sets of data.   The guys also show how you can use tables to sort the logical data set to help with the reporting and display of the data.
episodes.title: Creating Tables
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.512 --> 00:00:15.717
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.717 --> 00:00:17.459
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong,

4
00:00:17.459 --> 00:00:21.380
and today we're gonna be taking
a look at Microsoft Excel 2016.

5
00:00:21.380 --> 00:00:24.230
We're specifically gonna be
taking a look at creating tables.

6
00:00:24.230 --> 00:00:28.020
Tables are a really powerful function
that we can find inside of Excel

7
00:00:28.020 --> 00:00:30.890
to help us to logically
group our data together, and

8
00:00:30.890 --> 00:00:34.090
that way we can actually manipulate
the data within that table and

9
00:00:34.090 --> 00:00:36.470
make it do the things and
show the things that want to.

10
00:00:36.470 --> 00:00:40.504
And who better to help us to understand
all of the magic that tables bring with us

11
00:00:40.504 --> 00:00:42.960
than the magic man himself, Mr.
Mike Roderick?

12
00:00:42.960 --> 00:00:43.730
How's it going, Mike?

13
00:00:43.730 --> 00:00:46.070
>> [LAUGH] It's going great,
Ronnie, glad to be here.

14
00:00:46.070 --> 00:00:48.860
Fun times with Excel and tables ahead.

15
00:00:48.860 --> 00:00:50.550
And you're right, tables, I love tables.

16
00:00:50.550 --> 00:00:53.930
I will tell you, I alway say this, right,

17
00:00:53.930 --> 00:00:55.593
there's one of my
favorite things in Excel.

18
00:00:55.593 --> 00:00:57.215
>> [LAUGH]
>> You haven't heard that before.

19
00:00:57.215 --> 00:01:00.920
But I remember when I first started,
when they first brought in tables, and

20
00:01:00.920 --> 00:01:03.840
we got to play with them and
they have a lot of power.

21
00:01:03.840 --> 00:01:06.370
Ronnie, before of the show
was teasing with, like, so

22
00:01:06.370 --> 00:01:07.540
what are we gonna talk about tables?

23
00:01:07.540 --> 00:01:08.490
Why do we want to use a table?

24
00:01:08.490 --> 00:01:09.605
I said, because they're pretty.

25
00:01:09.605 --> 00:01:10.850
>> [LAUGH]
>> And they are,

26
00:01:10.850 --> 00:01:15.795
they do add some formatting to our data,
but there's so much more than that.

27
00:01:15.795 --> 00:01:17.647
So, let's take a look at
this sheet I have here.

28
00:01:17.647 --> 00:01:20.212
I'm gonna kind of do a little compare and

29
00:01:20.212 --> 00:01:24.825
contrast to trying to do it ourselves
versus trying to do it with a table.

30
00:01:24.825 --> 00:01:28.370
All right, so on this first sheet, and
I think I've got all these guys lined up,

31
00:01:28.370 --> 00:01:30.000
we'll go to one of these other ones.

32
00:01:30.000 --> 00:01:32.000
I don't want to mess up
my first sheet there.

33
00:01:32.000 --> 00:01:34.340
So this is basically the same set of data.

34
00:01:34.340 --> 00:01:35.660
I've got January.

35
00:01:35.660 --> 00:01:37.360
A couple of different months here.

36
00:01:37.360 --> 00:01:41.000
And what I might try to do,
because this is not super legible, right,

37
00:01:41.000 --> 00:01:42.500
it all kind of blurs together.

38
00:01:42.500 --> 00:01:43.660
It can be difficult.

39
00:01:43.660 --> 00:01:48.230
So one of the things I would probably find
myself doing is making that title row

40
00:01:48.230 --> 00:01:52.620
a little bit bolder and bigger than
the rest of the text, but then,

41
00:01:52.620 --> 00:01:56.550
to try to follow this data across,
I almost have to use my cursor.

42
00:01:56.550 --> 00:01:59.770
I know I got old eyes and
things like that, so we might try and

43
00:01:59.770 --> 00:02:00.900
do some formatting.

44
00:02:00.900 --> 00:02:02.240
I might do something like this.

45
00:02:02.240 --> 00:02:06.340
I might say, all right,
let's take this row of data here and

46
00:02:06.340 --> 00:02:10.070
do a little background color on it,
something like that.

47
00:02:10.070 --> 00:02:14.490
And then, what I could do is I could
take my format painter, right,

48
00:02:14.490 --> 00:02:19.400
and I could start applying that
guy on these different rows.

49
00:02:19.400 --> 00:02:23.784
And you can see I can kind of get some
interesting looks, and I'll just get rid

50
00:02:23.784 --> 00:02:27.850
of that format, I won't go all
the way down, you get the idea, right?

51
00:02:27.850 --> 00:02:30.082
So now it's starting to
look a little bit better.

52
00:02:30.082 --> 00:02:36.604
I might decide to put some borders around
everything, so we might do All borders,

53
00:02:36.604 --> 00:02:41.340
and then we might do a nice,
thick outside border, right?

54
00:02:41.340 --> 00:02:45.040
And it's starting to become
a little more user-friendly,

55
00:02:45.040 --> 00:02:46.890
as far as looking at that data.

56
00:02:46.890 --> 00:02:49.410
The problem I have, though,
with doing it like this, one,

57
00:02:49.410 --> 00:02:51.740
it's a very manual process.

58
00:02:51.740 --> 00:02:54.630
Imagine if this was a few hundred or
a few thousand rows.

59
00:02:54.630 --> 00:02:58.400
I would almost wanna break out my VBA and
try to write a macro

60
00:02:58.400 --> 00:03:02.270
that would do this for me, which you
definitely could, it's not that difficult.

61
00:03:02.270 --> 00:03:05.750
But still a little bit of
a tedious process to create that.

62
00:03:05.750 --> 00:03:07.220
And then the problem becomes this.

63
00:03:07.220 --> 00:03:09.720
What if I have to insert a row, right?

64
00:03:09.720 --> 00:03:11.590
I go and insert a row.

65
00:03:11.590 --> 00:03:14.060
Well, the formatting goofs up.

66
00:03:14.060 --> 00:03:17.120
It can copy the formatting from
the row above, or I can say, hey,

67
00:03:17.120 --> 00:03:18.030
don't do that, Excel.

68
00:03:18.030 --> 00:03:19.850
Don't copy that formatting.

69
00:03:19.850 --> 00:03:23.250
Well, now, all of a sudden,
it's got no formatting at all.

70
00:03:23.250 --> 00:03:27.560
It's really gonna start goofing things
up if I start inserting rows in there.

71
00:03:27.560 --> 00:03:30.360
Another thing that happens when
you're working with data like this,

72
00:03:30.360 --> 00:03:34.410
even if you make it look pretty and
like a table, is when you go to sort it.

73
00:03:34.410 --> 00:03:36.560
Now Excel is pretty
good about it nowadays.

74
00:03:36.560 --> 00:03:40.823
In the past, though, you could easily
hose your data or mess your data.

75
00:03:40.823 --> 00:03:42.916
I use the technical term hose there,
Ronnie.

76
00:03:42.916 --> 00:03:45.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> You could really mess your data up.

77
00:03:45.750 --> 00:03:48.740
Cuz what would happen, and
let's say I wanna sort it by product.

78
00:03:48.740 --> 00:03:52.490
So I come over here, do a little Sort and
Filter, and do a Sort.

79
00:03:52.490 --> 00:03:56.200
And luckily for me,
all the data's touching, and

80
00:03:56.200 --> 00:03:58.310
so it seems to sort all the rows.

81
00:03:58.310 --> 00:04:02.400
But if you're not careful, if there's any
blanks, any cells that don't have values

82
00:04:02.400 --> 00:04:06.440
in there, it'll sort the one column and
not the columns on either side.

83
00:04:06.440 --> 00:04:10.315
So now all the sudden,
you've completely ruined your data, right?

84
00:04:10.315 --> 00:04:12.560
Because now you've got products
that aren't on the right order,

85
00:04:12.560 --> 00:04:14.170
not with the right company.

86
00:04:14.170 --> 00:04:18.290
You better start doing Ctrl+Z or
hope you have a backup of that worksheet.

87
00:04:18.290 --> 00:04:22.330
So we run in to a little bit of problems
working with data like this, and

88
00:04:22.330 --> 00:04:24.890
tables solve all those problems.

89
00:04:24.890 --> 00:04:26.560
Another cool thing is filtering.

90
00:04:26.560 --> 00:04:29.290
And we can do some filtering right here.

91
00:04:29.290 --> 00:04:33.000
I can take this product column and
I can go over to Sort and Filter.

92
00:04:33.000 --> 00:04:37.850
And I can say, Filter and
it adds these little drop down lists.

93
00:04:37.850 --> 00:04:42.510
But this is relatively new to Excel,
it's within the last few versions.

94
00:04:42.510 --> 00:04:43.965
Remember, way back when you and

95
00:04:43.965 --> 00:04:47.415
I started it didn't have that
easy filtering capability.

96
00:04:47.415 --> 00:04:51.915
So tables are gonna basically do
all those things for us at once.

97
00:04:51.915 --> 00:04:53.645
It makes it very easy to work with.

98
00:04:53.645 --> 00:04:56.395
Let me switch over to this other tab and
I'll show you what I mean.

99
00:04:56.395 --> 00:04:58.985
And they're extremely easy to create.

100
00:04:58.985 --> 00:05:02.515
All you have to do click
somewhere in your data.

101
00:05:02.515 --> 00:05:06.750
Then you're going to go to your Insert
ribbon, and you're gonna choose Table.

102
00:05:06.750 --> 00:05:09.670
And it's gonna ask you one question or
two I should say.

103
00:05:09.670 --> 00:05:10.860
Where is your data?

104
00:05:10.860 --> 00:05:15.360
And since all my data is touching,
it's contiguous, it already has the range.

105
00:05:15.360 --> 00:05:19.400
There's, by default, a check mark there,
my table has header rows, which mine does.

106
00:05:19.400 --> 00:05:21.980
It has title for
each one of those columns.

107
00:05:21.980 --> 00:05:24.880
I click OK, and bada bing, that's it.

108
00:05:24.880 --> 00:05:26.880
We've got ourselves a table.

109
00:05:26.880 --> 00:05:30.660
And so, you'll see that it's similar
to what I was doing manually

110
00:05:30.660 --> 00:05:31.770
on that other sheet, right?

111
00:05:31.770 --> 00:05:34.220
It's got those banded rows in there.

112
00:05:34.220 --> 00:05:37.690
The header bar looks a little bit
different for the column headers.

113
00:05:37.690 --> 00:05:40.670
It's got those filters, but
it did it all with one click.

114
00:05:40.670 --> 00:05:44.270
I didn't have to do each one of
those steps individually, all right?

115
00:05:44.270 --> 00:05:48.640
And Excel recognizes the table itself.

116
00:05:48.640 --> 00:05:51.150
And that's gonna become very important for
a few different things and

117
00:05:51.150 --> 00:05:54.830
especially formulas when
we get into that episode.

118
00:05:54.830 --> 00:05:58.353
For example, let me show you what
happens when I insert a row.

119
00:05:58.353 --> 00:06:02.537
All right, I'm gonna insert a row at six,
so it's gonna move six down and

120
00:06:02.537 --> 00:06:04.104
I'm gonna get a new row 6.

121
00:06:04.104 --> 00:06:07.097
I'll say Insert, and
notice when I click away,

122
00:06:07.097 --> 00:06:09.733
the banding remains consistent, right?

123
00:06:09.733 --> 00:06:13.494
It changed that row blue, and everything
else is now alternating blue and white.

124
00:06:13.494 --> 00:06:16.820
So it's smart enough to move
that formatting around.

125
00:06:16.820 --> 00:06:17.952
Same thing when I delete it.

126
00:06:17.952 --> 00:06:19.670
You would think I might
have a white row and

127
00:06:19.670 --> 00:06:24.040
a white row together when I
delete this blue row, all right?

128
00:06:24.040 --> 00:06:25.540
But it's smart enough to say, hey, okay,

129
00:06:25.540 --> 00:06:28.690
I'm gonna reformat it as
that data shifts around.

130
00:06:28.690 --> 00:06:30.600
So, as you're inserting new elements or

131
00:06:30.600 --> 00:06:34.380
records into your table, it's gonna
take care of all of that for you.

132
00:06:34.380 --> 00:06:37.540
You automatically get these filter
buttons up across the top, and

133
00:06:37.540 --> 00:06:39.820
I love these little filter buttons.

134
00:06:39.820 --> 00:06:42.310
I don't like them out there all the time,
I'll tell you that, but

135
00:06:42.310 --> 00:06:43.437
I love their functionality.

136
00:06:43.437 --> 00:06:48.577
You click on it, and you can sort by
a particular column, A to Z, Z to A.

137
00:06:48.577 --> 00:06:52.377
Sort by color, if you had done some
of those conditional formattings that

138
00:06:52.377 --> 00:06:56.548
we talked about the other day, where
you're coloring different things based on

139
00:06:56.548 --> 00:06:58.600
the value, you can then sort by color.

140
00:06:58.600 --> 00:07:03.400
And again, it treats the data as one unit,
as a table there, so

141
00:07:03.400 --> 00:07:06.330
I don't have to worry about it
not sorting the first column

142
00:07:06.330 --> 00:07:10.690
when it rearranges the second column or
the third column, whatever you're doing.

143
00:07:10.690 --> 00:07:12.670
Let me get rid of that sort for
us there, or

144
00:07:12.670 --> 00:07:14.420
actually I'll just leave that,
doesn't matter.

145
00:07:14.420 --> 00:07:17.490
You've got some great text
filters built into here.

146
00:07:17.490 --> 00:07:23.100
I can say Begins with the letter,
I don't know which letters we're using, D.

147
00:07:23.100 --> 00:07:24.660
And I'll say OK.

148
00:07:24.660 --> 00:07:27.700
And there's all my products
that start with a D.

149
00:07:27.700 --> 00:07:28.910
Again, it's just a filter.

150
00:07:28.910 --> 00:07:30.320
The data isn't gone.

151
00:07:30.320 --> 00:07:34.160
You notice my row numbers, right,
all the data is still there.

152
00:07:34.160 --> 00:07:35.900
I can just remove that text filter.

153
00:07:37.450 --> 00:07:38.740
We'll just uncheck it over there.

154
00:07:38.740 --> 00:07:41.940
If I can get rid of my filter.

155
00:07:41.940 --> 00:07:43.960
Where's my clear filter?

156
00:07:43.960 --> 00:07:44.942
Goodness gracious, there we go.

157
00:07:44.942 --> 00:07:48.220
Clear filter is above it now,
it's not on the list anymore.

158
00:07:48.220 --> 00:07:50.689
So I'll clear that filter,
and all of my data is back.

159
00:07:50.689 --> 00:07:55.174
For numbers, a lot of times, this is
really handy, cuz they've got some special

160
00:07:55.174 --> 00:07:59.594
number filters that we can do, where you
can say Greater Than, or Greater Than Or

161
00:07:59.594 --> 00:08:02.208
Equal To, or
Between a certain value, right?

162
00:08:02.208 --> 00:08:05.279
You also get a list of
all the unique values.

163
00:08:05.279 --> 00:08:09.945
So if you just wanna see all
the products that sold for $10.31,

164
00:08:09.945 --> 00:08:11.970
well there they are, right?

165
00:08:11.970 --> 00:08:18.490
I can go back in, and I can select
all to get all of my data back.

166
00:08:18.490 --> 00:08:21.350
Order dates, there's a common one to do.

167
00:08:21.350 --> 00:08:23.550
I wanna do a text filter.

168
00:08:23.550 --> 00:08:26.670
If I can get my fly out to come out again.

169
00:08:26.670 --> 00:08:31.190
Between, or we can say contains,

170
00:08:31.190 --> 00:08:35.340
unfortunately I think I actually
have that formatted as text and

171
00:08:35.340 --> 00:08:38.950
not a date, so
my filters aren't quite right.

172
00:08:38.950 --> 00:08:41.870
Let's change that to a date.

173
00:08:43.550 --> 00:08:45.670
And now when I do my filters.

174
