1,000 rows, and

631
00:32:05.180 --> 00:32:09.310
format it all at one time and
only effect that data set, as well.

632
00:32:09.310 --> 00:32:13.110
It really is a powerful tool
that we should know how to use,

633
00:32:13.110 --> 00:32:16.730
know how to actually use it effectively,
and by being able to actually do that,

634
00:32:16.730 --> 00:32:19.490
we're going to actually be able to
manipulate our data much more efficiently.

635
00:32:19.490 --> 00:32:21.120
Mike, any other last words here?

636
00:32:21.120 --> 00:32:23.080
>> One parting word I
wanna share with you guys.

637
00:32:23.080 --> 00:32:26.180
Remember I told you, and I said if
Microsoft's listening, please fix this.

638
00:32:26.180 --> 00:32:29.540
When you sort it,
your formatting doesn't sort properly.

639
00:32:29.540 --> 00:32:31.150
Or it really goofs things up.

640
00:32:31.150 --> 00:32:33.500
So if we look at my spreadsheet
it kinda looks ugly.

641
00:32:33.500 --> 00:32:34.880
Real quick easy fix for

642
00:32:34.880 --> 00:32:39.220
you guys out there, remove your table,
convert it back to a range.

643
00:32:39.220 --> 00:32:44.630
Once you've sorted it and everything's
all wrong, you just remove the table and

644
00:32:44.630 --> 00:32:47.465
then you can just clear
your formatting altogether.

645
00:32:47.465 --> 00:32:52.241
Woo, whoops, good thing I have that Cmd+Z,
yeah [CROSSTALK].

646
00:32:52.241 --> 00:32:57.203
Let's do that again, clear formats and
then just insert the table again.

647
00:32:57.203 --> 00:33:02.416
Insert > Table, and OK,
and we're back to normal.

648
00:33:02.416 --> 00:33:04.924
The only thing you'll wanna worry
about there is that it does change

649
00:33:04.924 --> 00:33:05.770
the name of the table.

650
00:33:05.770 --> 00:33:06.620
If you've given it a name,

651
00:33:06.620 --> 00:33:09.560
you're gonna have to re-name that
table back to what it use to be.

652
00:33:09.560 --> 00:33:11.310
Just a quick little tip.

653
00:33:11.310 --> 00:33:13.789
>> All right, well that's a great
place for us to go ahead and

654
00:33:13.789 --> 00:33:15.130
end this episode then.

655
00:33:15.130 --> 00:33:17.070
Signing off for ITProTV.

656
00:33:17.070 --> 00:33:17.696
I'm Ronnie Wong.

657
00:33:17.696 --> 00:33:18.695
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

658
00:33:18.695 --> 00:33:20.239
>> And we'll see you next time.

659
00:33:20.239 --> 00:33:28.320
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike introduce us to the fundamentals of building formulas.  They discuss the uses of relative references in formulas and absolute reference.  The guys also talk about the order of operations and its importance to being able to see the data we need.  Understanding the way that excel creates the formula is extremely helpful as our data and calculated values become more complex.
episodes.title: Ranges and References
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.650 --> 00:00:15.391
Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:15.391 --> 00:00:21.110
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today we're
taking a look at Microsoft Excel 2016.

4
00:00:21.110 --> 00:00:25.870
Now, we're specifically going to be taking
a look at getting ready to use formulas.

5
00:00:25.870 --> 00:00:30.020
And who better to help us to get started
here is gonna be Mr. Mike Rodrick?

6
00:00:30.020 --> 00:00:31.010
Mike, how's it going?

7
00:00:31.010 --> 00:00:31.890
>> It's going great, Ronnie.

8
00:00:31.890 --> 00:00:33.610
We are getting into the good stuff now,
right?

9
00:00:33.610 --> 00:00:36.310
We're really starting to
pull the power of Excel out.

10
00:00:36.310 --> 00:00:40.530
When we start talking about formulas and
functions, right?

11
00:00:40.530 --> 00:00:42.690
So, well, we'll dive right in, I guess.

12
00:00:42.690 --> 00:00:45.750
First, before I jump into my worksheet and
we start looking at it.

13
00:00:45.750 --> 00:00:49.880
Let me differentiate because you
hear people talk about functions,

14
00:00:49.880 --> 00:00:54.310
you'll hear people talk about formulas and
what's the difference, right?

15
00:00:54.310 --> 00:00:59.610
Well really a formula is one that you
would write yourself, like if you say

16
00:01:00.680 --> 00:01:06.900
if you wanna add up cells a1 and a2,
you could say equals a1 plus a2.

17
00:01:06.900 --> 00:01:08.160
All right, that's a formula.

18
00:01:08.160 --> 00:01:09.940
You're going to write everything out.

19
00:01:09.940 --> 00:01:12.690
Just think about the old
math formulas you wrote.

20
00:01:12.690 --> 00:01:17.900
Four plus three times two to
the power of four, that's a formula.

21
00:01:17.900 --> 00:01:21.080
A function is a built-in formula,

22
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:25.500
basically, where it knows what
mathematical calculation you want to do.

23
00:01:25.500 --> 00:01:28.220
You just have to tell it what
cells you want to do it on.

24
00:01:28.220 --> 00:01:32.040
So take that same one,
I want to add a1 and a2.

25
00:01:32.040 --> 00:01:33.170
I could do that two ways.

26
00:01:33.170 --> 00:01:40.460
I could say equals a1 plus a2 or
I could say equals SUM.

27
00:01:40.460 --> 00:01:42.420
That's my function.

28
00:01:42.420 --> 00:01:46.220
Open parentheses a1 comma
a2 close parentheses.

29
00:01:46.220 --> 00:01:47.940
In the end I'm gonna get the same result.

30
00:01:47.940 --> 00:01:52.500
But depending on what I'm doing,
one can be easier than the other.

31
00:01:52.500 --> 00:01:55.860
It really is one of those things that you
have to look at each situation differently

32
00:01:55.860 --> 00:01:58.510
and decide what's easier,
write my own formula or

33
00:01:58.510 --> 00:02:00.620
use one of those built-in functions?

34
00:02:00.620 --> 00:02:02.500
There's an average function, for example.

35
00:02:02.500 --> 00:02:04.030
We know how to make an average,

36
00:02:04.030 --> 00:02:08.160
add all your numbers up, divide that
number that you get, that total,

37
00:02:08.160 --> 00:02:13.050
by the number of numbers that you added
together to get an average, right?

38
00:02:13.050 --> 00:02:14.840
And we can do that
mathematically with a formula.

39
00:02:14.840 --> 00:02:19.240
I could say a plus b plus c plus d
divided by 4, I'd get an average.

40
00:02:19.240 --> 00:02:23.580
Or I could do average open parentheses,
abcd, closed parentheses, and

41
00:02:23.580 --> 00:02:25.870
I don't have to worry about telling it,
hey, divide this by 4.

42
00:02:25.870 --> 00:02:30.350
It knows that whatever that total is,
I'm going to figure out an average by

43
00:02:30.350 --> 00:02:34.546
dividing it by the number of integers,
or values I see in that parentheses.

44
00:02:34.546 --> 00:02:39.720
>> Now, Mike, we had mentioned earlier
in an episode that we had a friend

45
00:02:39.720 --> 00:02:44.270
that literally typed numbers inside
of Excel and then took a calculator

46
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:48.900
to be able to add those numbers up and
enter a value into another cell for us.

47
00:02:48.900 --> 00:02:52.280
And, I hate to say it,
when it comes down to Excel,

48
00:02:52.280 --> 00:02:56.170
a lot of times people begin with that if
they haven't actually studied it at all or

49
00:02:56.170 --> 00:02:58.070
understand a little bit about Excel.

50
00:02:58.070 --> 00:03:02.780
So, if I wanted to add up two numbers
inside of Excel, I can do that math!

51
00:03:02.780 --> 00:03:04.330
We know that we can take a calculator and

52
00:03:04.330 --> 00:03:07.800
do that but there's a reason why we
shouldn't do it that way, isn't there.

53
00:03:07.800 --> 00:03:10.050
>> Yeah, cuz Excel is dynamic, right?

54
00:03:10.050 --> 00:03:14.900
If those values change it's going
to change your total for you.

55
00:03:14.900 --> 00:03:18.150
We don't have to go back and
recalculate those numbers.

56
00:03:18.150 --> 00:03:20.270
If I use a calculator,
add the numbers up and

57
00:03:20.270 --> 00:03:24.040
then type the value in there, what if
one of those sales numbers changes?

58
00:03:24.040 --> 00:03:26.540
But my total is not
going to change anymore.

59
00:03:26.540 --> 00:03:29.490
Whereas when you do
a formula you're saying hey,

60
00:03:29.490 --> 00:03:33.060
look at this cell, add it to this cell and
add it to this cell.

61
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:36.210
It doesn't matter what those values are,
they could change.

62
00:03:36.210 --> 00:03:38.670
The formula will still work, right?

63
00:03:38.670 --> 00:03:40.675
But if you had statically
typed in the answer,

64
00:03:40.675 --> 00:03:42.620
that's not going to update automatically.

65
00:03:42.620 --> 00:03:47.330
So let's take a look here, I guess Ronnie
first at writing a couple simple ones and

66
00:03:47.330 --> 00:03:52.275
we need to understand the way
Excel functions in the background

67
00:03:52.275 --> 00:03:53.905
a little bit as well.

68
00:03:53.905 --> 00:03:56.005
So let's start, I've got a sheet here and

69
00:03:56.005 --> 00:03:59.915
I've simply created a few
cells with some numbers in it.

70
00:03:59.915 --> 00:04:04.045
And the first thing we have to know,
all formulas, and functions for

71
00:04:04.045 --> 00:04:06.555
that matter,
start with an equal sign, right?

72
00:04:06.555 --> 00:04:10.950
If I just type 4+2 and hit Enter.

73
00:04:10.950 --> 00:04:15.480
Excel's not gonna do anything
except display 4+2, right?

74
00:04:15.480 --> 00:04:21.880
If I say =4+2,
Excel says that's six, right?

75
00:04:21.880 --> 00:04:25.670
And remember when we talked about
displayed value versus actual content, or

76
00:04:25.670 --> 00:04:28.120
displayed content versus actual content.

77
00:04:28.120 --> 00:04:31.140
The cell holds the number six or
so it looks like.

78
00:04:31.140 --> 00:04:34.780
But if you look up here,
this is what's actually in the cell,

79
00:04:34.780 --> 00:04:37.950
this formula that I've written right here.

80
00:04:37.950 --> 00:04:41.320
When I go away from that cell you
can see it calculates it out and

81
00:04:41.320 --> 00:04:42.990
it gives me the answer.

82
00:04:42.990 --> 00:04:47.330
So all formulas, functions are going
to start with an equals sign.

83
00:04:47.330 --> 00:04:51.907
Now let's say I want to add up these
numbers right here, 5, 10, 15, and 20.

84
00:04:51.907 --> 00:04:53.770
There's a couple different
ways we can do this.

85
00:04:53.770 --> 00:04:56.910
We're gonna start with simple
formulas we'll get into functions

86
00:04:56.910 --> 00:04:58.390
in some later episodes.

87
00:04:58.390 --> 00:05:02.240
So I'm gonna say equals, oops,
that's not an equals sign.

88
00:05:02.240 --> 00:05:07.050
Equals and now I can do a couple
of different ways here.

89
00:05:07.050 --> 00:05:11.727
I can say equals, this is cell c4.

90
00:05:11.727 --> 00:05:16.600
So I can type in c4,
I can use that cell reference.

91
00:05:16.600 --> 00:05:19.960
And you can see it draws
a box around that cell.

92
00:05:19.960 --> 00:05:25.102
Plus, c, sorry, not c, but let's do d4

93
00:05:25.102 --> 00:05:30.991
plus e4 plus

94
00:05:30.991 --> 00:05:36.540
f4, and I'll hit Enter, and
there's my total, right?

95
00:05:36.540 --> 00:05:39.390
So I'm just adding up those cells there.

96
00:05:39.390 --> 00:05:42.760
That's one way to do it, is actually
type them out another way that you could

97
00:05:42.760 --> 00:05:47.130
do that, and let me undo that guy there.

98
00:05:47.130 --> 00:05:49.680
I could say equals, and

99
00:05:49.680 --> 00:05:53.940
I could just select the cell, plus and
I can click on the next cell,

100
00:05:53.940 --> 00:05:59.670
plus click on the next cell,
plus click on the next cell hit Enter.

101
00:05:59.670 --> 00:06:01.380
And I get the same result, all right.

102
00:06:01.380 --> 00:06:02.390
It's just how do you wanna do it.

103
00:06:02.390 --> 00:06:05.400
Do you want to type it out,
would you rather click on it,

104
00:06:05.400 --> 00:06:09.530
you can do it either way and
you end up with the same results.

105
00:06:10.620 --> 00:06:14.594
Now, so, creating that formula is
pretty straightforward, right?

106
00:06:14.594 --> 00:06:18.320
I just wanna add those together so,
use my basic math symbols, my plus sign.

107
00:06:18.320 --> 00:06:22.624
If I wanted to multiply
them I will simply do

108
00:06:22.624 --> 00:06:27.170
equals which cell and then times, right?

109
00:06:27.170 --> 00:06:30.010
In Excel, the splat or asterisk or

110
00:06:30.010 --> 00:06:34.030
the star whatever you wanna call that
is gonna be your multiplication symbol.

111
00:06:34.030 --> 00:06:39.350
Select your second cell, hit enter and
I get 5 times 10 is 50 right?

112
00:06:40.690 --> 00:06:44.240
So, pretty straightforward there,
use your cell references.

113
00:06:44.240 --> 00:06:47.280
Here's where formulas start
to get a little bit trickier.

114
00:06:47.280 --> 00:06:51.190
At least you have to pay attention
when I start moving these guys around.

115
00:06:51.190 --> 00:06:54.370
Now if, let's say if I wanted
to move this over underneath,

116
00:06:54.370 --> 00:06:57.610
well actually let's just say I
want to move it over one cell.

117
00:06:57.610 --> 00:07:03.080
If I go to the border of this cell,
I get my move symbol,

118
00:07:03.080 --> 00:07:07.200
I can click and drag and
move that over here, and nothing changed.

119
00:07:07.200 --> 00:07:08.280
It still says 50.

120
00:07:08.280 --> 00:07:14.760
Because it's still c4 plus d4, where
the sum or where answer is doesn't matter,

121
00:07:14.760 --> 00:07:20.910
it's still multiplying this
cell times this cell, right?

122
00:07:20.910 --> 00:07:23.350
If I start trying to do
a series fill though, and

123
00:07:23.350 --> 00:07:26.540
let's do it a little bit differently here,
let's change this up.

124
00:07:26.540 --> 00:07:30.620
Let's go ahead and add,
let's add these numbers.

125
00:07:30.620 --> 00:07:36.509
We're gonna say plus this guy plus this

126
00:07:36.509 --> 00:07:41.510
guy plus, we'll just do three.

127
00:07:41.510 --> 00:07:45.120
Now what if I wanted to do the same
thing for these cells here?

128
00:07:45.120 --> 00:07:51.955
If I drag this down, like this, and
do series fill, it works out, all right?

129
00:07:51.955 --> 00:07:53.985
Notice it's not 30 four times, all right?

130
00:07:55.295 --> 00:08:00.259
Because what happens is you see
the formula c4+d4+e4 when I did

131
00:08:00.259 --> 00:08:04.365
the series fill and
moved it down one notice it changed.

132
00:08:04.365 --> 00:08:05.805
And let's do, we can do this.

133
00:08:05.805 --> 00:08:10.205
See which numbers it's adding up?

134
00:08:10.205 --> 00:08:12.318
And look at this one.

135
00:08:12.318 --> 00:08:17.277
I moved the formula down, or should say
I copied the formula down one cell, so

136
00:08:17.277 --> 00:08:21.091
Excel said wait a second,
if you move the formula down one,

137
00:08:21.091 --> 00:08:26.440
I'm gonna move the numbers that your
adding together down one, right.

138
00:08:26.440 --> 00:08:27.858
If we take a look at the next one,

139
00:08:27.858 --> 00:08:31.460
notice which one's it's adding up,
again, cuz I moved it down one.

140
00:08:31.460 --> 00:08:33.230
This one is doing those.

141
00:08:33.230 --> 00:08:34.280
What if I did it one more?

142
00:08:35.620 --> 00:08:36.640
I get a big fat 0.

143
00:08:36.640 --> 00:08:37.600
Why?

144
00:08:37.600 --> 00:08:42.780
Well because it moved those boxes down one
and there's no numbers there, all right.

145
00:08:42.780 --> 00:08:46.070
So what this is by default
Excel uses something called

146
00:08:46.070 --> 00:08:48.750
a relative reference, right.

147
00:08:48.750 --> 00:08:53.925
The cells that I'm adding up are related
to the where the summary is or

148
00:08:53.925 --> 00:08:55.605
where that formula is.

149
00:08:55.605 --> 00:08:59.265
So if the formula moves down,
the numbers I'm adding up moves down, or

150
00:08:59.265 --> 00:09:01.205
the cells I'm using to add up.

151
00:09:01.205 --> 00:09:04.755
If I move this over, what's gonna happen?

152
00:09:04.755 --> 00:09:09.100
Well, I moved my formula over one,
so that means the cells,

153
00:09:09.100 --> 00:09:13.740
if you see here's my original formula,
5, 10, and 15 are being added together.

154
00:09:13.740 --> 00:09:16.370
I moved it over one, and now look.

155
00:09:16.370 --> 00:09:20.000
10, 15, and
20 are being added together, right?

156
00:09:20.000 --> 00:09:22.310
Formula moved over one to the right,

157
00:09:22.310 --> 00:09:25.570
the numbers that I'm adding
up moved over to the right.

158
00:09:25.570 --> 00:09:27.140
So sometimes that's a good thing.

159
00:09:27.140 --> 00:09:32.994
When we did that first series fill,
all right, before we had these guys.

160
00:09:32.994 --> 00:09:34.782
All right, clear that out.

161
00:09:34.782 --> 00:09:37.400
I didn't have to rewrite that formula.

162
00:09:37.400 --> 00:09:41.430
I didn't have to come over here and
say, equals this guy, plus this guy,

163
00:09:41.430 --> 00:09:42.080
plus this guy.

164
00:09:42.080 --> 00:09:46.050
I can just take that formula series fill,
and

165
00:09:46.050 --> 00:09:49.520
because of the relative nature
of those references, it said,

166
00:09:49.520 --> 00:09:52.330
hey you moved the formula down,
I'm gonna adjust the numbers I get.

167
00:09:52.330 --> 00:09:54.170
So it makes it very easy.

168
00:09:54.170 --> 00:09:58.780
Where it becomes difficult is
when I start moving that formula

169
00:09:58.780 --> 00:10:01.800
in a way that doesn't
coincide with the data.

170
00:10:01.800 --> 00:10:05.940
Let's say I wanted to move this summary,
let's move this summary here.

171
00:10:08.180 --> 00:10:09.982
Let's put that guy up there.

172
00:10:09.982 --> 00:10:14.110
All right, I want to move these formulas
up here underneath the summary.

173
00:10:14.110 --> 00:10:18.185
So I'm thinking okay, I'll just take
them and move them up over there.

174
00:10:18.185 --> 00:10:23.605
And notice that worked just fine because,
why did that work actually?

175
00:10:23.605 --> 00:10:27.030
[LAUGH] Usually a lot of times
that will not work for you.

176
00:10:27.030 --> 00:10:28.741
Excel is trying to help me out there.

177
00:10:28.741 --> 00:10:33.637
Watch what happens if I copy this guy,
and paste this guy.

178
00:10:33.637 --> 00:10:37.583
All of a sudden it doesn't work,
because look at the numbers here,

179
00:10:37.583 --> 00:10:40.265
I'm adding up these three cells.

180
00:10:40.265 --> 00:10:43.269
When I move that formula up to and
over four, so

181
00:10:43.269 --> 00:10:45.744
look what numbers this guy's doing.

182
00:10:45.744 --> 00:10:49.076
Up two and over four, see what i'm saying?

183
00:10:49.076 --> 00:10:53.218
And again, this is one of those concepts
that's kind of hard to verbalize,

184
00:10:53.218 --> 00:10:57.740
it's easier I think, visually hope
you guys are seeing what I'm doing.

185
00:10:57.740 --> 00:11:02.510
Now what if I wanted to be
able to move this around, but

186
00:11:02.510 --> 00:11:06.880
not change the numbers that Excel
was actually calculating on?

187
00:11:06.880 --> 00:11:10.740
In that case we have to change
that relative reference, and

188
00:11:10.740 --> 00:11:12.870
it's actually very easy to do.

189
00:11:12.870 --> 00:11:14.450
It's a dollar sign.

190
00:11:14.450 --> 00:11:19.600
A dollar sign is gonna tell Excel,
don't change this reference.

191
00:11:19.600 --> 00:11:21.680
Every cell reference has two parts to it.

192
00:11:21.680 --> 00:11:26.380
A column, and a row, all right.

193
00:11:27.570 --> 00:11:31.993
If I put a dollar sign in front
of that column referenced there,

194
00:11:31.993 --> 00:11:38.641
when I move this guy, And
I'll paste it over here again.

195
00:11:38.641 --> 00:11:39.860
All right.

196
00:11:39.860 --> 00:11:42.055

00:13:17.693 --> 00:13:21.580

00:16:05.388 --> 00:16:10.179
Are gonna be carried out in, and that,

00:16:12.136 --> 00:16:16.305
You might have heard of the term PEMDAS

00:16:16.305 --> 00:16:20.960

00:16:20.960 --> 00:16:24.110

00:16:29.880 --> 00:16:34.050
And then Addition and Subtraction are also

00:16:34.050 --> 00:16:35.240
we usually write them out like that.

284
00:16:35.240 --> 00:16:38.190
So, Please Excuse My Dear Aunt Sally.

00:16:38.190 --> 00:16:40.380
PEMDAS, Parenthesis, Exponents,

286
00:16:40.380 --> 00:16:43.100
Multiplication, Division,
Addition, Subtraction.

00:17:39.610 --> 00:17:41.190

00:17:41.190 --> 00:17:43.290
Multiplication comes next.

310
00:17:43.290 --> 00:17:46.480
So we're gonna do the multiplication

311
00:17:46.480 --> 00:17:50.729

00:17:50.729 --> 00:17:53.039

to change this to a cell reference.

421
00:24:09.030 --> 00:24:11.676
I'm going to say here Is my bonus rate.

422
00:24:11.676 --> 00:24:13.022
R3 right?

423
00:24:13.022 --> 00:24:17.180
And I'm gonna hit Enter and
I get the exact same number right?

424
00:24:17.180 --> 00:24:20.810
Cuz it's doing the same thing, .05 or 5%.

425
00:24:20.810 --> 00:24:25.900
Now I start doing a series fill on
this and nobody else gets a bonus.

426
00:24:25.900 --> 00:24:27.360
What happened?

427
00:24:27.360 --> 00:24:31.200
Well remember,
when I moved that formula down one,

428
00:24:31.200 --> 00:24:33.800
all the numbers that
are adding up move down one.

429
00:24:33.800 --> 00:24:36.870
Well that's good,
now I'm on Lopez, my second row.

430
00:24:36.870 --> 00:24:41.240
But where it was getting the bonus
rate from also moved down one.

431
00:24:41.240 --> 00:24:42.900
This was multiplying by R3.

432
00:24:43.990 --> 00:24:46.280
This one's multiplying by R4.

433
00:24:46.280 --> 00:24:48.420
And R4 is blank.

434
00:24:48.420 --> 00:24:50.524
This one's multiplying by R5.

435
00:24:50.524 --> 00:24:56.300
So somehow, I need this part of
the formula to move down with each row.

436
00:24:56.300 --> 00:25:00.760
But I need the bonus rate reference,
that R3, to stay there.

437
00:25:00.760 --> 00:25:01.980
All right.

438
00:25:01.980 --> 00:25:04.420
That's where that absolute
reference comes into play.

439
00:25:04.420 --> 00:25:05.310
Let's see if we can fix it.

440
00:25:05.310 --> 00:25:06.548
We go back over here.

441
00:25:06.548 --> 00:25:09.242
And we change this to say hey,
you know what?

442
00:25:09.242 --> 00:25:12.251
Do not change the column value.

443
00:25:12.251 --> 00:25:14.886
Do not change the row value.

444
00:25:14.886 --> 00:25:19.700
Leave that R3 the same no matter
where I move that formula.

445
00:25:19.700 --> 00:25:20.900
I'll hit Enter.

446
00:25:20.900 --> 00:25:22.970
This one still works just fine.

447
00:25:22.970 --> 00:25:26.140
Now when I do my series fill,
they work fine as well.

448
00:25:26.140 --> 00:25:30.968
Notice that each one of
these is multiplying by R3,

449
00:25:30.968 --> 00:25:36.798
everything else is changing,
but the R3 is staying the same.

450
00:25:36.798 --> 00:25:39.367
So you can see where those
relative references and

451
00:25:39.367 --> 00:25:42.300
those absolute references
can make a difference.

452
00:25:42.300 --> 00:25:45.590
We can also see where those order of

453
00:25:45.590 --> 00:25:48.150
operations can make a big
difference in the outcome.

454
00:25:48.150 --> 00:25:49.241
Right?
So these are things we have

455
00:25:49.241 --> 00:25:49.812
to think about.

456
00:25:49.812 --> 00:25:53.049
And we didn't really look at
writing a lot of formulas.

457
00:25:53.049 --> 00:25:57.076
But we got to see the basics that we
need to understand in order to make

458
00:25:57.076 --> 00:25:58.820
successful formulas.

459
00:25:58.820 --> 00:25:59.320
All right.

460
00:26:01.090 --> 00:26:03.240
We can also do ranges.

461
00:26:03.240 --> 00:26:05.789
Now I'm gonna,
to wipe these formulas out here.

462
00:26:08.548 --> 00:26:12.220
And we're gonna try to
reference a range this time.

463
00:26:12.220 --> 00:26:15.770
Now unfortunately Microsoft does
throw this ahead of our formulas.

464
00:26:15.770 --> 00:26:20.080
I'm gonna use a formula cuz that's really
where ranges are gonna come into play.

465
00:26:20.080 --> 00:26:21.040
Another way to do that.

466
00:26:21.040 --> 00:26:24.170
I said we could take each cell and
put a plus sign in between them.

467
00:26:24.170 --> 00:26:25.440
Right?
To add them all up.

468
00:26:25.440 --> 00:26:31.174
Another way we could do that is
to use a function I should say,

469
00:26:31.174 --> 00:26:33.656
not a formula, =sum(.

470
00:26:33.656 --> 00:26:38.395
Now, sum is a built-in function and
it says, all right,

471
00:26:38.395 --> 00:26:42.860
sum(, and
then what numbers do you wanna add up?

472
00:26:42.860 --> 00:26:46.300
And I can just do,
what was that first cell there, B3?

473
00:26:48.110 --> 00:26:52.530
I can type in B3 and
then instead of a plus sign, a comma.

474
00:26:53.545 --> 00:26:58.290
c3, and then all the way out d3,
all the way out to the end.

475
00:26:58.290 --> 00:27:03.150
And then close your parentheses,
and hit Enter, right.

476
00:27:03.150 --> 00:27:05.230
And that's gonna start
adding those values up.

477
00:27:05.230 --> 00:27:06.221
Did I not get the right ones.

478
00:27:06.221 --> 00:27:08.340
Yeah, that's gonna add those guys up.

479
00:27:08.340 --> 00:27:12.694
So if we look at this one it's
still doing the same thing,

480
00:27:12.694 --> 00:27:15.418
it's adding those three values but

481
00:27:15.418 --> 00:27:20.246
instead of saying b3 + c3 + d3,
I just said sum b3 c3 d3.

482
00:27:20.246 --> 00:27:21.100
Right?

483
00:27:21.100 --> 00:27:22.910
Now with 12 of them.

484
00:27:22.910 --> 00:27:24.800
That's a lot of typing, right?

485
00:27:24.800 --> 00:27:28.960
So there's another way I could do this,
and let me zoom back in here.

486
00:27:28.960 --> 00:27:32.600
And that's where my range
references come into play.

487
00:27:32.600 --> 00:27:38.534
Instead of trying to list
each cell individually,

488
00:27:38.534 --> 00:27:44.608
what I could do is I could
say let's add up b3:m3.

489
00:27:44.608 --> 00:27:48.442
And as I zoom back out look at
the box that it drew, right?

490
00:27:48.442 --> 00:27:53.192
I'm saying, go all the way from b3 to m3.

491
00:27:53.192 --> 00:27:54.550
Yeah, see how it's doing that?

492
00:27:54.550 --> 00:27:58.441
And we'll end up with that same value.

493
00:27:58.441 --> 00:28:00.240
All right, so just another way to do it.

494
00:28:00.240 --> 00:28:03.620
You can reference those ranges and
this won't make sense, but

495
00:28:03.620 --> 00:28:07.790
just watch the selection box because it
will teach you how these ranges work.

496
00:28:07.790 --> 00:28:10.200
If I change this to b3:m4, all right.

497
00:28:13.340 --> 00:28:16.350
b3 is basically your starting point.

498
00:28:16.350 --> 00:28:17.860
m4, your ending point.

499
00:28:17.860 --> 00:28:20.280
And it's gonna grab
everything in between there.

500
00:28:20.280 --> 00:28:25.547
If I change this to m14, right?

501
00:28:25.547 --> 00:28:30.060
You see how it now goes from b3
all the way down to m14, okay?

502
00:28:31.300 --> 00:28:34.600
With these ranges you can
also drag these boxes around,

503
00:28:34.600 --> 00:28:36.250
which is kind of a cool little trick.

504
00:28:36.250 --> 00:28:37.540
Not really a part of the objectives, but

505
00:28:37.540 --> 00:28:41.670
just understand you can move
the selection boxes around.

506
00:28:41.670 --> 00:28:43.040
That might be a little beyond this,
but hey,

507
00:28:43.040 --> 00:28:45.400
something to play with after
we're done with this episode.

508
00:28:46.790 --> 00:28:50.040
All right, Ronnie,
what else do we have to talk about?

509
00:28:50.040 --> 00:28:51.130
>> Named ranges.

510
00:28:51.130 --> 00:28:53.700
>> Named ranges are another
really cool one.

511
00:28:53.700 --> 00:28:57.030
I love my name ranges.

512
00:28:57.030 --> 00:29:00.000
They come in handy all the time.

513
00:29:00.000 --> 00:29:02.510
Let's do a couple of things here.

514
00:29:02.510 --> 00:29:06.271
Let's do this.

515
00:29:06.271 --> 00:29:10.429
I'm gonna select all of these cells,
right?

516
00:29:10.429 --> 00:29:15.577
And then I'm gonna go up to the main
box up here in the corner and

517
00:29:15.577 --> 00:29:20.144
I'm gonna type in Rodgers,
and I'm gonna hit Enter.

518
00:29:20.144 --> 00:29:20.870
All right.

519
00:29:20.870 --> 00:29:25.800
Now that is,
this range of cells has a specific name.

520
00:29:25.800 --> 00:29:29.470
If I go to my drop down list,
I can choose Rodgers, and

521
00:29:29.470 --> 00:29:31.160
look what cells it highlights, right?

522
00:29:31.160 --> 00:29:36.731
I can do the same thing,
we'll do Laura down here,

523
00:29:36.731 --> 00:29:42.561
just to make it little more obvious,
I'll say Lara,

524
00:29:42.561 --> 00:29:48.671
all right, and now I can go to Lara,
I can go to Rodgers.

525
00:29:48.671 --> 00:29:52.490
And you might think whoop di do Mike,
what's the big deal there?

526
00:29:52.490 --> 00:29:55.830
Well now I can start
using that in formulas.

527
00:29:55.830 --> 00:30:03.420
I can say equals, sum, open parenthesis,
Rogers, close parenthesis, enter.

528
00:30:04.470 --> 00:30:06.030
And look at that, right.

529
00:30:06.030 --> 00:30:08.170
So now I'm referencing that same thing,
and

530
00:30:08.170 --> 00:30:11.640
instead of saying b3:m3,
I can just say Rogers.

531
00:30:13.130 --> 00:30:16.890
And that can be extremely handy especially
when you're writing formulas on different

532
00:30:16.890 --> 00:30:21.490
worksheets and you have to reference those
ranges that are on separate worksheets,

533
00:30:21.490 --> 00:30:25.150
using those name ranges
can be extremely handy.

534
00:30:25.150 --> 00:30:29.040
Some other examples, I know we're
getting low on time here Ronnie.

535
00:30:29.040 --> 00:30:35.683
But let me try this,
let me say I'm gonna call this January.

536
00:30:35.683 --> 00:30:36.867
All right?

537
00:30:38.833 --> 00:30:43.234
And I'm gonna call this one,
you'll never guess.

538
00:30:43.234 --> 00:30:45.242
February.

539
00:30:48.097 --> 00:30:49.756
All right?

540
00:30:49.756 --> 00:30:51.854
I'm gonna try to tie
some of these together.

541
00:30:51.854 --> 00:30:56.837
And then what I'm gonna do is,
I'm gonna put it for here,

542
00:30:56.837 --> 00:31:00.112
I'm gonna say equals sum of January.

543
00:31:00.112 --> 00:31:05.740
Here I'm gonna say it
equals sum of February.

544
00:31:07.650 --> 00:31:08.890
So same thing I was doing over there,

545
00:31:08.890 --> 00:31:12.200
it's just adding up all the values
that are in that named range.

546
00:31:12.200 --> 00:31:17.350
Then over here I'm gonna say
I wanna see a total for,

547
00:31:17.350 --> 00:31:19.490
and we should do March and
then we can call it quarter one.

548
00:31:19.490 --> 00:31:24.590
So let's say I add March,
we'll call this one

549
00:31:24.590 --> 00:31:29.600
MAR, so now I've got that one here.

550
00:31:29.600 --> 00:31:35.370
We're gonna do equals sum of March, and

551
00:31:35.370 --> 00:31:40.343
then over here I wanna
put quarter one totals,

552
00:31:40.343 --> 00:31:43.370
all right.

553
00:31:43.370 --> 00:31:46.020
Now I could try to go over there and
grab quarter one's data.

554
00:31:46.020 --> 00:31:47.990
And this is a relatively
small spreadsheet, so

555
00:31:47.990 --> 00:31:50.050
it wouldn't be that difficult.

556
00:31:50.050 --> 00:31:55.149
Or without even looking at what rows and

557
00:31:55.149 --> 00:32:00.400
what columns I need, I can say equals sum

558
00:32:00.400 --> 00:32:05.210
of January, February, and March.

559
00:32:05.210 --> 00:32:07.770
Close my parenthesis, and enter.

560
00:32:07.770 --> 00:32:10.211
It's that easy because
I named those ranges,

561
00:32:10.211 --> 00:32:13.040
I don't even have to look to
go see where January end.

562
00:32:13.040 --> 00:32:15.357
Okay, it's B32.

563
00:32:15.357 --> 00:32:17.410
Where's that total at, right?

564
00:32:17.410 --> 00:32:21.510
It just took these three name ranges,
and added them together.

565
00:32:21.510 --> 00:32:25.380
So if we take a look at that formula
again, I'm adding up the named ranges.

566
00:32:25.380 --> 00:32:28.910
So the point of this is,
you can name cells.

567
00:32:28.910 --> 00:32:32.850
And even more important,
you can name ranges of cells.

568
00:32:32.850 --> 00:32:37.520
And then I can use that to either jump
to that location in the spreadsheet or

569
00:32:37.520 --> 00:32:38.550
in formulas.

570
00:32:38.550 --> 00:32:41.530
I can use those name references and

571
00:32:41.530 --> 00:32:43.930
not have to worry about
the specific cell references.

572
00:32:43.930 --> 00:32:46.493
So, named ranges, I use them all the time.

573
00:32:46.493 --> 00:32:47.924
Well Mike, thank you for

574
00:32:47.924 --> 00:32:52.820
actually showing us the ability to begin
to work with formulas a little bit.

575
00:32:52.820 --> 00:32:56.850
Understanding the order of operations is
probably one of the key elements here.

576
00:32:56.850 --> 00:32:59.360
That Excel only knows how
to do math one way and

577
00:32:59.360 --> 00:33:02.070
we have to actually understand that
if we're gonna actually create

578
00:33:02.070 --> 00:33:05.390
the formulas that we need to show
us the results that we need.

579
00:33:05.390 --> 00:33:09.820
Also we've got to see here again is
actually the use of the relative reference

580
00:33:09.820 --> 00:33:12.050
and why it's actually very important for
us.

581
00:33:12.050 --> 00:33:15.140
And we haven't even really began
to hit some of the more complex

582
00:33:15.140 --> 00:33:16.430
formulas that are out there.

583
00:33:16.430 --> 00:33:19.110
But understanding and seeing
the foundations of this is really gonna

584
00:33:19.110 --> 00:33:22.310
help us as we move on and
actually learn a little bit more.

585
00:33:22.310 --> 00:33:24.640
Mike, any final words about the formulas?

586
00:33:24.640 --> 00:33:28.500
>> Stay turned for some more excitement
because it does get even better but yeah,

587
00:33:28.500 --> 00:33:31.190
this foundational knowledge
will help you be successful.

588
00:33:31.190 --> 00:33:34.159
If you don't understand
the order of operations,

589
00:33:34.159 --> 00:33:38.588
if you don't understand how to reference
cells, ranges of cells, named.

590
00:33:38.588 --> 00:33:41.581
And if you don't understand
those relative and absolutes,

591
00:33:41.581 --> 00:33:43.879
formulas will give you
all kinds of problems.

592
00:33:43.879 --> 00:33:45.589
>> [LAUGH]
>> Once you get those down Pat,

593
00:33:45.589 --> 00:33:47.612
formulas really aren't that bad.

594
00:33:47.612 --> 00:33:48.517
>> Excellent.

595
00:33:48.517 --> 00:33:51.690
Well, that's a great place for
us to go and end this episode then.

596
00:33:51.690 --> 00:33:55.280
Signing off for IT pro TV,
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

597
00:33:55.280 --> 00:33:56.120
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

598
00:33:56.120 --> 00:33:57.997
>> And we'll see you next time.

599
00:33:57.997 --> 00:34:05.889
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike talk about using text functions to help make text values more consistent.  Mike uses these functions to help with data inconsistencies.  The guys show us how to extract data from cells as well as link multiple data values to report as a single value.
episodes.title: Sums and Conditional Logic
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.338 --> 00:00:10.338
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.518 --> 00:00:15.858
Welcome to another exciting
episode right here, on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.858 --> 00:00:21.180
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today we're
taking a look at Microsoft Excel 2016.

4
00:00:21.180 --> 00:00:25.190
And we're specifically going to be
entering into the arena of functions.

5
00:00:25.190 --> 00:00:28.470
We've taken a look at
basic formula foundations.

6
00:00:28.470 --> 00:00:31.620
Now we're gonna take a look at some
of the most common functions and

7
00:00:31.620 --> 00:00:34.230
even some conditional logic statements so

8
00:00:34.230 --> 00:00:38.430
that we can get ready for more advanced
formulas and functions that are coming up.

9
00:00:38.430 --> 00:00:42.180
And who better to help us then, well, the
function master himself, Mr. Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:42.180 --> 00:00:42.760
How's it going Mike?

11
00:00:42.760 --> 00:00:43.940
>> It's going fantastic.

12
00:00:43.940 --> 00:00:47.520
We're getting into the really
exciting stuff with the formulas and

13
00:00:47.520 --> 00:00:48.730
the functions now.

14
00:00:48.730 --> 00:00:49.490
So I'm glad to be here.

15
00:00:49.490 --> 00:00:54.650
Glad to be able to show you guys some of
the ways you can use these functions and

16
00:00:54.650 --> 00:00:57.620
formulas to work with your spreadsheets.

17
00:00:57.620 --> 00:01:00.420
As Ronnie said, we're gonna
start off with some basic ones.

18
00:01:00.420 --> 00:01:04.380
We'll start with just a simple sum and
you've seen me do this in a couple of

19
00:01:04.380 --> 00:01:08.460
other episodes, I kept saying we'll
talk more about it in a later episode.

20
00:01:08.460 --> 00:01:09.450
Well here we are.

21
00:01:09.450 --> 00:01:10.930
We are in that later episode.

22
00:01:10.930 --> 00:01:12.320
We're now going to talk about it.

23
00:01:12.320 --> 00:01:14.740
So let's take a look at what
I've got here on my computer.

24
00:01:14.740 --> 00:01:18.680
I've got that same spreadsheet up where
it's got a list of salespeople down

25
00:01:18.680 --> 00:01:20.090
the left-hand side.

26
00:01:20.090 --> 00:01:24.960
I've got the months across the top right
there and then some values plugged in for

27
00:01:24.960 --> 00:01:26.110
their sales.

28
00:01:26.110 --> 00:01:31.030
And a very common thing to do is to need
to be able to get some totals out of this.

29
00:01:31.030 --> 00:01:32.650
All right, get some sums.

30
00:01:32.650 --> 00:01:36.670
So let's start by, let's do a month.

31
00:01:36.670 --> 00:01:37.990
We'll do it this way first.

32
00:01:37.990 --> 00:01:39.790
We'll do it vertically.

33
00:01:39.790 --> 00:01:43.190
So what I wanna do,
is I want a total for January sales.

34
00:01:43.190 --> 00:01:44.930
So I could go down to the bottom.

35
00:01:44.930 --> 00:01:50.010
Maybe we add a row, call it Totals,
something like that.

36
00:01:50.010 --> 00:01:51.940
And then here's where I'm
gonna put my formula.

37
00:01:52.960 --> 00:01:56.560
Now the formula that I wanna use,
we saw in a previous episode I could say,

38
00:01:56.560 --> 00:01:58.090
let's see where this starts.

39
00:01:58.090 --> 00:02:03.148
It starts at b3 is the first value,

40
00:02:03.148 --> 00:02:08.881
so I could try to say =b3+b4+b5 and

41
00:02:08.881 --> 00:02:16.818
all the way down to where do we end here,
b32, right.

42
00:02:16.818 --> 00:02:20.200
It'll be a lot of typing to
try to get all of that in.

43
00:02:20.200 --> 00:02:25.000
So rather than do that,
we're gonna use a function, all right?

44
00:02:25.000 --> 00:02:28.670
A function's that built-in formula where
you just got to tell it what function you

45
00:02:28.670 --> 00:02:32.720
want to use, and you'll see as I type, and

46
00:02:32.720 --> 00:02:36.290
let me click away and do that again so
you can see that full list there.

47
00:02:36.290 --> 00:02:39.580
As I type, Excel gives me a list

48
00:02:39.580 --> 00:02:43.860
of all of the built-in functions that
it has that in this case start with s.

49
00:02:43.860 --> 00:02:45.530
And you can see there's a ton.

50
00:02:45.530 --> 00:02:48.040
There are a lot of built-in formulas.

51
00:02:48.040 --> 00:02:50.700
And as I type,
I get down to what I need, I get sum.

52
00:02:50.700 --> 00:02:54.110
It says,
adds all the numbers in a range of cells.

53
00:02:54.110 --> 00:02:55.980
Well, that's what I'm trying to do.

54
00:02:55.980 --> 00:02:59.760
So I'm gonna type in sum(.

55
00:02:59.760 --> 00:03:03.030

00:28:59.360 --> 00:29:02.640
So I gotta tell it this
part is not a string.

528
00:29:02.640 --> 00:29:03.890
So here's how we do that.

529
00:29:03.890 --> 00:29:08.220
We're gonna put quotes around
just the greater than symbol and

530
00:29:08.220 --> 00:29:10.550
then we're gonna glue that together.

531
00:29:10.550 --> 00:29:11.910
And see how it turned red?

532
00:29:11.910 --> 00:29:14.180
Now you can see that it is
an actual cell reference.

533
00:29:14.180 --> 00:29:18.330
And if I zoom out,
we should see in my formula that,

534
00:29:18.330 --> 00:29:20.620
now it sees that cell, right?

535
00:29:20.620 --> 00:29:23.016
So greater than S6.

536
00:29:23.016 --> 00:29:27.866
And then, because the range and
the sum range are the same,

537
00:29:27.866 --> 00:29:31.800
I don't have to define them twice, right?

538
00:29:31.800 --> 00:29:33.360
The range is Rogers.

539
00:29:33.360 --> 00:29:35.880
What numbers do I want to add up for
the sum range?

540
00:29:35.880 --> 00:29:39.110
Is also Rogers So
I don't really need to add that up.

541
00:29:39.110 --> 00:29:43.608
So I hit my n parenthesis and OK.

542
00:29:43.608 --> 00:29:46.798
And so now it's telling me $18,000.

543
00:29:46.798 --> 00:29:50.400
Well that sounds a little steep for
a bonus, right?

544
00:29:50.400 --> 00:29:55.220
That's because we're not paying him
the actual amount that he sold that month.

545
00:29:55.220 --> 00:29:57.630
We're paying him 5% of that amount.

546
00:29:57.630 --> 00:30:00.970
So I still need to take this whole thing.

547
00:30:00.970 --> 00:30:02.888
And multiply it by 5%.

548
00:30:02.888 --> 00:30:06.620
Now, multiplications typically first, but

549
00:30:06.620 --> 00:30:10.560
I wanna make sure I'm careful
with that order of operations.

550
00:30:10.560 --> 00:30:15.905
So what I like to do is put those
whole thing in parenthesis.

551
00:30:17.080 --> 00:30:19.520
Right.
And I can zoom in so you can see that.

552
00:30:19.520 --> 00:30:25.220
I'm taking that whole sumif function,
and putting it inside parenthesis.

553
00:30:25.220 --> 00:30:28.490
Saying hey, do this first, all right?

554
00:30:28.490 --> 00:30:33.750
Then multiply that by 5%.

555
00:30:33.750 --> 00:30:34.350
All right.

556
00:30:34.350 --> 00:30:35.030
Then what I'm gonna do?

557
00:30:35.030 --> 00:30:38.850
Cuz I know I wanna use this formula for
the rest of those sales people and

558
00:30:38.850 --> 00:30:42.820
if I move that formula down, this box
right here's gonna move down, right?

559
00:30:42.820 --> 00:30:43.620
And I don't want that.

560
00:30:43.620 --> 00:30:48.040
I need that to stay, so
we'll make that an absolute reference.

561
00:30:48.040 --> 00:30:50.569
We'll do our little F4, right?

562
00:30:51.580 --> 00:30:56.740
This one also needs to stay because that's
not gonna move as I move that formula

563
00:30:56.740 --> 00:31:00.340
down, so we're gonna make that one
an absolute reference as well.

564
00:31:00.340 --> 00:31:03.990
And then we'll keep our fingers
crossed and we'll hit enter.

565
00:31:03.990 --> 00:31:06.740
And we can zoom in just so
you can see that final formula or

566
00:31:06.740 --> 00:31:08.600
should we'll make sure it
works before we show you?

567
00:31:08.600 --> 00:31:09.500
We'll zoom back out.

568
00:31:09.500 --> 00:31:11.080
We'll hit enter.

569
00:31:11.080 --> 00:31:12.970
And that looks a little bit better.

570
00:31:12.970 --> 00:31:15.360
He's gonna get $900 bonus.

571
00:31:15.360 --> 00:31:18.390
So, that was really,
a little bit complex maybe for

572
00:31:18.390 --> 00:31:20.600
where we're at in our Excel lessons.

573
00:31:20.600 --> 00:31:23.590
But I wanted to show you how you can
start combining all the things that we're

574
00:31:23.590 --> 00:31:24.720
learning here.

575
00:31:24.720 --> 00:31:27.220
Right.
We're learning that sumif function.

576
00:31:27.220 --> 00:31:30.480
And so we've got that tied in
here based on a condition.

577
00:31:30.480 --> 00:31:32.740
And then we're learning
that order of operations.

578
00:31:32.740 --> 00:31:36.970
I wanna make sure this is done first
before it does any multiplication.

579
00:31:36.970 --> 00:31:39.570
We're learning about those
absolute references.

580
00:31:39.570 --> 00:31:44.790
So now as I move this formula down, right.

581
00:31:44.790 --> 00:31:47.840
Oops it should not copy like that.

582
00:31:47.840 --> 00:31:48.820
Let's see here.

583
00:31:48.820 --> 00:31:49.380
Let's delete.

584
00:31:50.650 --> 00:31:53.300
Remember that delete key is not a delete.

585
00:31:53.300 --> 00:31:57.534
You must clear those contents.

586
00:31:57.534 --> 00:32:01.097
And I believe I'm going
to run into an issue with

587
00:32:01.097 --> 00:32:03.689
my Rodgers there not moving down.

588
00:32:03.689 --> 00:32:05.152
Why is it not doing that?

589
00:32:05.152 --> 00:32:08.790
Everybody's getting paid the same
bonus for them this case.

590
00:32:08.790 --> 00:32:09.975
Now I'm kidding.

591
00:32:09.975 --> 00:32:14.960
We'd have to figure out why it's
not moving that reference down.

592
00:32:14.960 --> 00:32:20.490
So I need to come over here and
do something like this.

593
00:32:20.490 --> 00:32:21.280
Let's do this.

594
00:32:21.280 --> 00:32:26.620
Let's move that down My named reference
is gonna cause me a problem in this case.

595
00:32:26.620 --> 00:32:32.330
So what I wanna do is change
this to B4 through M4.

596
00:32:32.330 --> 00:32:39.800
All right, so
you can see that range is selected.

597
00:32:39.800 --> 00:32:40.780
I'll hit Enter.

598
00:32:40.780 --> 00:32:42.250
That looks a little bit better.

599
00:32:42.250 --> 00:32:45.720
Now as I drag this down,
these should not change.

600
00:32:45.720 --> 00:32:48.330
But these should change
as I move that down.

601
00:32:48.330 --> 00:32:50.510
So I drag that down and there we go.

602
00:32:50.510 --> 00:32:52.630
In that case it was that named range.

603
00:32:52.630 --> 00:32:53.740
It was saying, hey,

604
00:32:53.740 --> 00:32:56.850
I'm going to focus on this name
range even if you move that formula.

605
00:32:56.850 --> 00:32:58.640
Which is a lot of times what we want,
right?

606
00:32:58.640 --> 00:33:02.500
Normally we're giving this a name called
bonus, and it's never going to move.

607
00:33:02.500 --> 00:33:04.000
We're giving this a name called average.

608
00:33:04.000 --> 00:33:05.150
And it's never gonna move.

609
00:33:05.150 --> 00:33:07.930
In this case,
the name range actually hurt me,

610
00:33:07.930 --> 00:33:10.610
because the reference didn't
move when I moved the formula.

611
00:33:10.610 --> 00:33:15.710
But just an example of how we can start,
as you learn these basic steps,

612
00:33:15.710 --> 00:33:17.100
you might think,
gosh this stuff is so easy.

613
00:33:17.100 --> 00:33:19.030
He's teaching us how to do a sum.

614
00:33:19.030 --> 00:33:22.060
He's teaching us how to do a count and
an average.

615
00:33:22.060 --> 00:33:24.420
But you can start combining
these techniques and

616
00:33:24.420 --> 00:33:26.490
get some really powerful results, Ronnie.

617
00:33:26.490 --> 00:33:28.260
>> Yeah, and
the same thing actually goes here.

618
00:33:28.260 --> 00:33:31.950
That named range really becomes
an absolute reference in your workbooks.

619
00:33:31.950 --> 00:33:36.190
And what ends up happening is say hey, use
this range, regardless of what happens.

620
00:33:36.190 --> 00:33:39.410
And even if you drag down, you're
saying hey, in the original formula.

621
00:33:39.410 --> 00:33:42.595
You had an absolute reference just like
you put those dollar signs around, and

622
00:33:42.595 --> 00:33:46.860
named range is kind of alias for
an absolute reference, so that happens to.

623
00:33:46.860 --> 00:33:51.410
So, in this episode we did take a look
at some very foundational functions, but

624
00:33:51.410 --> 00:33:55.250
the goal behind that was not just so
you could do an average or a sum, but

625
00:33:55.250 --> 00:33:59.070
to show you how to actually use those
functions inside of an Excel workbook.

626
00:33:59.070 --> 00:34:03.390
Then what Mike also did is show us how we
could actually use the same things, but

627
00:34:03.390 --> 00:34:07.040
adding in a criteria or
a condition to actually say,

628
00:34:07.040 --> 00:34:10.950
hey, we only want it to happen if it
does meet the criteria that we need.

629
00:34:10.950 --> 00:34:14.025
And And
this is really where we begin, right?

630
00:34:14.025 --> 00:34:18.225
Is that we realize,
just don't simple things is not enough,

631
00:34:18.225 --> 00:34:21.485
because we need to see the data in the way
that we're actually asked to see the data.

632
00:34:21.485 --> 00:34:24.365
And if you're gonna be working with Excel,
that is the key.

633
00:34:24.365 --> 00:34:28.065
That is what will actually make
you more proficient at it, and

634
00:34:28.065 --> 00:34:30.980
actually makes you more
valuable to your company too.

635
00:34:30.980 --> 00:34:33.550
So Mike, thank you again for
those examples.

636
00:34:33.550 --> 00:34:36.630
That's a great place for
us to go ahead and end this episode then.

637
00:34:36.630 --> 00:34:39.450
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

638
00:34:39.450 --> 00:34:40.300
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

639
00:34:40.300 --> 00:34:41.810
>> We'll see you next time.

640
00:34:41.810 --> 00:34:46.988
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike talk about using text functions to help make text values more consistent.  Mike uses these functions to help with data inconsistencies.  The guys show us how to extract data from cells as well as link multiple data values to report as a single value.
episodes.title: Text Functions
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.140 --> 00:00:15.495
Welcome to another exciting
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.495 --> 00:00:20.487
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today we're
taking a look at Microsoft Excel 2016.

4
00:00:20.487 --> 00:00:23.800
Now we're specifically gonna be
dealing with some different functions.

5
00:00:23.800 --> 00:00:25.380
A lot of times, what ends up happening,

6
00:00:25.380 --> 00:00:28.700
is that you get data that you are now
working with spreadsheets, and

7
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:33.280
you start noticing different things with
the text instead, of just the numbers.

8
00:00:33.280 --> 00:00:35.820
You might notice things that
are all in capital letters, and

9
00:00:35.820 --> 00:00:37.800
they need to be put in proper case.

10
00:00:37.800 --> 00:00:40.774
Fields that are actually all
together in some way or another, and

11
00:00:40.774 --> 00:00:42.194
you need to separate them out.

12
00:00:42.194 --> 00:00:45.565
And you have only one recourse right
now if you don't know about functions,

13
00:00:45.565 --> 00:00:47.101
which is to manually type them in.

14
00:00:47.101 --> 00:00:51.536
But the great thing is, we have Mr. Mike
Roderick with us, and he's going to help

15
00:00:51.536 --> 00:00:55.937
us see all these different functions that
we can actually use to help us out here.

16
00:00:55.937 --> 00:00:57.930
>> Absolutely, and
it is one of those things.

17
00:00:57.930 --> 00:01:00.143
And thanks for having me Ronnie.

18
00:01:00.143 --> 00:01:03.095
When you're dealing with Excel, typically
we're dealing with numbers, right.

19
00:01:03.095 --> 00:01:07.889
And when we think of formulas and
functions, we think of things like sums

20
00:01:07.889 --> 00:01:13.040
and countifs and deviations or averages or
whatever the case may be, right.

21
00:01:13.040 --> 00:01:17.960
Crunching those numbers, that's what
Excel excels at, pardon the pun there.

22
00:01:17.960 --> 00:01:22.390
But we have to deal with other types
of data in our spreadsheets as well.

23
00:01:22.390 --> 00:01:27.080
Very commonly, we've got text in there,
we have names,

24
00:01:27.080 --> 00:01:29.730
months, products, things like that.

25
00:01:29.730 --> 00:01:32.910
So we do need to be able
to deal with text and

26
00:01:32.910 --> 00:01:36.180
sometimes even numbers
are gonna be treated as text.

27
00:01:36.180 --> 00:01:40.390
You know, the old rule of thumb is if
you're not gonna be doing mathematical

28
00:01:40.390 --> 00:01:44.120
calculations, you should
not format it as a number.

29
00:01:44.120 --> 00:01:48.680
Like a zip code really
should be formatted as text.

30
00:01:48.680 --> 00:01:50.910
It's not gonna hurt it to
format it as a number and

31
00:01:50.910 --> 00:01:53.510
there are definitely some
special formats that you can do.

32
00:01:53.510 --> 00:01:57.608
But phone numbers, zip codes,
employee ID's, things like that,

33
00:01:57.608 --> 00:01:58.960
that's really text.

34
00:01:58.960 --> 00:02:01.460
Just because it's a digit,
a numerical digit,

35
00:02:01.460 --> 00:02:06.180
doesn't mean we're going to be dividing by
it or multiplying or anything like that.

36
00:02:06.180 --> 00:02:09.360
So, a lot of times we will just
not bother formatting as a number,

37
00:02:09.360 --> 00:02:13.580
just leave it as general, or
maybe we actually format it as text

38
00:02:13.580 --> 00:02:18.190
to get it to a line like text normally
does to the left hand side or

39
00:02:18.190 --> 00:02:21.280
whatever the case may be or
to start plugging things together, right?

40
00:02:21.280 --> 00:02:25.723
To cancadnate, I'll use a fancy term
that we'll define here in a little bit.

41
00:02:25.723 --> 00:02:29.176
To be able to plug those things
together not mathematically, but

42
00:02:29.176 --> 00:02:31.937
taking an area code and
a seven digit phone number and

43
00:02:31.937 --> 00:02:35.612
plugging those together,
we could use our text functions for that.

44
00:02:35.612 --> 00:02:40.034
So there's a bunch of them built into
Excel I'm gonna go over the ones that they

45
00:02:40.034 --> 00:02:44.322
call out on the exams specifically and
that I think are ones that we typically

46
00:02:44.322 --> 00:02:47.660
end up using in a day to
day working with Excel.

47
00:02:47.660 --> 00:02:50.460
>> Now, Mike, when we start taking a look
at and when we're talking about as far as

48
00:02:50.460 --> 00:02:55.070
the text functions go, a lot of times it
is because we do get data that was entered

49
00:02:55.070 --> 00:02:57.950
in, and sometimes we don't
know how old that data is.

50
00:02:57.950 --> 00:03:01.040
And so what you might see is different
fields and formats that have happened over

51
00:03:01.040 --> 00:03:04.590
time on the same column, and
they're now coming to you.

52
00:03:04.590 --> 00:03:07.878
And what you need to do is be able to
separate out some of that data that's in

53
00:03:07.878 --> 00:03:09.587
that field and put it somewhere else.

54
00:03:09.587 --> 00:03:11.563
And we have functions that help
us to deal with that, right?

55
00:03:11.563 --> 00:03:12.390
>> We do, exactly.

56
00:03:12.390 --> 00:03:13.870
So let's just dive right in, here.

57
00:03:13.870 --> 00:03:15.080
I've got a spreadsheet open, and

58
00:03:15.080 --> 00:03:18.750
we're gonna start with these functions
known as right, left and mid.

59
00:03:18.750 --> 00:03:22.590
And what these allow me to do
is take a part of a string.

60
00:03:22.590 --> 00:03:23.520
And let's define a string.

61
00:03:23.520 --> 00:03:28.100
A string just being a string of
characters, again, alphanumeric, right.

62
00:03:28.100 --> 00:03:33.150
It does not have to be strictly letters,
but like my phone number here that

63
00:03:33.150 --> 00:03:38.080
I've got typed out is going to be what
we would call alphanumeric text, right.

64
00:03:38.080 --> 00:03:39.600
So let's look at my sheet.

65
00:03:39.600 --> 00:03:43.210
And what I wanna do with,
again there's right, left and mid.

66
00:03:43.210 --> 00:03:44.060
And what these allow you to do,

67
00:03:44.060 --> 00:03:46.830
just kinda their name really
tells you what we're gonna do.

68
00:03:46.830 --> 00:03:52.140
Right is gonna allow me to take
part of that string from the right,

69
00:03:52.140 --> 00:03:54.540
I'm gonna start on the right-hand
side of that value, and

70
00:03:54.540 --> 00:03:58.920
I'm gonna count characters over,
and I'm gonna grab just that part.

71
00:03:58.920 --> 00:04:02.620
Left would start from the left side,
and it would take so

72
00:04:02.620 --> 00:04:03.740
many characters, all right.

73
00:04:03.740 --> 00:04:08.380
Mid allows me to start somewhere in the
middle, and then grab so many characters.

74
00:04:08.380 --> 00:04:12.530
So what we're gonna do, in this
case I've got phone numbers, right?

75
00:04:12.530 --> 00:04:15.850
And somebody has entered this
data in with the area code.

76
00:04:15.850 --> 00:04:20.530
And let's say we don't want the area code
or we wanna be able to sort by area code,

77
00:04:20.530 --> 00:04:23.670
so I need to get these separated, right?

78
00:04:23.670 --> 00:04:28.085
What I wanna do here is just grab
the seven digit phone number and

79
00:04:28.085 --> 00:04:30.763
I wanna put that in a separate column.

80
00:04:30.763 --> 00:04:35.644
So, what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
write a function equals right

81
00:04:35.644 --> 00:04:39.836
because we're gonna start
from the right-hand side.

82
00:04:39.836 --> 00:04:45.446
So =right(, what text am I looking
at to get these characters,

83
00:04:45.446 --> 00:04:49.270
and I tell it this cell right here.

84
00:04:49.270 --> 00:04:53.030
I put a comma in there, and
then number of characters.

85
00:04:53.030 --> 00:04:54.268
How many characters do I want?

86
00:04:54.268 --> 00:04:58.219
Well, in this case, I've got four digits,
a hyphen and then three more digits if

87
00:04:58.219 --> 00:05:02.077
I'm starting from the right, for
a total of, what, eight characters there?

88
00:05:02.077 --> 00:05:06.020
So I tell it I want eight
characters from the right,

89
00:05:06.020 --> 00:05:10.380
close my parentheses,
hit enter and there we go.

90
00:05:10.380 --> 00:05:14.070
I now have just the phone
number without the area code.

91
00:05:14.070 --> 00:05:17.650
And then, of course,
I could do a little series fill or

92
00:05:17.650 --> 00:05:21.500
autofill on that and
I can take that all the way down.

93
00:05:21.500 --> 00:05:25.590
>> All right, now, Mike, does this
actually matter if the text field or

94
00:05:25.590 --> 00:05:27.700
the field that you're talking about,
like the phone number.

95
00:05:27.700 --> 00:05:31.790
If somebody had put in like a phone number
like a one, in certain ones like before

96
00:05:31.790 --> 00:05:33.850
the phone number like you're
dialing long distance or

97
00:05:33.850 --> 00:05:35.770
not when you do something
in the right function here.

98
00:05:35.770 --> 00:05:38.470
>> It really doesn't because
it's starting from the right and

99
00:05:38.470 --> 00:05:40.140
it's counting over eight characters.

100
00:05:40.140 --> 00:05:42.310
It doesn't matter what is past
that eight character right.

101
00:05:42.310 --> 00:05:46.550
Some of those numbers might have a one out
in front of them, some of them might not.

102
00:05:46.550 --> 00:05:49.175
In fact that would be a good
use of a formula like this.

103
00:05:49.175 --> 00:05:50.795
Let me undo all of that.

104
00:05:50.795 --> 00:05:53.705
And let's say we go in here and
modify a couple of these.

105
00:05:53.705 --> 00:05:59.205
I'll put a one in front of that one and
a one in front of this one.

106
00:05:59.205 --> 00:06:03.650
And I'll put a one out here in
front of this one, all right.

107
00:06:03.650 --> 00:06:08.000
And let's say that all of our
numbers use a country code of one so

108
00:06:08.000 --> 00:06:09.610
we typically don't put
the country code in.

109
00:06:09.610 --> 00:06:14.150
But some people have copied and pasted it
or they pulled data from another source

110
00:06:14.150 --> 00:06:17.190
that had that country code in there,
I had inconsistent data now.

111
00:06:17.190 --> 00:06:20.160

>> [LAUGH] We're going to
