00:29:02.290 --> 00:29:03.770
try it anyway, right?

566
00:29:03.770 --> 00:29:04.440
All right, here we go.

567
00:29:04.440 --> 00:29:06.410
So we're going to make my
field a little bit wider.

568
00:29:06.410 --> 00:29:09.410
And it's really much easier
than I make it sound.

569
00:29:09.410 --> 00:29:13.130
We're gonna just have to think about
the logic, that's all you have to do.

570
00:29:13.130 --> 00:29:18.810
I'll zoom back in here, and to make
their user name you want first initial,

571
00:29:18.810 --> 00:29:22.570
last name, @ and
then what's our company, ITpro.tv?

572
00:29:22.570 --> 00:29:23.530
>> Sure, that works.

573
00:29:23.530 --> 00:29:24.830
>> Something like that, all right.

574
00:29:24.830 --> 00:29:27.450
So let do, we're gonna say equals.

575
00:29:27.450 --> 00:29:29.400
And we're gonna just first have to,
their first name and

576
00:29:29.400 --> 00:29:32.640
their last name are in separate fields so
we're gonna have to glue them together,

577
00:29:32.640 --> 00:29:36.540
her first name I only want
the first letter from, all right?

578
00:29:36.540 --> 00:29:39.820
So we're gonna concatenate, right?

579
00:29:39.820 --> 00:29:41.960
And you can really work at this
problem in different ways.

580
00:29:41.960 --> 00:29:43.950
Some people like to work
from the middle out.

581
00:29:43.950 --> 00:29:46.390
I kind of like to start
from the beginning and

582
00:29:46.390 --> 00:29:49.840
my logic is a little bit different
than most, but who cares, right?

583
00:29:49.840 --> 00:29:54.970
So I'm gonna concatenate, and normally
I would go pick her first name, right?

584
00:29:54.970 --> 00:29:57.970
So I say all right I'm gonna
take this field right here, but

585
00:29:57.970 --> 00:30:00.230
I don't want that entire field.

586
00:30:00.230 --> 00:30:05.125
So I'm gonna slip in here
a little formula that

587
00:30:05.125 --> 00:30:09.907
says left, open parenthesis, what field?

588
00:30:09.907 --> 00:30:11.790
A-2.

589
00:30:11.790 --> 00:30:13.650
How many characters do I want?

590
00:30:13.650 --> 00:30:14.690
One.

591
00:30:14.690 --> 00:30:16.270
Close my parenthesis.

592
00:30:16.270 --> 00:30:16.900
Right, so

593
00:30:16.900 --> 00:30:22.530
now if you think in your head this part
of it all by itself, what is that?

594
00:30:22.530 --> 00:30:25.740
The first character of her first name,
right?

595
00:30:25.740 --> 00:30:27.980
So you could substitute
just saying the letter d,

596
00:30:27.980 --> 00:30:29.300
that's the way you got to think about it.

597
00:30:29.300 --> 00:30:31.690
There is one part of the puzzle solved.

598
00:30:31.690 --> 00:30:34.450
So now that I've got her first
letter of her first name,

599
00:30:34.450 --> 00:30:40.270
I want to glue that together with
her last name so comma, last name.

600
00:30:40.270 --> 00:30:42.580
No spaces in her user name or
email address, right?

601
00:30:42.580 --> 00:30:46.310
So it's first letter,
comma, last name, comma,

602
00:30:46.310 --> 00:30:49.500
and then the last part is text
that's always gonna be the same.

603
00:30:49.500 --> 00:30:50.850
It's static text.

604
00:30:50.850 --> 00:30:57.080
So it's gonna be quote, @itpro.tv.

605
00:30:57.080 --> 00:31:01.240
End my quote to end the string,
end my parentheses.

606
00:31:01.240 --> 00:31:06.804
Hit Enter, keep your fingers crossed,
and there you've got DRodgers@itpro.

607
00:31:06.804 --> 00:31:10.021
Now D and R are capitalized because
the fields we took it from were

608
00:31:10.021 --> 00:31:10.981
capital, right.

609
00:31:10.981 --> 00:31:14.080
I want it all lowercase,
that's the way most of my emails are.

610
00:31:14.080 --> 00:31:17.370
Let's just slip in here,
I'm gonna take the whole answer, right?

611
00:31:17.370 --> 00:31:20.480
This whole thing provides that name.

612
00:31:20.480 --> 00:31:25.310
Take that whole thing and
just put it inside a lower function.

613
00:31:25.310 --> 00:31:29.920
Open parentheses,
close parentheses, Enter.

614
00:31:29.920 --> 00:31:32.740
And now I've got drodgers@itpro.tv,
all lowercase.

615
00:31:32.740 --> 00:31:36.100
So, again, think of it using these
formulas, combining them up.

616
00:31:36.100 --> 00:31:38.810
It's not too bad once you
start to just think about

617
00:31:38.810 --> 00:31:40.390
the logic that you need to get through.

618
00:31:40.390 --> 00:31:43.700
>> There's no doubt that the use of
these of text formulas can really help

619
00:31:43.700 --> 00:31:48.420
you to make a new field, what we call
a calculated field, appear exactly

620
00:31:48.420 --> 00:31:52.730
the way that we want it instead of having
to manually type out all that information.

621
00:31:52.730 --> 00:31:56.826
I could not stand to type in everybody's
email address, or even a username.

622
00:31:56.826 --> 00:32:00.020
If they're saying, here's the list here,
you just have to create the username and

623
00:32:00.020 --> 00:32:02.185
email address,
I'd rather create it one time.

624
00:32:02.185 --> 00:32:02.700
>> Mm-hm.

625
00:32:02.700 --> 00:32:05.450
>> And then use that field,
let it do the rest.

626
00:32:05.450 --> 00:32:07.700
>> Yeah, here's another thing you
might not have thought about.

627
00:32:07.700 --> 00:32:09.290
Let's look at my spreadsheet again.

628
00:32:09.290 --> 00:32:12.060
Because it's a formula,
it's dynamic, right?

629
00:32:12.060 --> 00:32:13.920
Let's say Daria gets married.

630
00:32:13.920 --> 00:32:17.040
Me and Daria, we got this little thing,
and we're finally telling everybody in

631
00:32:17.040 --> 00:32:19.080
the company, we're going,
we got married, all right?

632
00:32:19.080 --> 00:32:20.109
I'm gonna change her last name.

633
00:32:22.980 --> 00:32:24.080
Look at that.

634
00:32:24.080 --> 00:32:26.140
Her email address changed, right?

635
00:32:26.140 --> 00:32:27.680
Because it's a formula that's dynamic.

636
00:32:27.680 --> 00:32:29.190
The source data changes.

637
00:32:29.190 --> 00:32:30.000
It keeps it up to date.

638
00:32:30.000 --> 00:32:31.210
So something else to think about.

639
00:32:31.210 --> 00:32:34.910
>> There's no doubt that the dynamic
nature of what we're actually doing here

640
00:32:34.910 --> 00:32:36.620
really does help speed up the process and

641
00:32:36.620 --> 00:32:39.600
a lot of things we can be
doing inside of Excel.

642
00:32:39.600 --> 00:32:40.830
Formatting the actual data,

643
00:32:40.830 --> 00:32:44.190
getting it actually appearing the way
that we want is really helpful.

644
00:32:44.190 --> 00:32:45.330
Remember when we do searches,

645
00:32:45.330 --> 00:32:48.380
it really does help us out to be
able to do stuff like that too.

646
00:32:48.380 --> 00:32:52.390
Also, when we start presenting the data
in things like reports, it's gonna help.

647
00:32:52.390 --> 00:32:56.540
All of these little functions that Mike
showed us today are really going to allow

648
00:32:56.540 --> 00:33:00.630
us to take regular data that's
actually in a string field, and

649
00:33:00.630 --> 00:33:02.980
do all those things that
he actually showed you.

650
00:33:02.980 --> 00:33:04.890
And then you'll actually
save a lot more time.

651
00:33:04.890 --> 00:33:08.150
Well thank you Mike again for
showing us those different functions.

652
00:33:08.150 --> 00:33:10.280
Thank you for joining us today.

653
00:33:10.280 --> 00:33:12.780
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

654
00:33:12.780 --> 00:33:13.620
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

655
00:33:13.620 --> 00:33:14.738
>> We'll see you next time.

656
00:33:14.738 --> 00:33:22.210
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike introduce the use of charts in Excel workbooks.  They emphasize that charts help to display the data visually making it easier to make business decision.  Mike demonstrates how Excel 2016 has tools to build charts quickly and effectively.  The guys take some time to show some of the different changes that anyone can use to modify the chart to format it for the proper impact.
episodes.title: Creating Charts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.678 --> 00:00:15.480
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.480 --> 00:00:17.380
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:17.380 --> 00:00:20.990
today we're gonna be taking
a look at Microsoft Excel 2016.

5
00:00:20.990 --> 00:00:24.870
We're specifically going to be getting
into the area of actually inserting charts

6
00:00:24.870 --> 00:00:26.800
into our Excel workbooks.

7
00:00:26.800 --> 00:00:28.770
But we wanna make sure that
we understand something,

8
00:00:28.770 --> 00:00:32.490
that a lot of times the data that
we have in front of us is so

9
00:00:32.490 --> 00:00:35.840
much data that what would be
easier is to present it visually.

10
00:00:35.840 --> 00:00:38.810
And so we've got our expect right here,
Mr. Mike Rodrick.

11
00:00:38.810 --> 00:00:39.750
How's it going?

12
00:00:39.750 --> 00:00:40.830
>> It's going great, Ronnie.

13
00:00:40.830 --> 00:00:43.610
I'm glad to be here, and
you really nailed it on the head there.

14
00:00:43.610 --> 00:00:47.620
Charts are something that we can
add into our spreadsheets to help

15
00:00:47.620 --> 00:00:49.930
represent that data graphically, right?

16
00:00:49.930 --> 00:00:52.280
When we look at these
spreadsheets full of numbers,

17
00:00:52.280 --> 00:00:56.570
sometimes we talk about it in previous
episodes where we looked at sparklines and

18
00:00:56.570 --> 00:00:59.430
conditional formatting and
things like that.

19
00:00:59.430 --> 00:01:00.400
What did we say?

20
00:01:00.400 --> 00:01:01.880
Why do we wanna do that?

21
00:01:01.880 --> 00:01:05.840
Well, to help draw our attention to
certain values that are out of the normal

22
00:01:05.840 --> 00:01:11.580
range of values, the highest of the month
or that really low point of the month or

23
00:01:11.580 --> 00:01:15.450
an unusual sales month, or to spot trends.

24
00:01:15.450 --> 00:01:18.730
A lot of times it's hard to see those
things just looking at the raw data,

25
00:01:18.730 --> 00:01:21.460
looking at the numbers,
because we just lose focus.

26
00:01:21.460 --> 00:01:24.180
It's just a bunch of numbers
that start blurring together.

27
00:01:24.180 --> 00:01:25.710
You put that in a chart.

28
00:01:25.710 --> 00:01:28.200
You draw a little line and
it's going along like this.

29
00:01:28.200 --> 00:01:30.830
Then it jumps up and then comes back down.

30
00:01:30.830 --> 00:01:32.200
That sticks out.

31
00:01:32.200 --> 00:01:34.050
You see that immediately.

32
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:37.810
If you've got a sheet full of numbers and

33
00:01:37.810 --> 00:01:41.430
three of them are red out of the thousand
numbers, those jump out at you.

34
00:01:41.430 --> 00:01:45.830
So a lot of times, we like to add
a visual element to our spreadsheets

35
00:01:45.830 --> 00:01:50.770
to draw attention to certain numbers or
to spot trends or anomalies in our data.

36
00:01:50.770 --> 00:01:52.940
And that's exactly what
we're gonna do here.

37
00:01:52.940 --> 00:01:55.900
>> Now, Mike, when we take a look
at the idea of charting data,

38
00:01:55.900 --> 00:01:59.320
I remember trying to do this during
the days when I was in grade school and,

39
00:01:59.320 --> 00:02:01.850
I wanna make a chart that
looks like this and like this.

40
00:02:01.850 --> 00:02:06.217
It was very easy for me to get confused on
what would go on that vertical line versus

41
00:02:06.217 --> 00:02:08.286
what would go on the horizontal line.

42
00:02:08.286 --> 00:02:11.611
Trying to figure out where the data
actually went was a little bit confusing

43
00:02:11.611 --> 00:02:12.624
for me [SOUND] at times.

44
00:02:12.624 --> 00:02:16.667
And so when we start seeing stuff like
that, right, what we have to remember,

45
00:02:16.667 --> 00:02:20.466
though, is that inside of Excel there
is actually a lot of tools for us that

46
00:02:20.466 --> 00:02:24.263
make it a lot easier, but it really
does help us to make a very professional

47
00:02:24.263 --> 00:02:28.100
looking chart and that's really
important when we need to present that.

48
00:02:28.100 --> 00:02:29.150
>> Absolutely Ronnie.

49
00:02:29.150 --> 00:02:33.370
I'm a little bit older than grade school
and I still have trouble figuring out

50
00:02:33.370 --> 00:02:36.460
sometimes which goes where when you're
making these charts, but as you said,

51
00:02:36.460 --> 00:02:37.320
Excel has wizards.

52
00:02:37.320 --> 00:02:41.370
Excel has ways of helping us
out creating those charts.

53
00:02:41.370 --> 00:02:43.450
Makes it pretty easy to work with.

54
00:02:43.450 --> 00:02:45.050
And it's easy to flop things around.

55
00:02:45.050 --> 00:02:45.550
Right?

56
00:02:45.550 --> 00:02:47.500
If you make a chart and it looks silly or

57
00:02:47.500 --> 00:02:51.240
it doesn't seem to represent your data or
it's not doing what you want it to do,

58
00:02:51.240 --> 00:02:55.220
you can easily move things around
to get it to where you need to be.

59
00:02:55.220 --> 00:02:57.740
It just takes a little bit of practice,
I will say that.

60
00:02:58.880 --> 00:03:03.830
Even myself, I don't do charts a lot and
sometimes I'll get a little lost in

61
00:03:03.830 --> 00:03:07.070
there trying to think is this
the horizontal, the vertical?

62
00:03:07.070 --> 00:03:10.310
But with Excel, like I said,
it's pretty intuitive.

63
00:03:10.310 --> 00:03:13.110
Try a few different things and
you can usually get it worked out.

64
00:03:13.110 --> 00:03:14.630
Talk about good looking charts.

65
00:03:16.100 --> 00:03:18.770
These charts will look professional.

66
00:03:18.770 --> 00:03:24.480
It's a great way to add that,
I don't want to say class, but

67
00:03:24.480 --> 00:03:27.450
it really does class up your spreadsheet
when you start throwing charts in there.

68
00:03:27.450 --> 00:03:30.770
I remember spending lots
of time formatting charts,

69
00:03:30.770 --> 00:03:35.360
trying to set the colors of the data
points themselves or the bars and

70
00:03:35.360 --> 00:03:38.880
the plot lines and the plot area and the
background and the titles and all this.

71
00:03:38.880 --> 00:03:39.970
Excel has styles.

72
00:03:39.970 --> 00:03:43.170
We've seen styles before that
we've applied to tables.

73
00:03:43.170 --> 00:03:46.000
Same thing is gonna work in here for
charts.

74
00:03:46.000 --> 00:03:49.304
So you can still spend hours doing
that formatting if you want, but

75
00:03:49.304 --> 00:03:52.136
if you need a quick and
dirty chart, and when I say dirty,

76
00:03:52.136 --> 00:03:56.330
I really shouldn't say that, a really good
looking chart, Excel can do it for you.

77
00:03:56.330 --> 00:03:59.367
>> Mike, when we start to
take a look at charting data,

78
00:03:59.367 --> 00:04:03.372
we've got to realize what the purpose
of it is and that's when we'll

79
00:04:03.372 --> 00:04:06.962
actually be able to decide what
needs to be in that vertical and

80
00:04:06.962 --> 00:04:11.200
what needs to be in that horizontal and
that really comes down to the key.

81
00:04:11.200 --> 00:04:13.400
But the good thing is Excel
can really help us there.

82
00:04:13.400 --> 00:04:15.480
I want to make a point
about this one thing.

83
00:04:15.480 --> 00:04:18.250
Charts really are the things
that most people want to see.

84
00:04:18.250 --> 00:04:20.450
They don't want to see
the thousands rows of data,

85
00:04:20.450 --> 00:04:24.150
they don't want to see the 55 columns
of data, they wanna see a chart.

86
00:04:24.150 --> 00:04:27.510
And the reason why is that they normally
need to make some type of business

87
00:04:27.510 --> 00:04:30.460
decision based off of the data
that they're presented.

88
00:04:30.460 --> 00:04:33.940
And if you can actually make a chart that
will show them exactly what they need,

89
00:04:33.940 --> 00:04:37.640
they appreciate it more than them having
to spend time saying, all right, so

90
00:04:37.640 --> 00:04:38.500
I see all these numbers.

91
00:04:38.500 --> 00:04:39.710
How does that really?

92
00:04:39.710 --> 00:04:41.650
Or what does that really
represent in my company?

93
00:04:41.650 --> 00:04:46.050
And so, even though it's an easy
way that we can do things.

94
00:04:46.050 --> 00:04:48.165
What we want to do is,
after we actually create one and

95
00:04:48.165 --> 00:04:50.236
Mike's about to show us how
easy it is to create one.

96
00:04:50.236 --> 00:04:52.346
We just need to verify that
it's actually reporting what,

97
00:04:52.346 --> 00:04:53.834
exactly what we thought it would report.

98
00:04:53.834 --> 00:04:54.474
>> Absolutely.

99
00:04:54.474 --> 00:05:00.005
And another little hint will be,
don't try to chart tons of data, right?

100
00:05:00.005 --> 00:05:00.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

101
00:05:00.600 --> 00:05:03.000
I'm gonna show you an example
here in just a second.

102
00:05:03.000 --> 00:05:07.590
When we create our charts, they're
usually built off of summaries, right?

103
00:05:07.590 --> 00:05:11.956
You have a list of sales people and
you have all their sales for a quarter,

104
00:05:11.956 --> 00:05:14.800
or a period, or a month or whatever it is.

105
00:05:14.800 --> 00:05:18.160
And then at the bottom of that we
typically have a totals row or

106
00:05:18.160 --> 00:05:21.220
an average or
however we wanna summarize that data.

107
00:05:21.220 --> 00:05:23.310
That's what we wanna chart.

108
00:05:23.310 --> 00:05:27.690
If you try to chart each and every sale
and things like that, you'll end up with

109
00:05:27.690 --> 00:05:30.990
a chart that's so busy that it's just
as bad as looking at the raw data.

110
00:05:30.990 --> 00:05:32.360
So keep that in mind.

111
00:05:32.360 --> 00:05:34.260
You have to play around with
your numbers a little bit or

112
00:05:34.260 --> 00:05:36.970
not play around with your numbers but
you really have to think about what it

113
00:05:36.970 --> 00:05:41.060
is that you're trying to represent and
it's usually not individual data points.

114
00:05:41.060 --> 00:05:44.700
It's usually summary information
that we're going to try to do.

115
00:05:44.700 --> 00:05:45.320
All right.

116
00:05:45.320 --> 00:05:47.575
So, let's first start by
making a simple chart.

117
00:05:47.575 --> 00:05:52.060
I"ve some data here and what I"ve got
in this workbook are several sheets.

118
00:05:52.060 --> 00:05:56.690
We've seen these throughout out episodes
where I've a quarter's worth of sales,

119
00:05:56.690 --> 00:05:59.080
all right, January through June here.

120
00:05:59.080 --> 00:06:03.420
And, these are the actual sales where
on the 21st of January this hospital

121
00:06:03.420 --> 00:06:08.560
purchased this product this many of them
at this amount, so on and so forth, right?

122
00:06:08.560 --> 00:06:12.080
Well I'm not charting this information
per se, the individual sales.

123
00:06:12.080 --> 00:06:15.900
I'll show you what'll happen if you
try to do that in just a little bit.

124
00:06:15.900 --> 00:06:20.550
Off to the side I have some summary
information for this month.

125
00:06:20.550 --> 00:06:24.580
And then I have each month has
its own little summary info.

126
00:06:24.580 --> 00:06:28.100
And then on the Summary tab,
I'm actually pulling the numbers from

127
00:06:28.100 --> 00:06:32.240
each one of those summaries back
onto this one spreadsheet here.

128
00:06:32.240 --> 00:06:35.620
So this is January for
the Florida Hospital.

129
00:06:35.620 --> 00:06:37.650
This is coming from the February sheet.

130
00:06:37.650 --> 00:06:40.860
You can see I'm just pulling
the values straight from

131
00:06:40.860 --> 00:06:42.790
those other worksheets, right?

132
00:06:42.790 --> 00:06:45.680
And the reason I'm doing that is
sometimes my boss doesn't want to see

133
00:06:45.680 --> 00:06:48.800
all the numbers she just wants
to see the summary information.

134
00:06:48.800 --> 00:06:51.650
And to make it easier to create
some charts to give me that

135
00:06:51.650 --> 00:06:52.732
visual representation.

136
00:06:52.732 --> 00:06:57.330
So, when you make a chart, a couple of
ways you can start out making the chart.

137
00:06:57.330 --> 00:07:01.520
You can just select somewhere
in the middle of the data, and

138
00:07:01.520 --> 00:07:03.230
you could actually start
inserting a chart.

00:07:03.230 --> 00:07:06.800
I will tell you that it's
usually better if you can select

140
00:07:06.800 --> 00:07:08.440
everything that you want
to try to chart out.

141
00:07:08.440 --> 00:07:09.830
And I'll show you what I mean.

142
00:07:09.830 --> 00:07:13.306
What I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
grab all of this information.

143
00:07:13.306 --> 00:07:14.006
Right?

144
00:07:14.006 --> 00:07:19.120
Now, you'll notice I get a little
tooltip that pops up over here.

145
00:07:19.120 --> 00:07:22.100
And when I hover over it,
I get this flyout menu.

146
00:07:22.100 --> 00:07:25.530
And Ronnie, I'm gonna jump around
on our list of topics here.

147
00:07:25.530 --> 00:07:28.290
This is what they call the quick analyzer.

148
00:07:28.290 --> 00:07:31.720
It used to be that we had to think
about making these charts and

149
00:07:31.720 --> 00:07:33.560
decide how we want to do it.

150
00:07:33.560 --> 00:07:38.220
Excel will now, once you select the data
it's looking at the data for you.

151
00:07:38.220 --> 00:07:39.940
And it's making some decisions.

152
00:07:39.940 --> 00:07:40.550
And it's gonna say,

153
00:07:40.550 --> 00:07:44.650
you know what this type of data would
be best represented by this chart.

154
00:07:44.650 --> 00:07:47.900
There are several different types
of charts that we can create.

155
00:07:47.900 --> 00:07:51.087
And depending on what your data is
some charts are better than others at

156
00:07:51.087 --> 00:07:52.554
displaying that data, right?

157
00:07:52.554 --> 00:07:59.136
Like line charts, bar charts,
scatter plots, pie charts, donuts.

158
00:07:59.136 --> 00:08:03.623
There's several different kinds but
some of them require two data points,

159
00:08:03.623 --> 00:08:06.130
some of them require three data points.

160
00:08:06.130 --> 00:08:09.390
So depending on what your data is,
Excel can guide you in a right way.

161
00:08:09.390 --> 00:08:11.480
So all I'm gonna do is
go down here to charts.

162
00:08:12.550 --> 00:08:14.480
And then you can see my different choices,
and

00:08:14.480 --> 00:08:18.760

hover over the different ones.

00:08:18.760 --> 00:08:22.930

think I'm gonna like the most.

00:08:22.930 --> 00:08:27.020

00:08:27.020 --> 00:08:30.330

00:08:30.330 --> 00:08:31.600

00:08:31.600 --> 00:08:32.350
I've got a chart.

00:08:37.970 --> 00:08:40.370

If i say, you know what, Excel,

00:09:17.930 --> 00:09:19.940

00:09:19.940 --> 00:09:25.530
You can go to All Charts, and you can pick

00:09:25.530 --> 00:09:30.610
Again, mine really only has two what

So things like scatter charts

Pie charts might work if I limit it to one

00:09:53.430 --> 00:09:56.170

Column chart for

00:10:03.900 --> 00:10:06.530

00:10:06.530 --> 00:10:10.690
And you see it's really the same

So it does do a pretty good job,

That's a quick and

And I could do recommended,

We could do the quick analyzer.

That tool tip was down there.

Once you get your chart made,

00:18:45.560 --> 00:18:50.050
If you want to add some glow or
change the fill color or the border for

367
00:18:50.050 --> 00:18:54.940
that legend, maybe I want to add a solid
line and I'll make it, I don't know,

368
00:18:54.940 --> 00:18:57.390
some kind of dark blue or something.

369
00:18:57.390 --> 00:19:02.780
Now you can see that blue box around
that legend everything is customizable.

370
00:19:02.780 --> 00:19:07.030
I can go to a single piece of my pie here,
and I can right click on that.

371
00:19:07.030 --> 00:19:08.360
And I'll zoom out.

372
00:19:08.360 --> 00:19:09.970
And I can change that color.

373
00:19:09.970 --> 00:19:15.170
I'm gonna say format data point,
and we'll go to fill color,

374
00:19:15.170 --> 00:19:19.450
and I'll change that to
some ugly dark green there.

375
00:19:19.450 --> 00:19:21.070
That's actually the border there, sorry.

376
00:19:21.070 --> 00:19:22.680
Let me go to fill.

377
00:19:22.680 --> 00:19:27.420
And I'll change that to burnt orange or
something, right.

378
00:19:27.420 --> 00:19:29.170
And you see that changed there.

379
00:19:29.170 --> 00:19:30.880
So you're not stuck.

380
00:19:30.880 --> 00:19:32.990
The point is excel is gonna make it.

381
00:19:32.990 --> 00:19:34.650
It usually looks pretty good.

382
00:19:34.650 --> 00:19:39.380
But if you need to do the title in company
colors rather than that default black.

383
00:19:39.380 --> 00:19:40.420
You can change it.

384
00:19:40.420 --> 00:19:42.280
If you wanna move this title around.

385
00:19:42.280 --> 00:19:49.520
If it gets in the way where it is I can
drag this guy over and move it over there.

386
00:19:49.520 --> 00:19:51.000
We can drag a piece of the pie.

387
00:19:51.000 --> 00:19:51.930
Sometimes it will let you,

388
00:19:51.930 --> 00:19:55.170
let's see if it will let me move
that piece of pie out there.

389
00:19:55.170 --> 00:19:56.540
I can break that guy up.

390
00:19:56.540 --> 00:19:58.620
How's that for cool factor, right?

391
00:19:59.750 --> 00:20:04.240
So anything that you can click on in here,
you can right click on and

392
00:20:04.240 --> 00:20:05.520
choose to format.

393
00:20:05.520 --> 00:20:09.360
I'm gonna change this back
to a bar chart real quick.

394
00:20:09.360 --> 00:20:12.650
So I'm gonna close my properties,
go back to design,

395
00:20:12.650 --> 00:20:15.910
and let's change this back to,
actually I'll do a column.

396
00:20:18.220 --> 00:20:18.750
Yeah, like that.

397
00:20:21.520 --> 00:20:23.990
All right, so there's my St.
Joseph's Hospital.

398
00:20:23.990 --> 00:20:28.360
Because I wanted to show you that you
can show the data values out there.

399
00:20:28.360 --> 00:20:32.910
If I right click on this guy,
I can choose format data labels.

400
00:20:32.910 --> 00:20:34.420
I can change their color.

401
00:20:34.420 --> 00:20:39.830
I can again, it's just about anything you
want can be customized, just select it.

402
00:20:39.830 --> 00:20:42.430
If you wanna change the font for
this over here.

403
00:20:42.430 --> 00:20:47.540
If you wanna put tick marks at
the half way point, you can.

404
00:20:47.540 --> 00:20:53.810
We can come over here,
if I can get rid of my styling there.

405
00:20:53.810 --> 00:20:56.000
There's my access options.

406
00:20:56.000 --> 00:20:59.190
If I need to see tick marks
a little more often than that.

407
00:20:59.190 --> 00:21:04.310
I want to see major tick marks inside and
you see those little lines popping,

408
00:21:04.310 --> 00:21:05.630
let's do minors as well.

409
00:21:05.630 --> 00:21:06.900
That will make it a little more visible.

410
00:21:08.430 --> 00:21:11.470
So now if you look over here
you see this little ruler like?

411
00:21:11.470 --> 00:21:14.170
That's what I just added
by adding those tick marks.

412
00:21:14.170 --> 00:21:18.010
So it's whatever you want
to do to these charts.

413
00:21:18.010 --> 00:21:20.580
As far as moving them around,
Ronnie, pretty straightforward.

414
00:21:20.580 --> 00:21:24.910
You've seen me, when I hover over my
chart, I get the little four-way arrow.

415
00:21:26.000 --> 00:21:30.290
Right, and so I can drag this chart
around so it's not overlapping my data.

416
00:21:31.330 --> 00:21:35.330
I can also go to my design ribbon
where I have my chart selector.

417
00:21:35.330 --> 00:21:37.100
Remember those are contextual ribbons.

418
00:21:37.100 --> 00:21:39.680
If I click away from the chart,
they go away.

419
00:21:39.680 --> 00:21:41.680
Click on the chart, they come back.

420
00:21:41.680 --> 00:21:46.980
I go to design, I can do move chart and
I can move this to a new sheet.

421
00:21:46.980 --> 00:21:54.037
And I can call it, I don't know, I'll
call it, what is this, St. Joseph's And

422
00:21:54.037 --> 00:21:58.300
I'll click okay and
now I've got that chart on its own sheet.

423
00:21:58.300 --> 00:22:01.810
Right, so I can make it much bigger
because I've got the room there.

424
00:22:03.470 --> 00:22:04.040
What else?

425
00:22:04.040 --> 00:22:06.480
Format ribbon,
we haven't even looked at that yet.

426
00:22:06.480 --> 00:22:12.090
If we wanna add, let's go to our, I don't
know, our data points here or our title.

427
00:22:12.090 --> 00:22:16.610
And let's go format and
add some fancy word art to it,

428
00:22:16.610 --> 00:22:21.120
our word art styles here,
see what happened to Saint Joseph's there?

429
00:22:21.120 --> 00:22:25.410
Now it's all,
I don't know how to describe that,

430
00:22:25.410 --> 00:22:27.750
looks like a neon light or something.

431
00:22:27.750 --> 00:22:30.890
So you've got all these
different styles you can add.

432
00:22:30.890 --> 00:22:32.880
We can add some drop shadow to it.

433
00:22:32.880 --> 00:22:37.120
And we'll show you some of these little
tools in our next episode when we get to

434
00:22:37.120 --> 00:22:42.500
inserting objects I tell you,
I'm gonna have to bring that ribbon back.

435
00:22:42.500 --> 00:22:45.340
I'm one of those people that just
can't stand that auto hiding.

436
00:22:45.340 --> 00:22:49.390
I try to do it, to make more room,
but it does drive me crazy.

437
00:22:49.390 --> 00:22:51.550
If I don't wanna show the legend,
let me show you,

438
00:22:51.550 --> 00:22:52.560
I haven't shown you this one yet.

439
00:22:52.560 --> 00:22:56.670
That little plus sign,
the blue paint brush is for styles.

440
00:22:56.670 --> 00:22:59.530
So I can quickly change
the style of that chart.

441
00:22:59.530 --> 00:23:02.290
Love the live preview that I can get.

442
00:23:02.290 --> 00:23:04.790
The filter lets me filter out data.

443
00:23:04.790 --> 00:23:09.630
If I wanna see both hospitals again now
that I'm not on that pie chart anymore,

444
00:23:09.630 --> 00:23:11.170
I can put both hospitals.

445
00:23:11.170 --> 00:23:12.070
And see, that's perfect for

446
00:23:12.070 --> 00:23:15.790
us here in Gazo, we got a little gator
going with that orange and blue.

447
00:23:15.790 --> 00:23:17.470
I think that actually
looks pretty darn good.

448
00:23:17.470 --> 00:23:21.580
If I don't want to show the legend,
I can just uncheck legend.

449
00:23:21.580 --> 00:23:23.590
I can take off the grid line.

450
00:23:23.590 --> 00:23:25.360
I can put the legend back.

451
00:23:25.360 --> 00:23:27.650
You can even do trend lines in here.

452
00:23:27.650 --> 00:23:29.810
I'll do it based on Florida hospital so

453
00:23:29.810 --> 00:23:34.400
I can see that over the course of six
months, I'm actually on a downward slope.

454
00:23:34.400 --> 00:23:38.130
Again, this is information and I'll zoom
in so you can see that trend line there.

455
00:23:39.200 --> 00:23:43.070
This is information that you're not
going to get from those numbers.

456
00:23:43.070 --> 00:23:47.140
Here it's graphically showing you that
over the course of the six months,

457
00:23:47.140 --> 00:23:48.760
there's been some up and downs.

458
00:23:48.760 --> 00:23:51.079
But overall, it's actually going down.

459
00:23:51.079 --> 00:23:55.023
I might have missed that fact if I
was just looking at the numbers and

460
00:23:55.023 --> 00:23:56.653
not looking at the graphs.

461
00:23:56.653 --> 00:23:58.098
There is no doubt, Mike,

462
00:23:58.098 --> 00:24:02.107
that being able to chart the data,
right, being able to take all that and

463
00:24:02.107 --> 00:24:06.052
present it the way that we need to is
what's gonna give those people that

464
00:24:06.052 --> 00:24:10.580
are actually requiring the data to
make good, solid business decisions.

465
00:24:10.580 --> 00:24:14.260
What we don't ever want to do, and this is
what Excel really does help us and Mike's

466
00:24:14.260 --> 00:24:18.600
just showing us this, is that when we make
a chart and we don't know what it means.

467
00:24:18.600 --> 00:24:20.950
And I've seen that before,
where people made a chart and

468
00:24:20.950 --> 00:24:22.520
then you ask them to explain it.

469
00:24:22.520 --> 00:24:26.700
And you're still looking at a chart going,
what does that really mean?

470
00:24:26.700 --> 00:24:28.190
Excel, Mike showed us,

471
00:24:28.190 --> 00:24:32.350
that by using the wizard that's actually
right there, just selecting the data.

472
00:24:32.350 --> 00:24:33.100
That it says hey,

473
00:24:33.100 --> 00:24:36.870
here's the type of chart we believe
that suits this particular type of data.

474
00:24:36.870 --> 00:24:40.416
And then going back in and understanding,
if you know what data you want to present,

475
00:24:40.416 --> 00:24:45.310
that you can manually present that data
and make it display however you want to.

476
00:24:45.310 --> 00:24:47.490
And that is really important, too.

477
00:24:47.490 --> 00:24:52.250
A lot of times, we do, we put too much
data inside of what we think people need.

478
00:24:52.250 --> 00:24:56.150
And all they're really asking for is, I
need to make this decision in the next six

479
00:24:56.150 --> 00:24:59.722
hours, Mike, but
you've given me 1,000 rows of data.

480
00:24:59.722 --> 00:25:04.490
Now you've given me this chart, and this
pie chart is split up into 62 different

481
00:25:04.490 --> 00:25:07.610
pieces, and they're still
trying to make that decision.

482
00:25:07.610 --> 00:25:11.490
So knowing your data is gonna be
important when you make this chart.

483
00:25:11.490 --> 00:25:13.540
Now, we've been playing
with this set of data so

484
00:25:13.540 --> 00:25:15.990
Mike knows it fairly well,
but that's the same thing.

485
00:25:15.990 --> 00:25:17.670
If you're looking at it,
that doesn't make any sense,

486
00:25:17.670 --> 00:25:19.870
it's because you don't know the data.

487
00:25:19.870 --> 00:25:24.860
The better that you actually
understand your data, the more that

488
00:25:24.860 --> 00:25:28.850
you know what you want to display,
then you can take the time to format it.

489
00:25:28.850 --> 00:25:30.940
Now, Mike,
you talked about spending hours and

490
00:25:30.940 --> 00:25:32.780
actually formatting something like this.

491
00:25:32.780 --> 00:25:34.210
And don't get me wrong, you can do that.

492
00:25:34.210 --> 00:25:36.210
And you can see why you can do that.

493
00:25:36.210 --> 00:25:39.780
But remember, a lot of times,
this is done quickly and on the fly and

494
00:25:39.780 --> 00:25:42.950
you just need to make it presentable
more than anything else.

495
00:25:42.950 --> 00:25:45.080
So, Mike,
anything else as far as charts go?

496
00:25:45.080 --> 00:25:48.580
>> Yeah, I did want to show you guys what
happens when you try to do too much, so

497
00:25:48.580 --> 00:25:50.860
I'm gonna come over here to
another one of my sheets, and

498
00:25:50.860 --> 00:25:52.800
you guys have seen this sheet before.

499
00:25:52.800 --> 00:25:56.070
There's about 250 orders,
I think, in here, so

500
00:25:56.070 --> 00:25:59.270
I'm gonna see if I can select all of this.

501
00:25:59.270 --> 00:26:04.040
So I selected all of that data and
I'm gonna go Insert, and

502
00:26:04.040 --> 00:26:06.099
I'll see what Excel recommends here.

503
00:26:07.330 --> 00:26:09.870
>> And it's like,
I don't even know how to do this.

504
00:26:09.870 --> 00:26:10.420
You can see it.

505
00:26:10.420 --> 00:26:13.230
It just doesn't look quite right at all.

506
00:26:13.230 --> 00:26:17.180
Let me show you what would happen
if I tried to do a line chart here.

507
00:26:17.180 --> 00:26:18.730
And there you can see.

508
00:26:18.730 --> 00:26:20.070
I mean, that's, yeah.

509
00:26:20.070 --> 00:26:23.790
Let's go ahead and do that one, all right?

510
00:26:23.790 --> 00:26:27.340
Now I'll zoom in for you, and
it's just too much information.

511
00:26:27.340 --> 00:26:33.141
We could try getting rid of-
the labels aren't even on there and

512
00:26:33.141 --> 00:26:36.290
it still just looks atrocious.

513
00:26:36.290 --> 00:26:40.050
There's no way to make sense
out of that much data.

514
00:26:40.050 --> 00:26:42.610
You really wanna be careful
in choosing your data.

515
00:26:42.610 --> 00:26:44.310
The other thing I'll show you, sorry,

516
00:26:44.310 --> 00:26:47.860
I'm trying to get rid of that chart,
and I don't know.

517
00:26:47.860 --> 00:26:51.210
I think it's so much data,
Excel is actually locking up,

518
00:26:51.210 --> 00:26:53.920
trying to make sense of
all that data there.

519
00:26:53.920 --> 00:26:56.210
Let me go back up here to
this little summary area,

520
00:26:56.210 --> 00:27:02.430
cuz I did wanna show you one more thing,
if I can get myself to scroll over.

521
00:27:02.430 --> 00:27:05.010
I was gonna stick this guy in here.

522
00:27:05.010 --> 00:27:09.329
Insert a chart, and we're gonna just do
a simple bar chart again, or column chart.

523
00:27:10.890 --> 00:27:15.070
Right, and you'll see that it
graphed everything, right?

524
00:27:15.070 --> 00:27:17.220
It actually did a pretty good job.

525
00:27:17.220 --> 00:27:20.807
Each one of the hospitals is listed here,
and then for

526
00:27:20.807 --> 00:27:24.637
each hospital I've got total orders,
total quantity,

527
00:27:24.637 --> 00:27:30.490
total average quantity and average amount,
so five columns for each one of those.

528
00:27:30.490 --> 00:27:34.140
But one of them is so big,
that the others, to keep it all to scale,

529
00:27:34.140 --> 00:27:36.410
the others are almost meaningless.

530
00:27:36.410 --> 00:27:38.620
I can't really tell what's going on there.

531
00:27:38.620 --> 00:27:42.190
But I wanted to show you this, and the
fact that, similar to when you're creating

532
00:27:42.190 --> 00:27:47.550
those formulas, Excel would draw colored
boxes around what you were working with,

533
00:27:47.550 --> 00:27:51.030
that formula, and you could actually
move those instead of typing.

534
00:27:51.030 --> 00:27:52.320
I can do the same thing here.

535
00:27:52.320 --> 00:27:56.360
I can say oops, I didn't mean to chart
all that Excel, let's adjust that.

536
00:27:56.360 --> 00:27:59.699
I can drag this over and
say I just wanna see the totals.

537
00:28:00.720 --> 00:28:01.470
All right?

538
00:28:01.470 --> 00:28:04.080
And now I've got Florida Hospital.

539
00:28:04.080 --> 00:28:07.050
Each one of those hospitals
listed individually, and

540
00:28:07.050 --> 00:28:09.420
I'm looking at the total in this case.

541
00:28:09.420 --> 00:28:13.990
I can drag this whole box over and
change that to Total Quantity.

542
00:28:13.990 --> 00:28:16.980
And it completely changed
what's being graphed there.

543
00:28:16.980 --> 00:28:19.810
And this doesn't need
the word customer in it.

544
00:28:19.810 --> 00:28:23.930
So I could actually drop that down,
get rid of that unnecessary column.

545
00:28:23.930 --> 00:28:28.060
Sometimes I find looking at
the boxes that Excel draws

546
00:28:28.060 --> 00:28:33.050
a little bit easier than working
with this dialogue box and

547
00:28:33.050 --> 00:28:37.950
trying to figure out what they mean by
category access and series and adding.

548
00:28:37.950 --> 00:28:39.310
Hey, just let me do it graphically.

549
00:28:39.310 --> 00:28:44.310
Just let me drag these guys around,
and I can see total orders, right?

550
00:28:44.310 --> 00:28:46.320
So, play around with some
of those different options,

551
00:28:46.320 --> 00:28:48.000
when it goes to making those charts.

552
00:28:48.000 --> 00:28:51.270
And after a few charts,
you'll get pretty good at it, I think,

553
00:28:51.270 --> 00:28:53.290
and Excel makes it pretty easy.

554
00:28:53.290 --> 00:28:54.040
Well, all right, Mike.

555
00:28:54.040 --> 00:28:57.620
Thank you again for those demonstrations
of how we can create different charts.

556
00:28:57.620 --> 00:29:00.226
And remembering the key there
is to take our data and

557
00:29:00.226 --> 00:29:03.105
to put it into what we know
that needs to be presented to.

558
00:29:03.105 --> 00:29:06.730
Well, that's a great place for
us to go and end this episode, then.

559
00:29:06.730 --> 00:29:09.720
Signing off for ITPro.TV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

560
00:29:09.720 --> 00:29:10.400
>> And I'm Mike Roderick.

561
00:29:10.400 --> 00:29:11.439
>> And we'll see you next time.

562
00:29:11.439 --> 00:29:18.840
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike show how to add different elements into an Excel spreadsheet to enhance the presentation of the data. Mike shows how to insert Smart Art to change the impact that data has on spreadsheet.  He also shows how to insert shapes and formatting those shapes to help us to make our data appear the way we want it.
episodes.title: Inserting Objects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.128 --> 00:00:10.128
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.528 --> 00:00:15.628
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.628 --> 00:00:20.745
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today we're
taking a look at Microsoft Excel 2016.

4
00:00:20.745 --> 00:00:23.950
And we're specifically gonna be getting
into the area where we need to actually

5
00:00:23.950 --> 00:00:26.260
enhance the data that
we're actually seeing.

6
00:00:26.260 --> 00:00:28.230
And we're not just talking
about formatting the data.

7
00:00:28.230 --> 00:00:32.850
We're talking about adding in more objects
into our data, so that we can present

8
00:00:32.850 --> 00:00:36.645
exactly what we want to because
sometimes data can become very boring.

9
00:00:36.645 --> 00:00:39.425
And who better to help us than Mr.
Excel himself, Mike Rodrick.

10
00:00:39.425 --> 00:00:40.065
How's it going, Mike?

11
00:00:40.065 --> 00:00:42.991
>> I don't know I've been told I'm
pretty boring as well [LAUGH] but

12
00:00:42.991 --> 00:00:45.005
we're gonna try to spice
it up a little bit.

13
00:00:45.005 --> 00:00:46.270
And Ronnie's right.

14
00:00:46.270 --> 00:00:49.810
And, thanks for having me here, and
I can't wait to do some more Excel.

15
00:00:49.810 --> 00:00:55.210
When we talk about things like smart
art and word art and shapes and

16
00:00:55.210 --> 00:00:59.670
putting those into our spreadsheets, we're
doing it sometimes to enhance the data,

17
00:00:59.670 --> 00:01:03.450
but a lot of times, we're doing this
completely separate from the data, right?

18
00:01:03.450 --> 00:01:07.830
We've got our spread sheets that do
a good job of crunching the numbers and

19
00:01:07.830 --> 00:01:10.008
giving us our totals and our averages.

20
00:01:10.008 --> 00:01:14.620
We've got our charts that are good
visual representations of that data, so

21
00:01:14.620 --> 00:01:17.530
we can spot trends and
anomalies and things like that.

22
00:01:17.530 --> 00:01:22.830
But sometimes we're using Excel for other
things, like we wanna make some diagrams,

23
00:01:22.830 --> 00:01:28.130
or some hierarchical charts, or
some flowcharts, or matrices, and

24
00:01:28.130 --> 00:01:33.855
things like that, and some people might
not think of Excel when it comes to that.

25
00:01:33.855 --> 00:01:35.835
But Excel is very good at it.

26
00:01:35.835 --> 00:01:39.675
They've actually added a lot of
really cool features to Excel.

27
00:01:39.675 --> 00:01:41.785
And they're really easy to work with.
